questions.text: Identify the thickened nerve marked in the arrow in the image shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Great auricular nerve

  • Great auricular nerve because it matches the thickened nerve marked in the image, which corresponds to the course of the great auricular nerve along the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle
  • The great auricular nerve is a sensory nerve that originates from the cervical plexus and provides sensation to the skin of the ear and the region over the parotid gland.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lesser occipital nerve: The lesser occipital nerve, originating from the cervical plexus, supplies sensation to the posterior scalp skin. Though it runs alongside the great auricular nerve, it's not highlighted in the image.

Option C - Facial nerve: The facial nerve controls facial muscles and transmits taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue but doesn't innervate the ear or parotid region.

Option D - Auriculotemporal nerve:The auriculotemporal nerve, innervates the external ear, temporal region, and part of the scalp. Unlike the great auricular nerve, it doesn't run along the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

questions.text: Broca’s area is situated in the_________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Inferior frontal gyrus

  • Broca's area, also known as Brodmann area 44 and 45, is a region of the brain associated with language production and speech articulation.
  • Broca's area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere.
  • It is specifically involved in language production and speech articulation, playing a crucial role in the ability to express oneself verbally.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Superior temporal gyrus: The superior temporal gyrus handles auditory processing and language comprehension but is not where Broca's area is located.

Option C - Angular gyrus:The angular gyrus, in the parietal lobe, aids in reading, writing, and math, but it is not the precise location of Broca's area..

Option D - Postcentral gyrus: The postcentral gyrus handles somatosensory data like touch and pressure, not speech production like Broca's area.

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve nuclei is not a part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Trochlear nerve

  • The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) is primarily involved in eye movement, specifically the downward and inward rotation of the eye.
  • It is part of the general somatic efferent column.
  • It does not have a role in special visceral afferent functions such as taste or smell.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Facial nerve: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) carries taste sensations from the front two-thirds of the tongue to the nucleus solitarius, part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column.

Option C - Vagus nerve: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) carries taste sensations from the epiglottis and lower pharynx to the nucleus solitarius, part of the special visceral afferent (SVA) column.

Option D - Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) transmits taste sensations from the back one-third of the tongue to the nucleus solitarius via the special visceral afferent (SVA) column.

questions.text: The joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib to the 7th rib is a:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Synovial joint

  • The joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib to the 7th rib is classified as a synovial joint.
  • Synovial joints are characterized by the presence of a joint cavity filled with synovial fluid, which allows for smooth movement between the articulating surfaces.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fibrocartilaginous joint: Fibrocartilaginous joints, like intervertebral discs and the pubic symphysis, provide stability with limited movement due to fibrocartilage between bones..

Option B - Symphyseal joint: Symphyseal joints, featuring hyaline and fibrocartilage, allow limited movement and are seen in the pubic symphysis and intervertebral discs.

Option D - Fibrous joint: Fibrous joints, like skull sutures, typically allow minimal movement due to fibrous connective tissue. However, the joint between the 8th and 9th rib attachment to the 7th rib permits movement and isn't solely fibrous.

questions.text: Which is the last fontanelle to close?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anterior

  • The anterior fontanelle closes between 18-24 months after birth.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Posterior: The posterior fontanelle close, usually by the age of 2 to 3 months. Therefore, it is not the last fontanelle to close.

Option C - Occipital: The occipital fontanelle is not a term used to describe a fontanelle. The occipital region of the skull refers to the back of the head, but it does not specifically indicate the presence of a fontanelle.

Option D - Mastoid: The mastoid fontanelle close, usually by the age of 1 year Therefore, it is not the last fontanelle to close.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Sibson's fascia is not correct?

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib
Not a part of scalenus minimus muscle

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

  • Sibson's fascia attaches to the inner border of the 1st rib and covers the apical part of the lung.
  • Sibson's fascia, also known as the suprapleural membrane, is a thin layer of connective tissue located at the apex of the lung.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Covers apical part of the lung: This statement is correct. Sibson's fascia covers the apical part of the lung and forms a protective layer over the lung apex.

Option C - Not a part of scalenus minimus muscle: This statement is correct. The scalenus minimus muscle is a small muscle found in some individuals near the apex of the lung, but it is not directly associated with Sibson's fascia.

Option D - Vessels pass above the fascia: This statement is correct. Sibson's fascia shields the lung apex from blood vessels like the subclavian vessels and brachiocephalic veins.

questions.text: The structure not passing through the aortic opening of the diaphragm is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Vagal trunk

  • The aortic opening of the diaphragm, also known as the aortic hiatus, is an opening in the diaphragm through which structures pass between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.
  • It is located at the level of the 12th thoracic vertebra.
  • The vagal trunk comes through an esophageal opening at 10th thoracic vertebra.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Aorta: The aorta, the largest artery in the body, passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm..

Option B - Azygous vein: The azygous vein, an important venous channel in the thorax, ascends on the right side of the vertebral column and passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

Option C - Thoracic duct: The thoracic duct, the main lymphatic vessel in the body, also passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

questions.text: The hard palate contains_________.

choices.text: Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, no salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, minor salivary glands

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands

  • The hard palate contains keratinized epithelium, submucosa, and minor salivary glands.
  • This combination of structures is essential for the functional and anatomical characteristics of the hard palate.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, no salivary glands: The hard palate does have a submucosa layer beneath the epithelium, which provides support and contains blood vessels, nerves, and minor salivary glands.

Option C - Non-keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands:. As mentioned earlier, the hard palate is lined with keratinized epithelium, which provides a protective and resilient covering.

Option D - Non-keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, minor salivary glands:. The hard palate does have a submucosa layer that contributes to its structure and function.

questions.text: What is the function of the muscle marked as A in the image below, at the metacarpophalangeal joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Flexion

  • The lumbrical muscles, marked as A in the image, play a role in flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Extension: Extension straightens or widens the angle between bones. Lumbrical muscles don't aid in extending the metacarpophalangeal joint.

Option C. Adduction: In the metacarpophalangeal joint, adduction brings fingers closer together. Lumbrical muscles aren't involved in adduction.

Option D. Abduction: At the metacarpophalangeal joint, abduction spreads fingers apart. Lumbrical muscles aren't involved in abduction.

questions.text: Which among the following is a tensor of vocal cords?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cricothyroid

  • The correct option is a. Cricothyroid, as it is the primary tensor muscle of the vocal cords.
  • It controls the tension and pitch of the vocal cords, enabling modulation of vocal

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lateral cricoarytenoid: The lateral cricoarytenoid muscle is an adductor muscle of the vocal cords. It assists in closing the vocal cords during phonation but does not directly act as a tensor.

Option C - Thyroarytenoids: The thyroarytenoid muscles are relaxor of vocal cords.

Option D - Posterior cricoarytenoids: The posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are the only abductor muscles of the vocal cords. They play a crucial role in opening the vocal cords during inhalation, allowing for the passage of air.

questions.text: The nerve of the second branchial arch is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Facial nerve

  • The nerve of the second branchial arch is the facial nerve.
  • During embryonic development, the branchial arches form the basic structure of the face and neck, and each branchial arch is associated with specific cranial nerves. The second branchial arch is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX): The glossopharyngeal nerve is associated with the third branchial arch

Option C - Trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V): The trigeminal nerve is associated with the first branchial arch

Option D - Vagal nerve (cranial nerve X): The vagal nerve is associated with the fourth and sixth branchial arches, not the second arch.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart’s ligament
It inserts into t he pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibers fan out with fascia iliaca laterally

questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Its fibers fan out with fascia iliaca laterally

  • The fibers of the iliopubic tract fan out with the fascia iliaca laterally.
  • The fascia iliaca is a broad, fibrous sheet that covers the iliopsoas muscle and provides attachment for various muscles and structures in the hip and thigh region.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract is not a thickening of the lumbar fascia. It is a thickened band of fascia that runs parallel to the inguinal ligament.

Option B - It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract, situated deeper in the anatomical layers, runs parallel to the inguinal ligament (Poupart's ligament) and lies posterior to it.

Option C - It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon: This statement is incorrect. The iliopubic tract does not directly insert into the pubic tubercle. It blends with the transversalis fascia and forms the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

questions.text: Ureteric bud develops from:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mesonephric duct:

  • The ureteric bud is a structure that arises from the mesonephric duct, also known as Wolffian duct.
  • During embryonic development, the ureteric bud grows out from the mesonephric duct and gives rise to the ureter, renal pelvis, calyces, and collecting ducts.
  • The ureteric bud interacts with the metanephric mesenchyme to form the kidney.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Metanephros: The definitive kidney (metanephros) develops from the interaction of the ureteric bud and metanephric mesenchyme. But the ureteric bud doesn't originate from the metanephros.

Option C - Pronephros: The pronephros, the most anterior and non-functional part of the embryonic kidney system, regresses early and doesn't form the ureteric bud.

Option D - Genital sinus: The genital sinus contributes to the urogenital system's development, forming the bladder and urethra, but it isn't directly linked to the development of the ureteric bud.

questions.text: During which developmental week does the heartbeat initiate in the cardiac region?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 4th week

  • The heart begins to beat in the 4th week of development. At this stage, the heart has formed and starts contracting, initiating blood circulation within the developing embryo

Incorrect Options

Option A - 2nd week: During the 2nd week of development, the heart is undergoing early stages of formation. However, it does not start beating during this time.

Option C - 6th week: By the 6th week of development, the heart is already beating. This option is incorrect because the heart starts beating earlier, in the 4th week.

Option D - 10th week: By the 10th week of development, the heart has been beating for several weeks. This option is incorrect because it suggests a later timeframe for the initiation of heartbeats.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with itchy lesions on her arm as shown. Her family history is positive for asthma. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Atopic dermatitis

  • In this case, the patient's positive family history of asthma and pruritic lesions on flexural site increases the likelihood of atopic dermatitis
  • Atopic dermatitis, also known as eczema, is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by itchy, red, and inflamed skin lesions.
  • It is commonly associated with a personal or family history of asthma, hay fever, or other allergic conditions.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Seborrhoeic dermatitis is a common, chronic, and relapsing skin condition characterized by red, scaly, and greasy patches, typically affecting areas rich in sebaceous glands such as the scalp, face, and upper trunk. It is not typically associated with a positive family history of asthma, making it less likely in this scenario.

Option C: Allergic contact dermatitis is an inflammatory skin reaction that occurs when the skin comes into contact with a specific allergen or irritant. It usually presents as a localized rash with redness, swelling, and itching. While it is possible for individuals with atopic dermatitis to develop allergic contact dermatitis, the patient's symptoms and family history are more suggestive of atopic dermatitis rather than a specific contact allergen.

Option D: Erysipelas is a bacterial skin infection characterized by a well-defined, raised, and erythematous rash, usually on the face or lower extremities. It is typically associated with fever and systemic symptoms. The symptoms described in the case, including itching and the positive family history of asthma, are not consistent with erysipelas.

questions.text: Which one of the subsequent options represents a primary skin lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Purpura

  • Purpura: Purpura is indeed a primary skin lesion.
  • It refers to the purple or red discoloration of the skin caused by bleeding into the skin or mucous membranes.
  • Purpura occurs due to various factors, including vascular fragility, platelet disorders, or clotting abnormalities. It can appear as small pinpoint spots (petechiae) or larger patches (ecchymosis) on the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Crust: Crust is not a primary skin lesion but rather a secondary change. It forms when dried exudate or blood accumulates on the skin surface, resulting in a scab or crust. Crusts are commonly seen in conditions like impetigo or eczema, but they are a result of an underlying primary lesion.

Option B - Atrophy: Atrophy is not considered a primary skin lesion but a secondary change. It refers to a thinning or wasting of the skin layers, leading to a reduction in skin thickness. Atrophy can occur due to various reasons, such as long-term use of corticosteroids or certain skin diseases. However, it is not an initial or fundamental skin abnormality.

Option D - Induration: Induration is also not a primary skin lesion but a secondary feature. It refers to the palpable or firm thickening of the skin, often associated with underlying inflammation, fibrosis, or cellular infiltration. Induration can be observed in conditions such as cellulitis or scleroderma, but it is not the primary skin lesion itself.

questions.text: What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Becker’s nevus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a large, irregular, hyperpigmented patch with increased hair growth (hypertrichosis) over the upper trunk/shoulder of a young male — typical of Becker’s nevus.

 

Feature Description
Onset Typically appears during adolescence
Site Commonly over the shoulder, upper back, or chest
Appearance Hyperpigmented, irregular patch
Hair growth Hypertrichosis often develops over the lesion
Gender More common in males
Hormonal link May be associated with androgen sensitivity (increased at puberty)
Malignancy No malignant potential

 

Mongolian spot (Option A): Blue-grey patch usually seen over the sacral area in infants; fades with age.

Nevus of Ito (Option B): Bluish-grey pigmentation in the supraclavicular or shoulder area, often unilateral, but lacks hypertrichosis.

Congenital melanocytic nevus (Option C): Present at birth, usually darker and may be nodular; typically not associated with Becker’s distribution pattern.

questions.text: Which organism is typically responsible for causing verruca vulgaris?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Human papillomavirus – 2:

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) - 2: Verruca vulgaris, also known as common warts, is primarily caused by infection with human papillomavirus (HPV) types 2 and 4.
  • HPV is a DNA virus that infects the skin and mucous membranes.
  • HPV type 2 is specifically associated with the development of verruca vulgaris.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HPV-1: Human papillomavirus type 1 is primarily associated with the development of plantar warts (verruca plantaris) rather than verruca vulgaris.

Option B - HPV-3: Human papillomavirus type 3 is commonly associated with epidermodysplasia verruciformis, a rare genetic disorder characterized by multiple wart-like skin lesions.

Option C - HPV-10:  Human papillomavirus type 10 is not typically associated with verruca vulgaris. It is more commonly linked to flat warts (verruca plana) or other types of cutaneous warts.

questions.text: What is the cause of cutis marmorata?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Exposure to cold temperature

  • Exposure to cold temperature: Cutis marmorata is a condition characterized by a mottled or reticulated appearance of the skin.
  • It occurs due to the dilation of capillaries and venules in response to cold temperature.
    • This is a normal physiological response to cold exposure and is commonly observed in infants and young children.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Humidity: Humidity does not directly cause cutis marmorata. However, changes in humidity can sometimes affect the appearance of the skin, particularly in individuals with underlying skin conditions or sensitivities.

Option C - Exposure to hot temperature: Cutis marmorata is not typically associated with exposure to hot temperatures. It is more commonly seen in response to cold temperatures.

Option D - An adverse reaction to drugs: While certain medications can cause skin reactions, cutis marmorata is not specifically associated with adverse drug reactions. It is primarily related to temperature-induced changes in blood vessel constriction.

questions.text: Varicella – zoster virus remains dormant in the:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Dorsal root ganglion:

  • Dorsal root ganglion: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV), the virus responsible for chickenpox and shingles, remains dormant (latent) in the sensory neurons of the dorsal root ganglia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Medulla oblongata: The medulla oblongata is not a site where the varicella-zoster virus remains dormant.

Option C - Skin: The varicella-zoster does not remain dormant in the skin.

Option D - Ventral root: The ventral root of the spinal nerve contains motor fibers and is not involved in the latency or reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding scleredema?

choices.text: The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal
Erythema and peau d’ orange appearance of the skin be seen
Can occur in association with diabetes
Associated with sclerodactyly or Raynauds phenomenon

questions.solution:
Correct Option D:Associated with sclerodactyly or Raynauds phenomenon

  • "Scleredema is associated with sclerodactyly or Raynaud's phenomenon." This statement is false.
  • Scleredema is a distinct condition and should not be confused with scleroderma, which is associated with sclerodactyly (thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers) and Raynaud's phenomenon (vasospasm of blood vessels in response to cold or stress).

Incorrect Options:

Option A: "The dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal." This statement is true for scleredema. Scleredema is characterized by thickening of the dermis, resulting in a firm, indurated texture of the skin.

Option B: "Erythema and peau d'orange appearance of the skin can be seen." This statement is also true for scleredema. Erythema (redness) and a peau d'orange (orange peel) appearance of the skin are commonly observed in scleredema.

Option C: "Scleredema can occur in association with diabetes." This statement is true. Scleredema can be associated with various underlying conditions, including diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Glossopharyngeal nerve

  • The ear pain sensation originating from the non-otologic source or outside the ear is called Referred Otalgia, also known as secondary otalgia.
  • In the case of tonsillitis, the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) is primarily responsible for this condition.

Incorrect Options

Option B: The facial nerve controls the muscles of the face.

Option C: The trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the face. It is not specifically responsible for transmitting pain signals from tonsillitis to the ear.

Option D: The vagus nerve mainly regulates the function of various organs in the thorax and abdomen.

questions.text: Water’s view best visualizes which of the following sinuses?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Maxillary sinus:

  • The Water's view X-ray technique is specifically used to visualize the maxillary sinus.

  • The Waters view primarily visualizes the frontal sinuses, ethmoid sinuses, and maxillary sinuses. (Maxillary sinus is best visualized)
  • It is done in the chin-up position.
  • If done with open mouth (allowing for better visualization of the sphenoid sinuses) it is called Pierre's view.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are not best visualized by Water’s view as explained above.

questions.text: The following instrument is used in
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Myringotomy:

  • Myringotomy is a surgical procedure performed to create a small incision in the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure or drain fluid from the middle ear.
  • The instrument shown in the image, called a myringotome, is specifically designed for making precise incisions in the tympanic membrane during a myringotomy procedure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D do not involve the use of a myringotome.

Option A - Septoplasty: Septoplasty is a surgical procedure performed to correct a deviated nasal septum, which is the cartilage and bone partition between the two nasal passages.

Option B - Myringoplasty: Myringoplasty is a surgical procedure performed to repair a perforated tympanic membrane . It involves grafting or patching the defect in the tympanic membrane to restore its integrity.

Option D - Adenoidectomy: Adenoidectomy is a surgical procedure performed to remove the adenoids, which are lymphoid tissue located at the back of the nasal cavity.

questions.text: How would you describe a fracture of the nasal septum that occurs both vertically and horizontally?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chevallet and Jarjaway fracture:

  • A fracture that runs horizontally across the nasal septum is a Jarjaway fracture, this is nearly always due to lateral trauma, while one running vertically is known as a Chevallet Fracture, this is usually caused by a frontal or fronto-lateral blow.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Parade ground fracture : It is a mandibular fracture involving bilateral subcondylar fractures of the condylar processes

Option C - Tripod Fracture: A tripod fracture, also known as a zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture, involves fractures of the zygomatic arch, orbital floor, and maxillary sinus and forms a "tripod" shape.

Option D - None of the above: This option is not correct

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Scala tympani

  • The electrode in cochlear implant procedures is typically placed in the scala tympani, where it makes contact with the organ of Corti and stimulates the auditory nerve fibers..

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following signs suggests the presence of a high tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: patients with total laryngectomy

  • High tracheostomy, where the surgical opening is made at the level of the 1st tracheal ring, is primarily indicated in patients who have undergone a total laryngectomy for carcinoma of the larynx. During a total laryngectomy procedure, the entire larynx is removed to treat the cancer, necessitating the creation of a new opening in the trachea for breathing.

  • By performing a high tracheostomy in these cases, the surgical opening is made in a clean area lower down, providing a clear airway and facilitating breathing without obstruction.

Incorrect options

Option A - Vocal cord palsy: Vocal cord palsy refers to the paralysis or weakness of the vocal cords, which can lead to hoarseness, difficulty speaking or swallowing, and breathing difficulties. High tracheostomy is not directly indicated for vocal cord palsy as it does not address the underlying issue of vocal cord dysfunction.

Option B - Tracheomalacia: Tracheomalacia is a condition characterized by the weakness or floppiness of the tracheal walls, leading to airway collapse during breathing. It can result in breathing difficulties, noisy breathing (stridor), and recurrent respiratory infections.

Option C - Foreign body obstruction: Foreign body obstruction occurs when an object becomes lodged in the airway, blocking the flow of air. This can be a life-threatening emergency, requiring immediate intervention to remove the foreign body and restore the airway.

questions.text: During pregnancy, in which trimester does acute fatty liver typically present most frequently?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Third trimester

  • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) typically manifests most commonly in the third trimester of pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- First trimester: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is extremely rare in the first trimester. It is primarily a third-trimester condition, although it can occur in the second trimester as well.

Option B- Second trimester: AFLP is less commonly seen in the second trimester compared to the third trimester. While it is possible for AFLP to manifest during the second trimester, it is not the most common period for its occurrence.

Option D- Both A and B: This option is incorrect because AFLP is most commonly seen in the third trimester, and while it can occur in the second trimester, it is less frequent.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 55-year-old woman who presents with abnormal uterine bleeding and undergoes a hysterectomy, resulting in the retrieval of the following specimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Leiomyoma:

  • The provided image shows a characteristic leiomyoma,
  • leiomyomas, or uterine fibroids, are benign tumors that arise from the smooth muscle cells of the uterus.
  • They can cause abnormal uterine bleeding and are typically well-circumscribed with a whorled appearance on histological examination. I

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Endometrial carcinoma: Endometrial carcinoma refers to cancerous growth in the lining of the uterus (endometrium). It can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in postmenopausal women.

Option C - Endometrial polyp: Endometrial polyps are benign growths that develop within the endometrial lining of the uterus. They can cause abnormal uterine bleeding and are typically detected through hysteroscopy or histological examination.

Option D - Adenomyosis: Adenomyosis is a condition characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the muscular wall of the uterus. It can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain, and uterine enlargement.

questions.text: Which of the following ligament is responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Round ligament

  • During pregnancy, the round ligament plays a crucial role in maintaining the anteversion of the uterus.
  • The round ligament is a band of fibrous tissue that originates from the upper part of the uterus near the fallopian tubes and extends through the inguinal canal to attach to the labia majora.
  • It helps to support the uterus and keep it in an anteverted (forward-tilted) position.
  • As the uterus grows and expands during pregnancy, the round ligament stretches and allows the uterus to expand while maintaining its anteverted position.
  • This helps to support the growing fetus and maintain the proper alignment of the uterus within the pelvis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Cardinal ligament: The cardinal ligament provides important support to the cervix and upper part of the vagina. It helps to hold the uterus in place and plays a role in maintaining its stability. However, it is not specifically responsible for maintaining the anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy.

Option C- Uterosacral ligament: The uterosacral ligament provides support to the uterus and helps to anchor it to the sacrum (lower part of the spine). It is involved in maintaining the position and stability of the uterus but is not primarily responsible for maintaining anteversion during pregnancy.

Option D- Pubocervical ligament: The pubocervical ligament provides support to the cervix and connects it to the pubic bone. It helps to maintain the position and stability of the cervix but does not play a significant role in maintaining anteversion of the uterus during pregnancy.

questions.text: Quadruple testing is done during which of the following weeks of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: 15-20 weeks

  • 15-20 weeks - This option is correct. The quadruple test, also known as the quadruple marker or quadruple screen, is typically done between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy.
  • It involves a blood test to measure the levels of four substances: alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), unconjugated estriol (uE3), and inhibin A.
  • These markers help in assessing the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities, neural tube defects, and other fetal conditions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- 9-11 weeks: This option is incorrect. During the 9-11 week period of pregnancy, a different test called the nuchal translucency (NT) scan is typically performed. The NT scan is used to assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities, particularly Down syndrome. It involves measuring the thickness of the fluid-filled space at the back of the baby's neck.

Option B- 12-14 weeks: This option is also incorrect. In the 12-14 week period, a combination of tests called the first-trimester screening is typically conducted. The first-trimester screening involves a blood test to measure specific hormones and proteins, along with the NT scan. These tests are used to assess the risk of chromosomal abnormalities.

Option D- 22-28 weeks: This option is incorrect. During the 22-28 week period, a glucose tolerance test (GTT) is usually performed to screen for gestational diabetes. The GTT measures blood sugar levels after consuming a glucose solution.

questions.text: What is the recommended frequency of antenatal visits?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: 12-14

  • The ideal number of antenatal visits recommended by healthcare professionals is typically between 12 and 14 visits. These visits allow healthcare providers to monitor the health of the mother and baby, perform necessary screenings and tests, provide prenatal education and counseling, and address any concerns or complications that may arise during the pregnancy.

Incorrect options

Option B- 6-8: Having only 6-8 antenatal visits would be inadequate for most pregnancies.

Option C- 7-9: While slightly closer to the correct answer, 7-9 antenatal visits would still be considered insufficient for most pregnancies.

Option D- 10-11: Although closer to the correct answer than the previous options, 10-11 antenatal visits would still be considered insufficient.

questions.text: What is the recommended course of action for managing a pregnant woman who tests positive for HIV during her first trimester?

choices.text: Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue life-long
Start ART immediately and continue life-long
Start ART after 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Start ART immediately and continue life-long

  • Start ART immediately and continue life-long - This option is the correct management for a woman diagnosed with HIV in her first trimester.
  • Initiating ART immediately after diagnosis is essential to suppress the virus, reduce the viral load, and minimize the risk of transmitting HIV to the fetus.
  • Continuing ART life-long is necessary to maintain viral suppression, preserve the mother's health, and prevent transmission to sexual partners.

Incorrect Options

Option A- Start ART immediately and continue till 6 weeks after delivery: This option is not the most appropriate management for a pregnant woman diagnosed with HIV in her first trimester. While initiating ART immediately is important to suppress the HIV virus and prevent transmission to the fetus, discontinuing treatment after 6 weeks post-delivery would leave the woman at risk of disease progression and complications.

Option B- Start ART after the 1st trimester and continue life-long: This option is also not the most appropriate management. Delaying the initiation of ART until after the 1st trimester can increase the risk of transmission of HIV to the fetus during the early stages of pregnancy. The recommended approach is to start ART as soon as possible after diagnosis, regardless of the trimester.

Option D- Start ART after the 1st trimester and continue till 6 weeks after delivery: This option is not the most appropriate management. As mentioned earlier, delaying ART initiation until after the 1st trimester increases the risk of transmission to the fetus during the early stages of pregnancy. Moreover, discontinuing treatment after 6 weeks post-delivery leaves the woman at risk of disease progression.

questions.text: What determines the destiny of the Mullerian duct?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Y chromosome:

  • The fate of the Müllerian duct is determined by the presence of the Y chromosome in individuals with male biological sex.
  • The Müllerian ducts, which are paired embryonic structures, develop into the fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper part of the vagina in the absence of the Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS) produced by the Sertoli cells of the developing testes.
  • The Y chromosome contains the SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene, which initiates the development of testes and the subsequent production of MIS, leading to the regression of the Müllerian ducts.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - X chromosome: This option is incorrect. The presence of the X chromosome alone does not determine the fate of the Müllerian duct. The X chromosome carries genetic information related to various traits and functions, but it does not directly influence the development of the Müllerian duct.

Option C - 1st chromosome: This option is incorrect. Humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes, numbered from 1 to 22, plus the sex chromosomes (X and Y). The fate of the Müllerian duct is not determined by a specific "1st chromosome."

Option D - 2nd chromosome: This option is incorrect. The sex chromosomes in humans are labeled as X and Y, and the Müllerian duct development is specifically influenced by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome.

questions.text: After the insertion of a pessary, what is the initial action to assess its proper retention?

choices.text: Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place
Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained
Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place
Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place:

  • This is the appropriate first step to check if the pessary is adequately retained.
  • The Valsalva maneuver involves asking the patient to bear down or strain as if having a bowel movement while holding their breath.
  • This maneuver increases intra-abdominal pressure, and if the pessary is properly fitted and retained, it should remain in place during the maneuver.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place- Voiding (urinating) does not specifically test the retention of the pessary.

Option B - Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained- The presence or absence of discomfort alone is not a reliable indicator of whether the pessary is adequately retained.

Option D - Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary - Admitting two fingers between the ring and the pessary suggests that the pessary is not adequately fitted or retained.

questions.text: A pregnant women presents with obstructed labor and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Cesarean section

  • Cesarean section: This is the appropriate management for a pregnant woman presenting with obstructed labor and fetal demise.
  • In cases of fetal demise, where the baby has died in the uterus,a cesarean section is performed to deliver the baby and provide necessary medical care to the mother.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Craniotomy- Craniotomy involves the surgical procedure of opening the skull. It is not an appropriate management option for obstructed labor with fetal demise. Craniotomy is occasionally performed in cases of severe fetal malformations or abnormalities where vaginal delivery is not feasible, but it is not the appropriate management in the given scenario.

Option B: Decapitation - Decapitation refers to the removal of the baby's head during childbirth. It is an extremely rare and extreme procedure performed only in very specific circumstances where vaginal delivery is impossible, and cesarean section is not feasible or safe. Decapitation is not a standard management option for obstructed labor with fetal demise.

Option D: Forceps extraction - Forceps extraction involves using specialized surgical instruments (forceps) to assist in the delivery of the baby's head during vaginal delivery. However, in the case of obstructed labor with fetal demise, forceps extraction may not be possible or appropriate.

questions.text: When is the most optimal period to determine the type of twin pregnancy using ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: 11-14 weeks

  • This is the best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound.
  • During this scan, the sonographer can also assess the number of gestational sacs, placentas, and amniotic fluid levels, which helps determine the type of twin pregnancy.
  • Identifying the presence of two separate gestational sacs and placentas during this time indicates a dizygotic (fraternal) twin pregnancy, while a single gestational sac and placenta suggest a monozygotic (identical) twin pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 18-22 weeks - While an ultrasound performed between 18-22 weeks can provide detailed information about fetal anatomy and development, it may not be the ideal time to accurately determine the type of twin pregnancy. By this stage, the anatomical features of the fetuses and their placentas may be more developed and distinguishable, but earlier ultrasound examinations, particularly in the first trimester, are typically more reliable in determining the type of twin pregnancy.

Option B: 24-28 weeks - Although an ultrasound performed between 24-28 weeks can provide valuable information about the growth and development of the fetuses, it is not the best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy. By this stage, the placentas and amniotic sacs may have undergone changes and may not be as clearly distinguishable as in earlier stages of pregnancy.

Option D: 14-18 weeks - While an ultrasound performed between 14-18 weeks can provide important information about fetal development, it may not be the optimal time to accurately determine the type of twin pregnancy. At this stage, the differentiation between monozygotic and dizygotic twins may not be as apparent, and the sonographer may not be able to visualize the necessary details for a definitive identification.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the umbilical cord is not true?

choices.text: It has one artery and two veins
It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly
Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies
Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cms

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: It has one artery and two veins

  • It has one artery and two veins - This statement is false.
  • The umbilical cord typically contains two umbilical artery and one umbilical vein.
  • The umbilical artery carries deoxygenated blood and waste products from the fetus to the placenta, while the umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood and nutrients from the placenta to the fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly - This statement is true. The umbilical cord is composed of Wharton's jelly, a gelatinous substance that provides structural support and cushioning for the blood vessels within the cord. It helps to protect the vessels from compression and ensures efficient blood flow between the fetus and the placenta.

Option C: Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies - This statement is true. In some cases, the umbilical cord may have only one umbilical artery instead of the usual two. This condition, known as a single umbilical artery (SUA), is associated with a higher risk of certain congenital anomalies, such as heart defects, renal abnormalities, and chromosomal abnormalities. However, it is important to note that the presence of a single umbilical artery does not always indicate the presence of these anomalies, and further evaluation and testing may be required.

Option D: Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm - This statement is true. The normal average length of the umbilical cord is typically around 50-60 cm in the normal full term newborn.

questions.text: Which of the statements below is incorrect regarding non-invasive prenatal testing?

choices.text: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum
It is used for the diagnosis of trisomy 13,18 and 21
It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation
It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

questions.solution:
Option D. It is done after the routine first-trimester ultrasound assessment.

Explanation:

Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening test that analyzes cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum to assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities in the fetus. NIPT is typically performed after 10 weeks of gestation and can be done independently of the routine first-trimester ultrasound assessment. It is not directly related to the timing of the ultrasound. NIPT is commonly used to detect trisomy 13, 18, and 21 (Down syndrome) in the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contribute to the development of secondary primary postpartum hemorrhage(PPH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Placenta previa

  • Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix, leading to bleeding during pregnancy or delivery.
  • Placenta previa is a potential cause of primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to antepartum bleeding but is not typically associated with secondary PPH, which refers to excessive bleeding occurring after the first 24 hours postpartum.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Retained cotyledon - Retained cotyledon refers to a portion of the placenta or fetal membranes that remains inside the uterus following childbirth. It can cause secondary PPH if not properly expelled, as it can lead to persistent bleeding and uterine atony (lack of uterine muscle tone).

Option B: Endometritis - Endometritis refers to inflammation or infection of the endometrium, the inner lining of the uterus. It can occur after delivery and can contribute to secondary PPH due to increased uterine activity and impaired uterine involution.

Option C: Placental polyp - A placental polyp is a rare condition where a piece of placental tissue remains attached to the uterine wall after delivery. It can lead to persistent bleeding and secondary PPH if not properly managed.

questions.text:
What is the likely diagnosis for a 16-year-old girl presenting with primary amenorrhea and the following characteristics?


	Normal stature
	Thelarche – absent
	FSH, LH – high
	Karyotype – 46 XX
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Gonadal dysgenesis:

  • Gonadal dysgenesis - This option is the most probable diagnosis for the given features.
  • Gonadal dysgenesis refers to the incomplete development or absence of the gonads (ovaries or testes).
  • It can present with primary amenorrhea, but the presence of high FSH and LH levels suggests ovarian dysfunction.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Testicular feminizing syndrome (Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome) - It occurs in karyotype XY.

Option C - Kallmann syndrome - Kallmann syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by delayed or absent puberty due to a deficiency of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion. It has low LH and FSH

Option D - Turner syndrome - Turner syndrome is a genetic condition that occurs in females with a missing or incomplete X chromosome (45 XO karyotype).

questions.text: Fimbriectomy is also known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Kroener’s procedure:

  • The technique of fimbriectomy as described by Kroener employs the ligation of the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures and then division and removal of the infundibulum of the tube.
  • Ligation and hemostasis are accomplished simultaneously.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pomeroy technique - This is most commonly done, wherein a single ligature is used, and ends are cut. However, the tube cut end are together, which can lead to fistula formation leading to failure

Option B - Uchida’s procedure - Sub Serosal Dissection of Tube (UCHIDA'S Procedure): Serosa is lifted by needle & saline is injected, then serosa is incised, and tube is resected. The serosa is sutured again. The advantage is that fibrosis & adhesions are very less, as cut ends are within the serosa

Option D - Irwing’s procedure -One end of tube is buried into uterine musculature and the other end of tube is buried into mesosalpinx

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is unable to pass through the placenta?  A. Iron  B. Albumin  C. Immunoglobulin M  D. Immunoglobulin G
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: B and C

  • Albumin: Albumin is a protein found in the blood. It is too large to cross the placenta, and therefore, it does not pass from the maternal bloodstream to the fetal circulation.
  • Immunoglobulin M (IgM): IgM is an antibody involved in the immune response. It is a large molecule and does not cross the placenta easily. Therefore, IgM antibodies present in the maternal bloodstream do not typically transfer to the fetal circulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: This option in incorrect, as albumin is too large to cross the placenta,

Option B: This option in incorrect, as IgM is a large molecule and does not cross the placenta

Option D: this option in incorrect, as IgM is a large molecule and does not cross the placenta

questions.text: In which situations is dilatation and curettage considered inappropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Pelvic inflammatory disease

  • Dilatation and curettage (D&C) is contraindicated in the presence of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Ectopic pregnancy- D&C is not the preferred treatment for ectopic pregnancy. In cases of ectopic pregnancy, the primary management is typically through medication (methotrexate) or surgical intervention (laparoscopic surgery). D&C is not appropriate for treating ectopic pregnancy.

Option C: Menstrual irregularities- D&C can be used as a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure for certain types of menstrual irregularities, such as abnormal uterine bleeding or excessive tissue growth in the uterus (endometrial hyperplasia). However, it is not contraindicated for menstrual irregularities.

Option D: Endometriosis- D&C is not a primary treatment for endometriosis. The management of endometriosis typically involves hormonal therapy, pain management, or surgical interventions such as laparoscopy. However, D&C may be performed in certain cases for diagnostic purposes or to remove endometrial tissue in conjunction with other treatments.

questions.text: What should be the next step in managing a 45-year-old woman who presents with post-coital bleeding and has a positive pap smear result?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Colposcopy directed biopsy:

  • In cases of post-coital bleeding and a positive pap smear, colposcopy directed biopsy is an appropriate next step to further evaluate the cervix and obtain tissue samples for pathological examination.
  • Colposcopy allows for a detailed visualization of any abnormal areas and helps guide targeted biopsies of suspicious lesions.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cone biopsy- Cone biopsy may be considered if colposcopy reveals significant abnormalities or if there is a need for more extensive tissue sampling. However, it is not the initial step in the management of post-coital bleeding and a positive pap smear.

Option C - Repeat pap smear- A repeat pap smear may be indicated in certain circumstances, such as if the initial pap smear was inadequate or if there are concerns about sample quality.

Option D - Hysterectomy- Hysterectomy, the surgical removal of the uterus, is not the initial management for post-coital bleeding and a positive pap smear.

questions.text: What is observed in cases of superfecundation?

choices.text: Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse
Fertilization of 2 ova released in the same cycle by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasion

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Fertilization of 2 ova released in the same cycle by sperms released at intercourse on 2 different occasion

  • Fertilization of 2 ova released in the same cycle by sperms released at intercourse on two different occasions. This is the correct definition of superfecundation.
  • It occurs when a woman releases multiple eggs during a single menstrual cycle and each egg is fertilized by a different sperm from separate acts of intercourse occurring at different times.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Fertilization of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at a single intercourse. This scenario describes ordinary fraternal (dizygotic) twins, where two separate eggs are released and fertilized by two different sperm during a single act of intercourse. Superfecundation, however, involves the fertilization of ova released at different times within the same cycle.

Option C: Both of the above- This option is incorrect because option A describes fraternal twins, not superfecundation. Superfecundation specifically refers to the fertilization of multiple ova in the same cycle by sperms from different instances of intercourse.

Option D: None of the above- This option is also incorrect as option B accurately describes superfecundation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding peripartum cardiomyopathy?

choices.text: Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery
Left ventricular end diastolic dimension more than 10 cm/m2 .

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Left ventricular end diastolic dimension more than 10 cm/m2 .

  • Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. This option is incorrect.
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy primarily involves Left ventricular end diastolic dimension more than 2.7 cm/m2 .

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery- This is true for peripartum cardiomyopathy. PPCM is defined as the development of heart failure symptoms and left ventricular dysfunction in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months after delivery, excluding other known causes of heart failure.

Option C: Absence of identifiable cause- This is true for peripartum cardiomyopathy. The exact cause of PPCM is unknown, and there are no identifiable factors or conditions that can consistently predict its occurrence. It is considered idiopathic, meaning without a known cause.

Option D: Ejection fraction less than 45% - This is true for peripartum cardiomyopathy. Ejection fraction less than 45% is present.

questions.text: Which of the options below does not describe the mechanism of action of progesterone-only pills?

choices.text: Kills the sperms in the cervical canal

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Kills the sperms in the cervical canal:

  • Progesterone-only pills do not have a direct spermicidal effect.
  • Their main mechanism of action is related to cervical mucus changes and inhibiting sperm penetration.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Thicken the cervical mucus- Progesterone-only pills work by thickening the cervical mucus, making it more difficult for sperm to pass through the cervix and reach the uterus. This mechanism helps to prevent fertilization.

Option B - Prevents ovulation- progesterone-only pills primarily work by inhibiting ovulation.

Option D - Inhibits penetration of sperm- Progesterone-only pills can inhibit the penetration of sperm into the upper reproductive tract by altering the cervical mucus consistency. The thickened cervical mucus serves as a physical barrier to prevent sperm from reaching the fallopian tubes and fertilizing an egg.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not regarded as a contributing factor for a pregnancy with an increased risk?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Previous manual removal of placenta

  • Previous manual removal of the placenta, although it may have been associated with complications in the past, is not typically considered as a factor for a high-risk pregnancy.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Obesity- Obesity is considered a factor for a high-risk pregnancy. Obesity is associated with various complications during pregnancy, including gestational diabetes, preeclampsia, preterm birth, macrosomia (large baby), and increased risk of cesarean delivery. It can also increase the risk of maternal health issues such as hypertension and cardiovascular diseases.

Option B: Polyhydramnios- Polyhydramnios, which refers to an excessive amount of amniotic fluid, is considered a factor for a high-risk pregnancy. It can be associated with complications such as preterm birth, fetal malpresentation, umbilical cord prolapse, and placental abruption.

Option C: Anaemia- Anaemia, which is a deficiency of red blood cells or hemoglobin in the blood, is considered a factor for a high-risk pregnancy. Severe anemia during pregnancy can increase the risk of preterm birth, low birth weight, and maternal complications such as preeclampsia and postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions may result from chronic pelvic inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pyometra:

  • Long-standing pelvic inflammation, particularly involving the uterus and fallopian tubes, can lead to the development of pyometra.
  • Pyometra is a condition characterized by the accumulation of pus within the uterine cavity. It is usually associated with bacterial infection and can occur as a result of untreated or chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Uterine polyposis- Uterine polyposis refers to the presence of multiple polyps in the uterine cavity. While chronic inflammation can contribute to the development of uterine polyps, it is not specifically linked to long-standing pelvic inflammation as a direct consequence.

Option C - Pseudocyesis- Pseudocyesis, also known as false pregnancy or phantom pregnancy, is a condition in which a person experiences symptoms of pregnancy, such as missed periods, abdominal enlargement, and even perceived fetal movements, despite not being pregnant.

Option D - Endometrial hyperplasia- Endometrial hyperplasia refers to the excessive proliferation of the endometrium, the inner lining of the uterus. While chronic inflammation may contribute to endometrial hyperplasia in some cases, it is not the primary outcome of long-standing pelvic inflammation.

questions.text: What is the most frequent manifestation of postpartum nerve injury among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Foot drop

  • Foot drop is the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury.
  • Foot drop refers to the difficulty or inability to lift the front part of the foot properly, leading to a dragging or slapping gait.
  • It is most commonly caused by damage to the peroneal nerve, which innervates the muscles involved in foot dorsiflexion.
  • Postpartum nerve injury resulting in foot drop can occur due to various factors, including prolonged pressure on the nerves during labor or the use of forceps or vacuum extraction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Facial palsy- Facial palsy, also known as Bell's palsy, is characterized by the weakness or paralysis of the muscles on one side of the face. It is most commonly caused by damage or inflammation of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). While facial palsy can occur in the postpartum period, it is not the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury.

Option B: Wrist drop- Wrist drop refers to the inability to extend or lift the wrist properly. It is typically caused by injury or compression of the radial nerve, which runs along the back of the forearm. While nerve injuries can occur during childbirth, resulting in conditions like brachial plexus injury, wrist drop is not the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury.

Option D: Claw hand- Claw hand refers to a deformity in which the hand appears with bent or curved fingers resembling a claw. It can result from different causes, including nerve injuries such as ulnar nerve compression or injury. However, claw hand is not typically associated with postpartum nerve injury as the most common presentation.

questions.text: What is altered in the thyroid profile throughout pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option - Total T3

  • Total T3 and Total T4 levels increase during pregnancy.
  • This is due to the elevated levels of estrogen, which increase the production of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG).
  • The increased TBG binds more thyroid hormones, resulting in higher total (but not free) thyroid hormone levels.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D:

  • Free T3 and Free T4 levels typically remain within the normal range.
  • TSH levels may decrease slightly in the first trimester but generally stay within the normal range.

questions.text: Which is the first organ to putrefy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Brain:

  • When it comes to decomposition or putrefaction of the body after death, the brain is generally the first organ to undergo significant decomposition.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Heart: Heart may undergo changes after death, such as loss of contractility and blood circulation, it does not typically decompose as rapidly as the brain.

Option C - Kidney: Kidneys can be affected by postmortem changes, they generally do not decompose as quickly as the brain.

Option D - Prostate: Prostate may undergo changes after death, but it does not decompose as rapidly as the brain.

questions.text: Which article in the constitution does not pertain to children?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Article 42:

  • 42," is the correct answer as it is not directly related to children.

  • Article 42 of the Indian Constitution focuses on the provision of just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Article 21A: Article 21A of the Indian Constitution relates to the Right to Education. It states that the State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children in the age group of 6 to 14 years.

Option B - Article 24: Article 24 of the Indian Constitution deals with the prohibition of child labor.

Option C - Article 45: Article 45 of the Indian Constitution pertains to the provision of early childhood care and education for children below the age of six years.

questions.text: In which Section does McNaughten's rule fall under?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Section 84 of IPC

  • The correct option is option B, which states that McNaughten's rule falls under Section 84 of the IPC.
  • This section deals with the defense of insanity in criminal cases and provides guidelines for determining the criminal responsibility of a person suffering from a mental illness at the time of committing an act.

Incorrect options

Option A - Section 83 of CrPC: It does not relate to McNaughten's rule.

Option C - Section 184 of IPC: It does not relate to McNaughten's rule.

Option D - Section 184 of CrPC: It does not relate to McNaughten's rule.

questions.text: Luminescent stools are associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Phosphorus:

  • Luminescent stools are associated with phosphorus.
  • High levels of phosphorus ingestion or phosphorus poisoning can sometimes cause stools to exhibit a luminescent or glowing appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mercury: Mercury is a toxic heavy metal that can cause various health issues when ingested. However, it is not typically associated with luminescent stools.

Option B - Cadmium: Cadmium is another toxic heavy metal that can be harmful to human health. Like mercury, it is not commonly associated with luminescent stools.

Option D - Oxalic acid: Oxalic acid is a naturally occurring compound found in various foods. Ingesting oxalic acid in normal amounts does not typically result in luminescent stools.

questions.text: Which of the following poisons present with bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa on post mortem examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sodium amytal:

  • Sodium amytal is known to cause bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa on post-mortem examination

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oxalic acid: Oxalic acid is not typically associated with bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa on post-mortem examination.

Option C - Soneryl: Soneryl is the trade name for a medication called amitriptyline, which is a tricyclic antidepressant. It is not known to cause bluish discoloration of the stomach mucosa.

Option D - Arsenic: It is known to cause red velvety discoloration of the stomach mucosa.

questions.text: Saturnine gout is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lead poisoning:

  • Saturnine gout refers to gout-like symptoms caused by chronic lead poisoning.

  • Lead exposure can interfere with the kidneys' ability to excrete uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia (elevated levels of uric acid in the blood).

  • This can result in the deposition of urate crystals in the joints, causing gout-like symptoms.

  • This condition was historically seen in people exposed to lead, such as those who drank wine sweetened with lead or worked in industries with high lead exposure.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cadmium poisoning: Cadmium poisoning primarily affects the kidneys and can cause kidney damage, but it is not specifically associated with Saturnine gout.

Option C - Beryllium poisoning: Beryllium poisoning is associated with lung disease (berylliosis) and is not directly linked to Saturnine gout.

Option D - Mercury poisoning: Mercury poisoning primarily affects the nervous system and can lead to symptoms such as tremors, cognitive impairments, and sensory disturbances. It is not specifically associated with Saturnine gout.

questions.text: At what age, basiocciput fuses with basisphenoid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 18-22 years:

  • The fusion of the basiocciput (the base of the occipital bone) with the basisphenoid (part of the sphenoid bone) occurs ib 18-22 years

Skull Sutures

  • 1st Suture: Metopic at 9 months

  • Last Suture: Squamous temporal >= 80 yr

  • Sagittal (best)

    • Posterior ⅓ 20-40 yrs

    • Anterior ⅓ 40-50 yrs

    • Middle ⅓ >50 yrs

  • Coronal

    • Upper half

      • 50-60yrs

    • Lower half

      • 40-50 yrs

  • Lambdoid

    • Upper half

      • 50-60 yrs

    • Lower half

      • 60-70 yrs

  • Basiocciput with Basisphenoid

    • 18-21 years

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 22-25 years: By the age of 22-25 years, the fusion of the basiocciput with the basisphenoid has usually already taken place.

Option C - 14-16 years: The fusion of the basiocciput with the basisphenoid occurs later than 14-16 years of age. At this stage, the cranial bones are still undergoing development and growth.

Option D - 12-14 years: The fusion of the basiocciput with the basisphenoid occurs later than 12-14 years of age. During early adolescence, the cranial bones are still in the process of development and have not yet fused completely.

questions.text: Edmond Locard is most famous for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Theory of exchange:

  • Locard is most famous for his theory of exchange, also known as Locard's Exchange Principle.
  • This principle states that whenever two objects come into contact, there will be an exchange of materials between them.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Study of fingerprints: While Edmond Locard did contribute to the field of forensic science, he is not primarily known for the study of fingerprints.

Option C - Stature estimation: Stature estimation involves determining a person's height based on skeletal remains.

Option D - Forensic ballistics: Forensic ballistics involves the analysis of firearms, ammunition, and the examination of ballistic evidence.

questions.text: What is the odor of the mummified body?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Odorless

  • Mummification is a process characterized by the rapid dehydration and desiccation of a dead body, resulting in the preservation of its natural appearances and features through evaporation of water. Here are the key points about mummification:

    • Definition: Rapid dehydration and desiccation of the body, preserving its natural appearance.

    • Modification of putrefaction: Mummification is a form of dry decomposition, distinct from the wet decomposition seen in putrefaction.

    • Physical changes: The entire body loses weight, becomes thin, stiff, and brittle. It also becomes odorless.

    • Prevention of decomposition: The process of normal decomposition, which involves the growth of microorganisms, is prevented or significantly retarded in mummification. This is due to the rapid dehydration and lack of moisture, which inhibits microbial growth.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pungent: This option is not correct. A pungent odor refers to a strong, sharp, and often unpleasant smell. It is not typically associated with a mummified body, as the process of mummification involves the preservation of the body and the prevention of decomposition.

Option C - Putrid: This option is not correct. The term "putrid" refers to a foul or rotten smell associated with decomposition. A mummified body does not have a putrid odor because the mummification process hinders decomposition.

Option D - Offensive: This option is not correct. An offensive odor refers to a strong, unpleasant, and offensive smell. Similar to the previous options, a mummified body does not have an offensive odor due to the preservation process that prevents decomposition.

questions.text: Which metallic poisoning Mimics cholera?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Arsenic:

Features of Arsenic Poisoning :

  • A - Aldrich-Mees line/Reynold's line (present over nails), Aphrodisiac (increase libido)

  • R - Red velvety mucosa, Raindrop pigmentation, Rashes (fading measles rash)

  • S - Subendocardial hemorrhage/Sheehan hemorrhage

  • E - Excess hyperpigmentation of palms and soles

  • N - Neuritis (sensory > motor)

  • I - Iron oxide antidote (hydrated ferric oxide)

  • C - Mimics cholera

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C & D do not mimic cholera.

questions.text: Which option provides the most accurate description of a posthumous child?

choices.text: Child is delivered after death of biological father
Child is born to an unmarried couple
Child is abandoned by the parents

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Child is delivered after death of biological father:

  • Child is delivered after the death of the biological father: This is the correct option.

  • A posthumous child refers to a child who is born after the death of their biological father.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Delivery of a macerated fetus: Maceration, refers to the softening and disintegration of fetal tissues due to prolonged retention in the uterus after fetal death.

Option C - Child is born to an unmarried couple: It is unrelated to the concept.

Option D - Child is abandoned by the parents: This is not the correct description of a posthumous child.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does the 40-year-old woman, who was involved in a car accident 2 months ago, experience when she wakes up screaming at night due to recurring nightmares of the same incident?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Post- traumatic stress disorder:

  • The lady's experience of waking up in the night after nightmares of the car accident suggests the presence of PTSD.
  • Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD): PTSD is a mental health condition that develops after experiencing or witnessing a traumatic event.
  • Symptoms of PTSD include intrusive thoughts, nightmares, flashbacks, avoidance of reminders of the event, emotional distress, and hyperarousal.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute stress reaction: Acute stress reaction refers to an immediate response to a traumatic event. It involves symptoms such as anxiety, dissociation, and emotional distress. However, these symptoms usually resolve within a short period, typically within a few days or weeks. In the given scenario, the symptoms have persisted for two months, suggesting a more chronic condition like PTSD.

Option B - Adjustment disorder: Adjustment disorder is a psychological reaction to a stressful life event, such as a major life change or trauma. It is characterized by emotional and behavioral symptoms that occur within three months of the stressful event. While the lady's symptoms may initially resemble adjustment disorder, the persistent and recurring nature of the nightmares and distress point more towards PTSD.

Option C - Mania: Mania is a symptom associated with bipolar disorder and is characterized by an elevated or irritable mood, increased energy, racing thoughts, and impulsive behavior. The symptoms described in the scenario, such as nightmares and distress related to the car accident, are not consistent with mania.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics provides stronger evidence in support of delirium?

choices.text: Occurs gradually over a period of time

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Fluctuating course:

  • Fluctuating course is a hallmark feature of delirium.
  • It refers to changes in the intensity and severity of symptoms, including attention, cognition, and consciousness, that can vary throughout the day.
  • Delirium is characterized by an altered state of consciousness that fluctuates, with periods of lucidity and confusion.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Occurs gradually over a period of time: Delirium typically has an acute onset, meaning it develops rapidly, often within hours or days, rather than occurring gradually over a period of time. This symptom is more consistent with a chronic cognitive disorder rather than delirium.

Option C - Preserved consciousness: Delirium is associated with an impaired level of consciousness. However, it is important to note that consciousness in delirium can vary, ranging from hyperactive (agitated and restless) to hypoactive (lethargic and withdrawn). While consciousness is impaired, it is not preserved, making this option incorrect.

Option D - Commonly associated with auditory hallucinations: Delirium is more commonly associated with perceptual disturbances, such as visual hallucinations or illusions.

questions.text: How can we describe the emotional release and discharge that occurs when a person consciously relieves a repressed painful experience?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Abreaction:

  • The correct option for the emotional release and discharge after consciously relieving a painful experience that has been repressed is "Abreaction."
  • Abreaction is a therapeutic process that involves the re-experiencing or reliving of traumatic events under hypnosis or in a deeply relaxed state. It aims to facilitate the release and processing of suppressed emotions, memories, and trauma-related distress.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Catharsis: Catharsis refers to the process of releasing or purging strong emotions, usually through an artistic or expressive outlet such as writing, painting, or engaging in physical activity. While catharsis involves emotional release, it does not specifically refer to reliving a repressed painful experience.

Option C - Venting out: "Venting out" generally refers to expressing one's thoughts, feelings, or frustrations openly and often in a cathartic manner. While it involves emotional release, it does not specifically refer to reliving a repressed painful experience.

Option D - Guided relaxation: Guided relaxation is a technique used to induce a state of deep relaxation and reduce stress or anxiety. It typically involves following verbal instructions or audio recordings that guide individuals through relaxation exercises. While it can be beneficial for emotional well-being, it does not specifically involve the conscious reliving of a repressed painful experience.

questions.text: According to the revision of DSM-5 by the American Psychiatric Association, what is the current term used to refer to 'mental retardation'?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Intellectual disability:

  • The correct option for what "mental retardation" is now called according to the American Psychiatric Association in its revision of DSM-5 is "Intellectual disability."

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Feeble-mindedness: Feeble-mindedness was a term used in the past to describe individuals with intellectual disabilities. However, this term is outdated and is no longer used in professional diagnostic criteria.

Option B - Mental subnormality: Mental subnormality is another outdated term that was previously used to describe individuals with intellectual disabilities. It is no longer used in current diagnostic criteria.

Option D - Intellectually challenged: This term is not used in professional diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: What is the purpose of utilizing the confusion assessment test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Delirium:

  • Delirium is an acute state of confusion and cognitive impairment that often occurs due to underlying medical conditions or medication side effects. The CAT is commonly used as a quick and reliable tool to assess for the presence of delirium. It helps identify cognitive deficits, attention disturbances, and other symptoms associated with delirium.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dementia- Dementia is a chronic cognitive disorder characterized by progressive decline in memory, thinking, and behavior. The CAT is not specifically designed to assess dementia. Instead, there are other specific assessment tools, such as the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE), that are commonly used to evaluate cognitive impairment in dementia.

Option B - Depression- Depression is a mood disorder characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, loss of interest, and changes in appetite, sleep, and concentration. The CAT is not primarily used for assessing depression. Diagnostic criteria for depression involve a comprehensive evaluation of mood symptoms, psychological and physical symptoms, and impairment in functioning.

Option D - Schizophrenia- Schizophrenia is a chronic mental disorder characterized by hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, and impaired social functioning. The CAT is not specifically designed to assess schizophrenia. The diagnosis of schizophrenia involves a comprehensive evaluation of symptoms, duration, and functional impairment.

questions.text: Which disorder was previously known as Minimal brain dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder:
