  • The disorder that was earlier known as "minimal brain dysfunction" is Attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dyslexia: Dyslexia refers to a specific learning disorder that primarily affects a person's ability to read, write, and spell. It is characterized by difficulties with accurate or fluent word recognition and poor spelling and decoding abilities. .

Option C - Mental subnormality: Mental subnormality is an outdated term that was previously used to describe what is now known as intellectual disability. Intellectual disability refers to significantly below-average intellectual functioning and limitations in adaptive behavior, which manifest during the developmental period.

Option D - Oligophrenia: Oligophrenia is another outdated term that was used to describe what is now known as intellectual disability. It refers to a condition characterized by significantly below-average intellectual functioning and limitations in adaptive behavior.

questions.text: For which of the following conditions is the squeeze technique utilized?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Premature ejaculation:

  • The Masters and Johnson's squeeze technique is indeed used for Premature ejaculation. It involves the application of pressure or squeezing on the head or base of the penis to delay ejaculation.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Retrograde ejaculation: Retrograde ejaculation is a condition in which semen flows backward into the bladder instead of being expelled through the penis during ejaculation. It can be caused by certain medical conditions, medications, or surgery. 

Option B - Erectile dysfunction: Erectile dysfunction (ED) refers to the inability to achieve or maintain an erection sufficient for sexual intercourse. It can have various causes, including physical, psychological, or a combination of both.

Option D - Painful ejaculation: Painful ejaculation, also known as dysorgasmia, refers to discomfort or pain during ejaculation. It can be caused by various factors, including infections, inflammation, structural abnormalities, or psychological factors. The approach to managing painful ejaculation involves identifying and addressing the underlying cause.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders may present with symptoms similar to Addison's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Depression:

  • Addison's disease, also known as adrenal insufficiency, can present with symptoms similar to depression.
  • Addison's disease occurs when the adrenal glands do not produce enough cortisol and sometimes aldosterone.
  • The symptoms of Addison's disease can include fatigue, loss of appetite, weight loss, low mood, and a lack of interest or pleasure in activities, which can overlap with depressive symptoms.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Generalized anxiety disorder: Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is a mental health condition characterized by excessive and persistent worry or anxiety about various aspects of life. While there may be some overlap in symptoms such as fatigue, difficulty concentrating, and irritability between Addison's disease and GAD, the core features and causes of the two conditions are distinct. Addison's disease primarily results from adrenal gland dysfunction, while GAD is a psychological disorder characterized by excessive and chronic worry.

Option C - Bipolar disorder: Bipolar disorder is a mood disorder characterized by alternating periods of depression and mania or hypomania. While there may be some overlap in symptoms such as fatigue, changes in appetite, and altered mood between Addison's disease and bipolar disorder, the underlying causes and nature of the conditions are different. Addison's disease results from adrenal gland dysfunction, whereas bipolar disorder involves disturbances in mood regulation.

Option D - Panic disorder: Panic disorder is a mental health condition characterized by recurrent and unexpected panic attacks, which are intense periods of fear and discomfort. While there may be some overlap in symptoms such as fatigue, dizziness, and feelings of unreality between Addison's disease and panic disorder, the core features and causes of the two conditions are distinct. Addison's disease primarily results from adrenal gland dysfunction, whereas panic disorder is characterized by recurrent panic attacks and associated anxiety symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is not classified as an obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) related ailment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Temper tantrums:

  • Temper tantrums are intense and often disruptive outbursts of anger or frustration, typically seen in children.
  • Temper tantrums are not considered an OCD-related disorder.
  • They are more associated with emotional regulation difficulties and are commonly seen in typically developing children as a part of their normal development.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hair pulling disorder (trichotillomania): Trichotillomania, also known as hair pulling disorder, is a disorder characterized by recurrent pulling out of one's hair, resulting in noticeable hair loss. It is considered an OCD-related disorder because it shares similarities with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) in terms of repetitive behaviors and urges.

Option C - Hoarding disorder: Hoarding disorder is a condition characterized by persistent difficulty in parting with or discarding possessions, regardless of their value. It involves excessive accumulation of items, leading to clutter and significant distress or impairment in daily functioning. Hoarding disorder is considered an OCD-related disorder because it shares similarities with OCD in terms of compulsive behaviors and difficulties with decision-making and organization.

Option D - Skin picking (excoriation disorder): Excoriation disorder, also known as skin picking disorder, is a disorder characterized by recurrent picking at one's own skin, resulting in skin lesions. It is considered an OCD-related disorder because it involves repetitive behaviors similar to those seen in OCD. Individuals with excoriation disorder may engage in skin picking to relieve tension, experience a sense of gratification, or attempt to improve the appearance of their skin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Alzheimer's disease?

choices.text: Neuritic plaques made of beta amyloid are found
Nucleus of Meynert is not affected

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nucleus of Meynert is not affected:

  • The nucleus of Meynert, also known as the basal nucleus of Meynert, is a group of neurons located in the basal forebrain that produces and releases the neurotransmitter acetylcholine.
  • In Alzheimer's disease, there is a significant degeneration of the nucleus of Meynert, which contributes to the cholinergic dysfunction observed in the disease.
  • The loss of cholinergic neurons and acetylcholine depletion is associated with cognitive impairments.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intracellular neurofibrillary tangles are seen: One of the pathological hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease is the presence of intracellular neurofibrillary tangles. These tangles are made up of abnormal tau protein that has accumulated inside neurons. Neurofibrillary tangles contribute to the disruption of neuronal function and eventual cell death.

Option B - Neuritic plaques made of beta-amyloid are found: Neuritic plaques, also known as senile plaques, are another characteristic feature of Alzheimer's disease. These plaques consist of aggregates of beta-amyloid protein that accumulate between neurons in the brain. The presence of neuritic plaques is associated with inflammation and neuronal damage.

Option D - Short-term memory is affected: Short-term memory impairment is a hallmark symptom of Alzheimer's disease. As the disease progresses, individuals may have difficulty retaining and recalling new information, experiencing deficits in short-term memory. This is often one of the initial cognitive symptoms noticed in Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms?

choices.text: Size more than 5.5 cm in males
Size more than 5 cm in females

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - All the above:

  • All of the above are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs).

Option A - Size more than 5.5 cm in males: This criterion is based on the risk of rupture. An AAA larger than 5.5 cm in diameter has a higher risk of rupture, and surgical intervention is recommended to prevent rupture and its potentially life-threatening consequences.

Option B - Size more than 5 cm in females: Although the threshold for surgical intervention is slightly lower in females compared to males, an AAA larger than 5 cm in diameter is still considered an indication for surgery in females. This is because females generally have a smaller aorta, and smaller aneurysms in women may carry a higher risk of rupture compared to men.

Option C - Expansion of > 0.5 cm within 6 months: Rapid expansion of an AAA indicates an increased risk of rupture. If the aneurysm grows more than 0.5 cm within a 6-month period, surgical intervention is recommended to prevent rupture.

questions.text: The following image shows the retrograde ureteropyelogram of a patient with loin pain. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hydronephrosis:

  • In the provided retrograde ureteropyelogram image, if there is evidence of dilatation or swelling of the renal pelvis and calyces, it indicates that there is an obstruction in the urinary tract leading to the accumulation of urine in the kidney. This finding is consistent with the diagnosis of hydronephrosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Duplex kidney: A duplex kidney refers to a congenital condition where an individual has two separate ureters draining a single kidney. This condition does not typically present with hydronephrosis as seen in the image.

Option C - Renal carcinoma: Renal carcinoma, or kidney cancer, is a malignant tumor that develops in the kidney. While renal carcinoma can cause obstruction and potentially lead to hydronephrosis, the retrograde ureteropyelogram image alone cannot provide a definitive diagnosis of renal carcinoma.

Option D - Renal stone: Renal stones, also known as kidney stones or renal calculi, are solid masses that form in the kidneys. While renal stones can cause obstruction and subsequent hydronephrosis, the retrograde ureteropyelogram image alone cannot confirm the presence of a renal stone.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is caused by the infection of protease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ammonium magnesium phosphate:

  • Ammonium magnesium phosphate is Caused by infection of protease.

  • Account for 15% of stones. Caused by infection with urease ⊕ bugs (eg, Proteus mirabilis, Staphylococcus saprophyticus, Klebsiella) that hydrolyze urea to ammonia → urine alkalinization.

  • Commonly form staghorn calculi.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Uric acid: Uric acid stones form due to high levels of uric acid in the urine. They are commonly associated with conditions such as gout or high purine intake in the diet. Uric acid stones are not specifically related to infection of protease.

Option C - Struvite: Struvite stones are composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate and are typically associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria. These bacteria convert urea into ammonia, which increases the urine pH and promotes the formation of struvite stones. They are not related to infection of protease.

Option D - Calcium oxalate: Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stones. They form due to an excessive amount of oxalate in the urine or reduced urine volume, leading to higher concentrations of oxalate. They are not related to infection of protease.

questions.text: What is the Glasgow Coma Score of a patient who is making Incomprehensible sounds, opens their eyes in response to painful stimuli and flexes one limb in response to painful stimuli.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: 8

  • Eye opening response: The patient opens his eyes in response to painful stimuli. This corresponds to a score of 2 on the GCS.
  • Best motor response which is scored as 4, as he can localise pain..
  • Verbal response: is 2 , as he is making Incomprehensible sounds
  • To calculate the GCS, we sum up the scores = 8

Incorrect Options

Option A: GCS of 9- This option is incorrect

Option B: GCS of 15- This option would be incorrect

Option C: GCS of 10- This option would also be incorrect

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless neck swelling. The histology of the tissue is as given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hashimoto’s Thyroiditis:

  • Based on the histology picture showing lymphocytic infiltration and follicular cell changes with a history of painless progression, the most likely diagnosis is Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • The hallmark of Hashimoto's thyroiditis includes Hurthle cells, characterized by abundant mitochondria giving a pink color, although they are not specific and can occur in other thyroid disorders.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Medullary Carcinoma:

  • Medullary carcinoma arises from the parafollicular or C cells of the thyroid gland, presenting with elevated calcitonin levels, diarrhea, amyloid stroma, and a familial link to pheochromocytoma or hyperparathyroidism, associated with MEN 2A and MEN 2B.

Option B - NHL:

  • While NHL can affect the thyroid gland, its histology typically shows malignant lymphoid cells infiltrating the tissue, unlike the image provided.

Option C - Graves Disease:

  • Graves disease involves hyperthyroidism, goiter, and thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) stimulating excess thyroid hormone production. Microscopically, it shows pseudopapillae resembling true papillae seen in papillary carcinoma, with fibrovascular cores and colloid scalloping indicating colloid consumption.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient who presented with scrotal swelling underwent an orchidectomy. The image below shows the histopathology findings. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Seminoma:

  • The image provided in the question is consistent with the histopathological appearance of a seminoma

  • Seminoma is a type of testicular germ cell tumor. It typically presents as a painless testicular mass or swelling.

  • Histologically, seminomas consist of uniform, undifferentiated germ cells with clear cytoplasm and prominent nuclei. 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Yolk-sac tumor: Yolk-sac tumor, also known as endodermal sinus tumor, is another type of testicular germ cell tumor. It primarily occurs in infants and young children. Histologically, yolk-sac tumors exhibit characteristic structures resembling primitive yolk sacs, such as Schiller-Duval bodies. The provided histopathology image does not show the features of a yolk-sac tumor.

Option C - Embryonal cell carcinoma: Embryonal cell carcinoma is another type of testicular germ cell tumor. It is composed of primitive, undifferentiated germ cells. Histologically, embryonal cell carcinomas often exhibit a mixture of different tissue types and can show features of glandular or tubular structures. The histopathology image provided does not demonstrate the characteristics of an embryonal cell carcinoma.

Option D - Teratoma: Teratoma is a type of testicular germ cell tumor that contains a variety of tissues derived from three embryonic germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm). Histologically, teratomas exhibit a diverse mixture of tissues, such as epithelial, mesenchymal, and neural elements. The provided histopathology image does not resemble the features of a teratoma.

questions.text: During the surgical procedure for an inguinal hernia in a child, the surgeon observes that the bowel is necrotic. Regarding the resection and anastomosis of the bowel, which statement is accurate?

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures
The surgeon must use the single-layer, extramucosal suture technique
The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The surgeon must use the single-layer, extramucosal suture technique:

  • The surgeon must use the single-layer, extramucosal suture technique for resection and anastomosis of the necrotic bowel.
  • This technique involves suturing only the outermost layers of the bowel (seromuscular layer) without including the inner mucosal layer.
  • By avoiding suturing the submucosa, the risk of leakage from compromised or ischemic mucosa is reduced.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The surgeon must use chromic catgut: Chromic catgut is a type of absorbable suture material.

Option B - The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures: The submucosa is typically not included in the sutures to minimize the risk of leakage and promote healing.

Option D - The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique: This statement is incorrect because the single-layer seromuscular suture technique does not specifically address the extramucosal aspect.

questions.text: A lady has a reddish, firm nodule on her chest that has not grown in size. The histopathological image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hemangioma:

  • Hemangiomas are benign tumors made up of blood vessels.
  • The histopathological image shows a lesion composed of numerous small blood vessels (capillaries), which is characteristic of a hemangioma.
  • The clinical description of a reddish, firm nodule that has not grown in size also supports this diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lipoma:

  • Lipomas are benign tumors composed of fat cells (adipocytes).
  • Histologically, they show mature adipose tissue with no significant vascular components.

Option B - Fibroadenoma:

  • Fibroadenomas are benign breast tumors composed of both glandular and stromal tissues.
  • Histologically, they display a mix of fibrous and glandular elements.

Option C - Nevus:

  • Nevi, or moles, are benign proliferations of melanocytes.
  • Histologically, they show nests of melanocytes in the epidermis and/or dermis.

questions.text: Which is the most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - E.coli:

  • Acute bacterial prostatitis is an infection of the prostate gland that is primarily caused by bacteria. E. coli (Escherichia coli) is the most frequently implicated organism in cases of acute bacterial prostatitis.

  • E. coli is a type of bacteria commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract, and it can enter the prostate gland through various routes, such as ascending infection from the urethra or reflux of infected urine into the prostatic ducts.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Enterococcus: Enterococcus species are Gram-positive bacteria that can cause urinary tract infections, including prostatitis. However, they are less commonly associated with acute bacterial prostatitis compared to E. coli. Enterococcus is more frequently implicated in infections such as urinary tract infections (UTIs), intra-abdominal infections, and infective endocarditis.

Option B - Proteus: Proteus species, particularly Proteus mirabilis, are known to cause urinary tract infections. While they can infect the prostate gland, they are not the most common organism associated with acute bacterial prostatitis. Proteus species are more commonly associated with complicated UTIs, particularly those involving urinary tract calculi or urinary catheterization.

Option C - Streptococcus Agalactiae: (Group B Streptococcus) Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), is a Gram-positive bacterium that can cause various infections, including urinary tract infections. However, it is not a common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis. GBS is more commonly associated with infections in pregnant women, newborns, and immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: ​​​​​​​In the OPD, a 35-year-old male presented with concerns of passing dark-colored stools. Following an endoscopy, the patient was diagnosed with an upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. Which anatomical structure serves as a distinguishing point to differentiate it from a lower GI bleed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ligament of Treitz:

  • The Ligament of Treitz, also known as the suspensory muscle of the duodenum, is a fibrous band located at the junction between the duodenum (the first part of the small intestine) and the jejunum (the second part of the small intestine).
  • This anatomical landmark serves as a useful reference point for distinguishing between upper and lower GI bleeding.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ampulla of Vater: The Ampulla of Vater is the site where the common bile duct and the pancreatic duct join and enter the duodenum.

Option C - Superior duodenal flexure: The superior duodenal flexure refers to the curved segment of the duodenum, where it transitions from the descending part to the horizontal part.

Option D - Ileocecal junction: The ileocecal junction is the point where the small intestine (ileum) connects to the large intestine (cecum).

questions.text: What is the most suitable graft for performing a femoropopliteal bypass procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Great saphenous vein:

  • The great saphenous vein, is considered the best graft for a femoropopliteal bypass due to its superior long-term patency rates and overall success in these procedures.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dacron: Dacron, a synthetic graft, is a secondary choice for femoropopliteal bypass due to lower patency rates compared to the great saphenous vein.

Option C - Polytetrafluoroethylene: Polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), another synthetic graft, has inferior long-term patency rates to the great saphenous vein for femoropopliteal bypass.

Option D - Short saphenous vein: The short saphenous vein is less favored than the great saphenous vein for femoropopliteal bypass due to its smaller diameter and inferior long-term outcomes.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Alcohol:

  • Alcohol is indeed the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis.

TIGARO Classification of Etiology:

  • T - Toxic - Metabolic
  • I - Idiopathic
  • G - Genetic
  • A - Autoimmune
  • R - Recurrent severe
  • O - Obstructive

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Gallstones: Gallstones can cause acute pancreatitis when they obstruct the pancreatic duct, leading to inflammation. However, while gallstones can contribute to recurrent acute pancreatitis, they are not the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis.

Option C - Autoimmune: Autoimmune pancreatitis is a relatively rare condition characterized by chronic inflammation of the pancreas due to an autoimmune reaction. It is an important cause of chronic pancreatitis, but it is less common than alcohol-induced pancreatitis.

Option D - Drugs: Certain medications, such as certain antiretroviral drugs used in HIV/AIDS treatment or certain immunosuppressive drugs used in organ transplant recipients, can rarely cause chronic pancreatitis. However, drug-induced pancreatitis accounts for a small percentage of cases and is not the most common cause.

questions.text: What is the name of the procedure in which a probe is inserted into the duct from which the discharge is emerging, followed by making a tennis racquet incision and dissecting the flap to reach the duct, and finally excising the duct?

choices.text: Wide excision of the lactiferous duct

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Microdochectomy:

  • It refers to the surgical removal of a single lactiferous duct or a small segment of the duct in the breast.
  • This procedure is typically performed when there is a persistent nipple discharge or abnormality in a specific duct in duct ectasia and duct papilloma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Macrodochectomy: Macrodochectomy refers to the surgical removal of a major lactiferous duct in the breast. It involves excising a larger duct within the breast tissue.

Option C - Cone excision: Cone excision, also known as conization or cone biopsy, is a procedure performed on the cervix to remove a cone-shaped portion of abnormal or precancerous tissue. It is not directly related to the treatment of nipple discharge or lactiferous ducts.

Option D - Wide excision of the lactiferous duct: Wide excision of the lactiferous duct is not a specific procedure or term used in breast surgery.

questions.text: What is a valid statement regarding chromic catgut?

choices.text: It is made from cat gut
It is made from rabbit gut
It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis
It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis:

  • Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture material that is absorbed by the body over time. It is treated with chromium salts to prolong its absorption rate.
  • Once implanted, the sutures undergo enzymatic degradation by the body's enzymes, such as proteases, and are subsequently phagocytosed (engulfed and broken down) by macrophages.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is made from catgut: Chromic catgut is not made from catgut. It is a type of absorbable suture material that was traditionally made from the intestines of sheep or other animals, not specifically cats.

Option B - It is made from rabbit gut: Chromic catgut is not made from rabbit gut. As mentioned earlier, catgut is typically sourced from the intestines of sheep or other animals, not rabbits.

Option D - It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue: The term "chromic" in chromic catgut refers to the use of chromium salts during the manufacturing process to delay the absorption of the suture material, not nickel salts.

questions.text: Please identify the instrument shown in the image provided:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Morris retractor:

  • The Morris retractor is the correct identification for the instrument shown in the image.
  • It is a self-retaining retractor commonly used in abdominal surgery.
  • The Morris retractor consists of multiple, adjustable blades that can be positioned and locked in place to hold back tissue and provide exposure during the surgical procedure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Daever's retractor: It is not the correct identification for the instrument in the image.

Option C - Czerney's retractor: Czerney's retractor is another type of abdominal retractor. Czerney's retractor typically consists of two curved blades with teeth or hooks at the ends that are used to hold back and retract tissue.

Option D - Double hook retractor: Double hook retractors are surgical instruments with two curved hooks at the end. They are used for tissue retraction and exposure during various surgical procedures. However, the instrument in the image is not a double hook retractor.

questions.text: Extra mammary Paget’s disease is commonly seen in the:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vulva: 

  • Extra mammary Paget's disease refers to the presence of Paget's disease of the skin occurring outside the mammary region.
  • It commonly affects the vulva, which is the external female genitalia.
  • Extra mammary Paget's disease of the vulva is a rare condition characterized by the presence of Paget cells in the skin of the vulva, causing symptoms such as itching, redness, and skin changes.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B , C & D: Extra mammary Paget's disease is not commonly seen in the vagina, uterus and cervix.

questions.text: What is the most effective technique for procuring tissue for the purpose of diagnosing pancreatic carcinoma?

choices.text: Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Transgastric FNAC guided by endoscopic ultrasound:

  • Transgastric fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) guided by endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is considered the best method to obtain tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma. E
  • US allows for precise visualization and targeting of the pancreatic lesion, while FNAC involves using a thin needle to extract cells for examination under a microscope.
  • This method is minimally invasive, has high diagnostic accuracy, and can provide valuable information for staging and treatment planning.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - MRI-guided biopsy: While MRI can provide detailed images of pancreatic tumors, it is not typically used for biopsy procedures. MRI-guided biopsies are not commonly performed for pancreatic carcinoma diagnosis.

Option C - Laparoscopic-guided biopsy: Laparoscopic-guided biopsies may be considered in some cases, but they are generally not the first-line approach for obtaining tissue for the diagnosis of pancreatic carcinoma. Laparoscopic procedures involve making small incisions and using a camera and surgical instruments to access and visualize the pancreas. However, transgastric FNAC guided by EUS is preferred over laparoscopic-guided biopsies due to its minimally invasive nature.

Option D - Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsy: Percutaneous transperitoneal biopsies involve inserting a needle through the abdominal wall to reach the pancreas and obtain tissue samples. While this method may be used in some cases, it is generally less preferred compared to transgastric FNAC guided by EUS, which provides better visualization and targeting of the pancreatic lesion.

questions.text: An abdominal mass in a patient with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is best seen_________:

choices.text: During palpation, over the left hypochondirum

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - During feeding:

  • An abdominal mass in a patient with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is best seen during feeding.
  • During feeding, the increased peristaltic activity and the passage of milk through the narrowed pylorus can cause the abdominal mass to become more prominent and easily palpable.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D - These options are incorrect.

questions.text: During the procedure of performing a fasciotomy to treat compartment syndrome, the incision is made through the following layers:

choices.text: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia
Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia, Deep fascia and a few muscular fibres

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia:

  • Fasciotomy is a surgical procedure performed to relieve this increased pressure by creating incisions in the affected compartment's fascial layers.

The layers incised during a fasciotomy for compartment syndrome are as follows:

  1. SkinSubcutaneous tissue: Superficial fascia: Also known as the subcutaneous fascia
  2. Deep fascia:

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Skin and Subcutaneous tissue:

  • It involves only incising the skin and subcutaneous tissue, which is inadequate for relieving pressure in compartment syndrome as it does not address the deep fascial layer.

Option B - Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia:

  • It involves incising the skin, subcutaneous tissue, and superficial fascia but omits the deep fascia, which is essential for proper decompression in compartment syndrome.

Option D - Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia, Deep fascia, and a few muscular fibers:

  • It includes incising skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, deep fascia, and some muscular fibers. While muscular fibers may be involved in the incision if necessary, it is not a standard practice. The primary focus is on incising the deep fascia to release compartment pressure.

questions.text: What is the accurate statement regarding Crohn's disease?

choices.text: For effective treatment of a Crohn’s mass, only antibiotics are prescribed
Symptomatic relapse after surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection
The proximal caecum is most commonly involved in Crohn’s disease
On endoscopic examination continuous lesions are visualised, which are diagnostic of Crohn’s disease

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Symptomatic relapse after surgery is not related to the presence of disease during resection:

  • Crohn's disease is known for its chronic and relapsing nature, and recurrence of symptoms can occur even in areas where surgical resection was performed.
  • This can happen due to the development of new areas of disease involvement or ongoing inflammation in other parts of the gastrointestinal tract.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - For effective treatment of a Crohn’s mass, only antibiotics are prescribed: The treatment of Crohn's disease is comprehensive and typically involves a combination of medications, including anti-inflammatory drugs, immunosuppressants, biologic agents, and sometimes surgical intervention. The specific treatment approach depends on the severity and location of the disease, as well as individual patient factors.

Option C - The proximal caecum is most commonly involved in Crohn’s disease: While Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from the mouth to the anus, the most common site of involvement is the terminal ileum, which is the distal portion of the small intestine. 

Option D - On endoscopic examination, continuous lesions are visualized, which are diagnostic of Crohn’s disease: Crohn's disease is characterized by a patchy pattern of inflammation rather than continuous lesions. The inflammation can appear as skip lesions, meaning that there are areas of healthy tissue in between affected areas.

questions.text: What is the earliest indication of Crohn's disease among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Aphthous ulcers:

  • Aphthous ulcers, also known as aphthous stomatitis, are shallow, round or oval ulcers.
  • They are considered one of the earliest signs of Crohn's disease and can precede the development of other intestinal symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cobblestone appearance: This is a common finding in Crohn's disease, it is not typically the earliest sign. It often develops as the disease progresses and affects a larger area of the gastrointestinal tract.

Option B - Deep fissured ulcers: Similar to the cobblestone appearance, they tend to develop as the disease progresses rather than being the earliest sign.

Option C - Rose-thorn appearance: The rose-thorn appearance is associated with Crohn's disease. It is not an early sign of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hormone receptor staining:

  • The Van Nuys grading system for DCIS does not consider hormone receptor staining as one of the parameters to assess the tumor.
  • Hormone receptor status, including estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) staining, is relevant in determining the treatment options for DCIS.

Scoring system for University of Southern California/Van Nuys Prognostic Index

Score 1 2 3
Size ≤15 mm 16–40 >40
Margin ≥10 mm 1–9 <1
Class Grade 1/2 without necrosis Grade 1/2 with necrosis Grade 3
Age >60 40–60 <40

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & D - These are included in the grading system.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true with regards to a keloid scar?

choices.text: The extant does not cross the wound margins
Wide excision of the keloid scar prevents recurrence
Histopathology of a keloid scar shows reduced collagen and increased vascularity
A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - A keloid scar forms due to increase in the level of growth factors:

  • Keloids result from an overactive healing response to an injury.

  • A keloid scar develops from heightened levels of growth factors, resulting in excessive tissue formation beyond the boundaries of the original wound, often leading to raised, thickened scar tissue.

Incorrect Options;

Option A - The extent of a keloid scar can cross the wound margins: Keloid scars are characterized by their tendency to extend beyond the original wound boundaries. Unlike normal scars, which typically stay within the limits of the wound, keloids can grow and spread beyond the initial injury site.

Option B - Wide excision of a keloid scar does not necessarily prevent recurrence: Keloid scars have a high recurrence rate even after surgical removal. While excision may temporarily remove the keloid, it does not guarantee that it won't reappear. Keloids have a complex and poorly understood formation process involving various factors, and surgical removal alone may not address all underlying causes.

Option C - Histopathology of a keloid scar does not typically show reduced collagen and increased vascularity: Keloid scars are characterized by excessive collagen deposition, leading to the formation of raised, firm, and thickened scars. The histopathological examination of keloids typically reveals an abundance of collagen fibers in irregular arrangements. Increased vascularity is not a consistent finding in keloids.

questions.text: Heller’s operation is done for _______:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Achalasia cardia:

  • Heller's operation, also known as Heller myotomy, is a surgical procedure performed to treat achalasia cardia.
  • Heller's operation involves cutting the muscles of the LES to relieve the obstruction and improve the movement of food through the esophagus.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Carcinoma esophagus: In cases of esophageal cancer, the treatment approach typically involves a combination of chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgical resection.

Option C - Esophageal stricture: The treatment of esophageal strictures usually involves nonsurgical methods such as dilation (stretching) of the stricture using an endoscope or the placement of stents to widen the narrowed area.

Option D - Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: The treatment for hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is surgical pyloromyotomy, which involves making a small incision in the pylorus to relieve the obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Barrett's esophagus is incorrect?

choices.text: It is the intestinal metaplasia of esophagus
Mucus secreting foveolar cells are characteristic
Alician blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimen
Adenocarcinoma of O-G junction is a complication

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Mucus-secreting foveolar cells are characteristic:

  • Barrett's esophagus is characterized by the presence of specialized columnar cells with goblet cells, not mucus-secreting foveolar cells.
  • Goblet cells are responsible for producing mucus, and their presence in the columnar epithelium is a hallmark of Barrett's esophagus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is the intestinal metaplasia of the esophagus: Barrett's esophagus refers to the condition where the normal squamous epithelium of the lower esophagus undergoes metaplastic changes and transforms into columnar epithelium with intestinal characteristics. This change is known as intestinal metaplasia.

Option C - Alcian blue is used in the staining of biopsy specimens: Alcian blue is a commonly used stain in histopathology to detect the presence of mucin-containing cells. In the case of Barrett's esophagus, Alcian blue staining can be used to identify the presence of goblet cells in the columnar epithelium during histological examination of biopsy specimens.

Option D - Adenocarcinoma of O-G junction is a complication: This statement is correct

questions.text: What is the calculation method for determining the modified shock index?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - HR/MAP:

  • The modified shock index is calculated by dividing the heart rate by the mean arterial pressure.
  • The mean arterial pressure is a measure of the average pressure within the arteries during one cardiac cycle and is a more reliable indicator of tissue perfusion compared to the systolic blood pressure alone.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - HR/SBP (Heart Rate/Systolic Blood Pressure): This is not the correct calculation for the modified shock index.

Option B - HR/DBP (Heart Rate/Diastolic Blood Pressure): This is not the correct calculation for the modified shock index.

Option D - PR/SBP (Pulse Rate/Systolic Blood Pressure): This is not the correct calculation for the modified shock index.

questions.text: How do the muscle relaxants in the curare group work?

choices.text: Competitively blocking the binding of ACH to its receptors
Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate
Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane

questions.solution:
Option B: Competitively blocking the binding of ACH to its receptors

  • Curare is a non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking agent that blocks neuromuscular transmission. This process allows the central nervous system to control muscle action at the neuromuscular junction.
  • It paralyzes muscles that bind directly to nicotinic receptors in the postsynaptic membrane, blocking acetylcholine binding and depolarizing the motor plate, thereby causing muscle paralysis. Hence, it competitively binds with the acetylcholine receptors. Hence, option B is the correct answer to the question given.

Option A:

  • It does not work by persistently depolarizing the neuromuscular junction,

Option C:

  • It does not work by repetitive stimulation of the acetylcholine receptors

Option D: 

  • It does not work by inhibiting the calcium channels.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is popularly used in clinical anesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ulnar Nerve:

  • To monitor a neuromuscular blockade, a supramaximal electrical stimulus is given to a peripheral nerve that can be accessed quickly, and the muscle response to the stimulus is noted.
  • One of the easily accessible nerves is the ulnar nerve, so it is preferred for monitoring it. Hence, option A is the correct answer to the question given.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Median Nerve:

  • It is not commonly used in clinical anesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade.

Option C - Radial Nerve:

  • It is not commonly used in clinical anesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade.

Option D - Mandibular Nerve:

  • It is not commonly used in clinical anesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade.

questions.text: Identify the Mallampati class of this patient
questions.solution:
Option A: Class II

  • In the diagram given in the question, there is a complete visualization of the soft palate but only the tip of the uvula is not seen. Hence, the type of Mallampatti classification seen is class II. Hence, option A is the correct answer for the question given.

 

Option B: In class I

  • Mallampatti classification, there is a complete visualization of the soft palate and uvula.

Option C: In class IV

  • The soft palate is not seen when we look at it.

Option D: In class III

  • There is a visualization of only the base of the uvula.

questions.text: Where can the devices in Murphy's eye be observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Endotracheal tube:

  • The Murphy's eye is a feature found in certain medical devices, particularly in endotracheal tubes (ETT) and tracheostomy tubes.
  • It consists of an additional opening or eyelet located on the side of the tube near the distal end, opposite to the main opening through which the tube is inserted into the airway.
  • The purpose of the Murphy's eye is to provide an alternative pathway for airflow in case the main opening becomes obstructed. This can happen due to factors such as mucosal swelling, secretions, or misplacement of the tube against the tracheal wall.
  • When the tube is correctly positioned in the airway, the Murphy's eye remains outside the tracheal wall. However, if the tube tip is pressed against the tracheal wall, the Murphy's eye allows air to flow into the lungs, preventing complete obstruction.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nasopharyngeal airway: The nasopharyngeal airway is used in conscious patients with a compromised airway. It is made of soft silicon and has a single opening.

Option B - Laryngoscope: The laryngoscope is an instrument used to view the larynx or voice box.

Option C - Bronchoscope: The bronchoscope is a tube-like instrument with a lens to check for abnormalities in the lungs and bronchioles.

questions.text: The following cells seen in the lymph node are indicative of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Measles:

  • The presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells with large grapelike clusters of inclusion bodies is suggestive of measles infection.
  • The Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are multinucleated cells that contain viral inclusion bodies and are commonly seen in measles infections.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not associated with the presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells.

questions.text: Which circuit is the most efficient for administering anesthesia while allowing for spontaneous breathing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Mapleson A

  • Anesthesia circuit links the anesthesia machine and the patient, which helps with breathing. The semi-closed circuit, the Mapleson circuit, is clinically used. There are six types of Mapleson circuits ranging from A to F.
  • In Mapleson A circuit, the inspiratory climb is shorter than the expiratory climb. When connected to a spontaneously ventilating patient, this circuit has to supply fresh air to the patient continuously; this is the patient's minute ventilation, and the expiratory gas will be able to go out. Hence, it is the ideal circuit for spontaneous breathing. Hence, option A is the best choice for this question.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: The Mapleson B this option is incorrect

Option C: The Mapleson C this option is incorrect

Option D: The Mapleson D circuit is the circuit of choice for controlled ventilation in adults.

questions.text: What is the most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Mediastinum

Explanation:

Extra-gonadal germ cell tumor:

  • The most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor is the mediastinum.
  • Extragonadal germ cell tumors can be benign or malignant.
  • Benign extragonadal germ cell tumors are called benign teratomas: These are more common than malignant extragonadal germ cell tumors and are often very large
  • Malignant extragonadal germ cell tumors are divided into two types:
    • Seminoma
    • Non-seminoma

questions.text: The best type of anesthesia for pre eclampsia is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Epidural anesthesia:

  • Epidural anesthesia is often considered the best choice for anesthesia in pre-eclampsia because because in preeclampsia there is risk of airway edema that can lead to difficult intubation, therefore continuous epidural anesthesia avoid that need of intubation

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Spinal anesthesia: Spinal anesthesia may cause a sudden drop in blood pressure, which can be problematic in pre-eclampsia where blood pressure control is important.

Option C - General anesthesia: it can be used in pre-eclampsia, it is not necessarily the best choice solely based on the risk of airway edema, but indicated in severe preeclampsia and coagulopathy.

Option D - Caudal block: This option is incorrect.

questions.text: If epinephrine fails to be effective, what other medication would you consider using for cardiac arrest?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Amiodarone:

  • Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication that is commonly used in the management of cardiac arrest. It is used when initial treatments, such as epinephrine, fail to restore a stable heart rhythm. Amiodarone works by stabilizing the electrical activity of the heart and is effective in treating various types of life-threatening arrhythmias.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vasopressin:

  • It has been used in the past as an alternative to epinephrine, current guidelines recommend epinephrine as the primary vasopressor in cardiac arrest. Amiodarone is the preferred alternative to epinephrine if it proves ineffective.

Option B - Atropine:

  • Atropine is a medication used to increase heart rate and treat certain types of bradycardia (slow heart rate). It is not typically effective in treating cardiac arrest, particularly in cases of ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia. Therefore, it is not the preferred alternative to epinephrine.

Option D - Adenosine:

  • Adenosine is primarily used in the treatment of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), which is a different type of arrhythmia compared to ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia seen in cardiac arrest. Adenosine works by briefly slowing down the heart rate and interrupting the re-entry pathway responsible for SVT. It is not indicated for use during cardiac arrest and is not an alternative to epinephrine in that context.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Aspartate and glutamate

  • Glutamate and aspartate are acidic amino acids that are responsible for negative charge in fibrinopeptide A .

Incorrect Options

Option A - In the case of glutamate and valine, though glutamate is acidic and negatively charged, valine is a nonpolar amino acid and is neutral in charge. So, this pair cannot be responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A.

Option B - In the case of histidine and lysine, both amino acids are basic and bear a positive charge. Also, they are not part of fibrinopeptide A, proving the b option incorrect.

Option D - In the case of serine and threonine, though serine is part one of the amino acids from which Fibrinopeptide A polypeptide is made, it’s neutral. And Fibrinopeptide A molecule does not contain threonine as its part, proving it an incorrect choice.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DNA polymerase I?

choices.text: It is involved in the creation of Okazaki fragments
It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - It is found in prokaryotes:

  • DNA polymerase I is found in prokaryotes.
  • It removes RNA primers from both leading and lagging DNA strands, leaving single or multiple gaps.
  • Its main function is DNA repair, resembling eukaryotic DNA polymerase β.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is involved in the creation of Okazaki fragments: DNA polymerase I is not involved in creating Okazaki fragments. It is involved in filling gaps between Okazaki fragments.

Option C - It synthesizes RNA primers: DNA polymerase I do not synthesize RNA primers.

Option D - It is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis: DNA polymerase I is not the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis. DNA polymerase III is the primary enzyme of DNA synthesis.

questions.text: Due to the lack of ________________, nude mice do not exhibit resistance to xenografts.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - T Cell:

  • T cells are another type of lymphocyte that are essential for cell-mediated immunity.
  • They play a central role in recognizing and eliminating foreign antigens.
  • Nude mice(lack body hair), which lack functional T cells due to absence of thymus, are unable to mount an effective cell-mediated immune response.
  • Therefore, the absence of T cells is the primary reason for the lack of resistance to xenografts in nude mice.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: What does Burkholderia cepacia exhibit resistance to among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cefotetan:

  • Burkholderia cepacia is known to exhibit intrinsic resistance to cefotetan.
  • This resistance is primarily attributed to the presence of various mechanisms, including efflux pumps, enzymatic degradation, and alterations in target sites.
  • Burkholderia cepacia is resistant to aminoglycosides, polymyxine, 1st and 2nd generation cephalosporins, and carboxypenicillins.
  • Burkholderia cepacia is susceptible to Ceftazidime, Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, Temocillin, doxycycline, meropenem, and piperacillin.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the causative agent for scombroid food poisoning among the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pseudomonas Aeruginosa:

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium that can cause various infections in humans.
  • Scombroid poisoning is caused by the consumption of fish.
  • Organisms responsible for causing Scombroid poisoning are Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella species, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • They are commensal in seafish and can break down histidine present in fish into histamine, which can cause food poisoning following seafood intake.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Salmonella: Salmonella is a group of bacteria that causes typhoid fever characterized by step ladder pattern fever, bradycardia, and pea soup diarrhea.

Option B- Staphylococcus: It causes food poisoning with the consumption of milk and meat products with an incubation period of 1 to 6 hours.

Option D- Peptostreptococcus: Peptostreptococcus is a genus of anaerobic bacteria that can be part of skin, mouth, intestine, and vagina. It is associated with puerperal sepsis and skin and soft tissue infection.

questions.text: During the period between 1 to 4 months following renal transplantation, which pathogen is most commonly responsible for infecting renal transplant recipients?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cytomegalovirus:

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV), is the predominant pathogen to infect renal (solid organ) transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following transplantation because of reactivation of the virus in immunocompromised individuals.
  • The immunosuppressive medications taken by transplant recipients increase their susceptibility to CMV infection, which can lead to significant morbidity and complications in the early post-transplant period.
  • It presents in various forms, such as:
    • Bilateral interstitial pneumonia, a life-threatening complication seen in 15–20% of bone marrow and solid organ transplant recipients
    • Febrile leukopenia is seen among solid organ transplant recipients.
    • Obliterative bronchiolitis in lung transplants.
    • Graft atherosclerosis in heart transplants.
    • Rejection of renal allografts.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. They are not the most common organism to cause infection in an organ transplant recipient between 1 to 4 months.

questions.text: For which condition is the Sabin-Feldman dye test utilized in diagnosing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Toxoplasmosis:

  • The Sabin-Feldman dye test is a gold standard test for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. It is a type of complement fixation test that detects the presence of specific antibodies, known as Toxoplasma-specific antibodies, in a person's blood.
  • It involves mixing the patient's serum with live tachyzoites from Toxoplasma gondii and then adding a dye (methylene blue). If antibodies are present, the tachyzoites will be colorless, and if antibodies are absent, the tachyzoites will show color. The presence of antibodies will activate the complement fixation and destroy the tachyzoites, and lead to distorted and colorless tachyzoites.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. The Sabin-Feldman dye test is specific and sensitive to toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: What is the term used to refer to the antigen known as Australia antigen among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HBsAg:

  • The Australia antigen, also known as the Australia antigen marker, is represented by the HBsAg.
  • The presence of HBsAg in the blood indicates an active Hepatitis B infection. It is an important marker used for screening and diagnosis of Hepatitis B.

Structural proteins of HBV

Description

P – DNA Polymerase
  • Largest
  • Reverse transcriptase
  • RNAse

C – Core gene
  • Has a core area and a pre-core area
  • Core area coats for C antigen
  • Pre-core area codes for E antigen

S – Surface Antigen (Australia Antigen)
  • These have different sizes (Small, medium and large)

X – HBX responsible for carcinogenesis
  • Liver (Hepatocellular carcinoma)

Incorrect Options:

Option B - HBeAg: HBeAg is another antigen produced by the Hepatitis B virus during active viral replication. Its presence indicates high viral replication and infectivity. HBeAg is used as a marker to assess the severity and prognosis of Hepatitis B infection.

Option C - HBcAg: Hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg) is an antigen that is located in the inner core of the Hepatitis B virus.

Option D- HBX: HBX is an oncoprotein responsible for hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes an allosteric modifier?

choices.text: This causes the enzyme to worker faster only

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Participates in feedback regulation

  • Allosteric modifiers are a group of regulatory compounds that bind reversibly and non-covalently to the allosteric site of an enzyme and can alter the affinity and efficacy of other substances acting on enzymes.
  • These allosteric modifiers are generally small metabolites or co-factors.
  • In addition to active sites, allosteric enzymes generally have one or more regulatory or allosteric sites for binding the modifiers.
  • Each modulator is specific to its regulatory site.
  • Thus, a feedback regulation occurs when a product of the reaction binds to an allosteric site of an enzyme and affects its catalytic activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Allosteric modifiers never desaturate the enzyme.

Option B - An increase in temperature causes the enzyme to work faster.

Option C - Allosteric modifiers do not bind to the catalytic site.

questions.text: Bacterial transduction occurs by

choices.text: Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bacteriophage:

  • Bacterial transduction occurs through the action of bacteriophages, which transfer bacterial genetic material from one bacterium to another.

Types of Bacteriophages

Virulent phage

Temperate phage
  • Dangerous
  • Follow only lytic cycle
  • Ex: T1 and T2 phage of E.coli
  • Less dangerous
  • Follow both lytic and lysogenic cycle
  • Ex: Lambda phage of E. coli

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Plasmids: Plasmids are circular, extrachromosomal DNA molecules that can be found in bacteria. While plasmids can carry genetic information and can be transferred between bacteria through a process called conjugation where plasmids are transferred between bacteria through direct physical contact.

Option B - Sex pilli: Sex pilli, or pili, are appendages found on the surface of certain bacteria that facilitate the transfer of genetic material during conjugation.

Option D - Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria: This refers to the gene transfer by transformation, a mechanism of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria, where bacteria can uptake free extracellular DNA from the environment and incorporate it into their own genome.

questions.text: What is the most frequently occurring end-product of the pathway for fatty acid synthesis among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Palmitic acid

  • The most common end-product of the fatty acid synthesis pathway is Palmitic acid.
  • Palmitic acid is a 16-carbon saturated fatty acid and serves as a central intermediate in fatty acid metabolism.
  • It is synthesized through a series of enzymatic reactions in the fatty acid synthesis pathway, starting from Acetyl CoA.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Arachidonic acid is a polyunsaturated omega-6 fatty acid stored within lipid bodies in immune cells and is involved in the arachidonic acid synthesis pathway.

Option B - Oleic acid is monounsaturated omega-9 fatty acid acting as an inhibitor in synthesis.

Option D - Acetyl-CoA acts as a precursor for the synthesis of fatty acids.

questions.text: In patients with diabetic ketoacidosis, which type of fungus is frequently linked to orbital cellulitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rhizopus:

  • Rhizopus is a genus of fungi, and the species most commonly associated with orbital cellulitis in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis is Rhizopus.
  • This fungal infection is known as rhinocerebral mucormycosis.
  • Rhizopus can invade the sinuses and orbit, leading to orbital cellulitis. This infection can spread rapidly and is considered a medical emergency.
  • Predisposing factors for mucormycosis: Iron is essential for mucormycosis growth. High iron levels increase the risk of invasive mucormycosis.
    • Diabetic ketoacidosis is the most important risk factor. Acidosis causes the release of iron from the sequestered proteins in the serum.
    • End-stage renal disease.
    • Patients taking iron therapy or deferoxamine (iron chelator)
    • Defects in phagocytic functions (e.g., neutropenia or steroid therapy).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Candida: Candida is a genus of yeast that can cause oral thrush, vulvovaginitis, esophagitis, endocarditis, and UTI in individuals with weakened immune systems (HIV)

Option C - Aspergillus: Aspergillus is a genus of filamentous fungi commonly found in the environment. It can cause invasive fungal infections in immunocompromised individuals, but it is more commonly associated with lung infections such as invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.

Option D - Trichophyton: Trichophyton is a genus of fungi that primarily causes infections of the skin, hair, and nails. It is not commonly associated with orbital cellulitis or invasive fungal infections in the orbit in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: In which of the following cases is the adult form of echinococcus observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dog:

  • The adult worm of Echinococcus lives in the jejunum and duodenum of dogs and other canine carnivora ( wolf and fox).
  • The larval stage (hydatid cyst) is found in humans and herbivorous animals like sheep, goats, cattle, and horses.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms can thrive in an acidic pH?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lactobacilli:

  • Most pathogenic bacteria grow best between pH 7.2 and pH 7.6, but there are some exceptions.
  • Lactobacilli can grow at acidic pH below pH 4. They are commonly found in various acidic environments, such as the vagina, gastrointestinal tract, and fermented foods like yogurt and sauerkraut.
  • Vibrio cholerae can grow at alkaline pH (8.2-8.9).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sandfly:

  • The given image is Leishman Donovan bodies, which are macrophages-laden amastigotes, which are ovoid or rounded cells, about 2-4 μm in size, suggesting typical Leishmaniasis.
  • The vector for the transmission of leishmaniasis is sandfly, particularly Phlebotomous argentipes and orientalis.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: TB test done only on whole blood sample is ______________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Interferon-gamma release assay:

  • Interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA) is a type of tuberculosis (TB) test that is performed on whole blood samples.
  • IGRA tests measure the release of interferon-gamma by T-cells in response to specific TB antigens (ESAT, 6TB 7.7, and CFP 10).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - TrueNat TB: TrueNat TB is a molecular diagnostic test for the detection of tuberculosis. It utilizes a cartridge-based platform to perform real-time PCR (polymerase chain reaction) to detect Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA in sputum samples. TrueNet TB is not specifically limited to whole blood samples, as it is primarily used for sputum-based testing.

Option B - GeneXpert: GeneXpert is a molecular diagnostic platform that uses real-time PCR technology to detect tuberculosis and resistance against rifampicin. The test is typically performed on sputum samples or other respiratory specimens rather than whole blood.

Option D - MGIT system: It is a molecular diagnostic platform that uses probe-based detection of amplified DNA in the specimen to detect tuberculosis and resistance 1st line and 2nd line antitubercular drugs. The test is typically performed on sputum samples or other respiratory specimens.

questions.text: Which statement regarding vitamin K is accurate?

choices.text: A deficiency of vitamin K leads to hypercoagulability
Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency
Menaquinone is the dietary source of vitamin K found in green vegetables.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency

  • Antibiotics used for the long term not just kills harmful bacteria but also kills the bacteria that make vitamin K.
  • Vitamin K is a group of vitamins required for blood clotting, mainly encompassing phylloquinone ( nutrition K1 ) and menaquinone ( nutrition K2 ). It is a fat-soluble vitamin. It's rare to have Vitamin K deficiency due to the presence of leafy vegetables and also being synthesized by the bacteria found in small intestines. Thus, sometimes due to consumption of antibiotics may kill the bacteria and lead to mild deficiency in people with low levels, to begin with.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Deficiency of vitamin K leads to vitamin K deficiency bleeding (VKDB).

Option B - Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin.

Option D - Menaquinone is the dietary source of vitamin K found in meat, dairy foods, and eggs.

questions.text: What causes the formation of multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses that show the presence of sulphur granules in the pus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Actinomyces Israelii:

  • Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses and the presence of sulfur granules in pus are characteristic features of actinomycosis caused by actinomyces israelii a commensal bacterium in the oral flora.
  • Actinomyces form aggregates called sulfur granules, which are composed of bacterial colonies surrounded by host tissue reaction. These granules are typically yellowish and contain tangled filamentous structures seen on microscopy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Nocardia: Nocardia can cause pulmonary infections in immunocompromised individuals and cutaneous lesions in immunocompetent individuals.

Option C - Salmonella: Salmonella bacteria are primarily associated with gastrointestinal infections, such as dysentery characterized by bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever.

Option D - Tularemia: Tularemia, also known as rabbit fever, is caused by the bacterium Francisella tularensis. It typically presents as a flu-like illness with symptoms such as fever, fatigue, and swollen lymph nodes.

questions.text: Vanillyl mandelic acid excreted in the urine in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pheochromocytoma:

  • Vanillylmandelic acid is a product of epinephrine and norepinephrine (belongs to the group of similar hormones called catecholamines) metabolism excreted in the urine and produced in the liver.
  • Pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-producing tumor, is a condition in which norepinephrine, epinephrine, and dopamine are released in abnormally high amounts.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Homogentisic acid is deficeint in the urine during alkaptonuria.

Option C - The compound called 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) is excreted in the urine in a condition called carcinoid syndrome.

Option D - Ketone is excreted in the urine during a condition known as diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: Identify the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Ancylostoma braziliense

  • The given organism is Ancylostoma braziliense
  • Cutaneous larva migrans, is caused by the larvae of Ancylostoma braziliense.
  • Ancylostoma braziliense is a hookworm that primarily infects dogs and cats.
  • The larvae of this parasite can penetrate the human skin, usually through direct contact with contaminated soil or sand.
  • Once in the skin, the larvae migrate and cause an inflammatory reaction, resulting in the characteristic serpiginous tracks seen in cutaneous larva migrans.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Strongyloides stercolaris: This option is incorrect

Option B- Toxocara canis: This option is incorrect

Option D- Necator americanus: This option is incorrect

questions.text: Serotonin is also known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 5 hydroxytryptamine

  • Serotonin is also known as 5 hydroxytryptamine. It is a monoamine neurotransmitter.

Incorrect Options - B, C, and D: These are incorrect

questions.text: What is absent in the urine of a patient who presents with recurrent kidney stones? Below in the microscopic eamination of the patient’s urine sample.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cysteine

  •  Cystinuria is an inherited AR disease
  • It is due to a defective amino acid transporter which is responsible for reabsorbing 4 amino acid along the PCT- Cystine, Ornithine, Lysine and Arginine.
  • The image shows cystine in the urine sample in hexagonal shape.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Urine sample contains arginine.

Option B - Given urine sample contains lysine.

Option C - Given urine sample contains cysteine.

questions.text: What type of hypersensitivity reaction is implicated in the hyperacute rejection of kidney transplants?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Type II:

  • Hyperacute rejection of renal transplants involves a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Type II hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by the binding of antibodies, typically IgM or IgG, to antigens on the surface of target cells or tissues.
  • In the case of hyperacute rejection, preformed antibodies in the recipient's blood react with antigens on the transplanted kidney, leading to immediate and severe destruction of the graft.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Type IV hypersensitivity reaction: Type IV hypersensitivity reactions, also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions, are cell-mediated immune responses involving T cells. They are characterized by a delayed onset of symptoms, typically 24-48 hours after exposure to the antigen. Type IV hypersensitivity reactions are not involved in hyperacute rejection, which occurs rapidly after transplantation.

Option B - Type III hypersensitivity reaction: Type III hypersensitivity reactions involve the formation of immune complexes composed of antigens and antibodies, leading to tissue damage when deposited in various organs. These reactions typically occur several hours to days after exposure to the antigen. Hyperacute rejection of renal transplants is not primarily mediated by immune complex deposition, making type III hypersensitivity reaction an incorrect option.

Option D - Type I hypersensitivity reaction: Type I hypersensitivity reactions, also known as immediate hypersensitivity or allergic reactions, involve the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators in response to an allergen. Type I hypersensitivity reactions are associated with conditions such as allergies, asthma, and anaphylaxis. They are not directly implicated in hyperacute rejection of renal transplants.

questions.text: In which condition is there an excessive excretion of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid in the urine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Carcinoid Syndrome

  • In Carcinoid syndrome, there is an excessive synthesis of serotonin or 5-Hydroxytryptamine. This serotonin, after metabolism, excretes 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid into the urine for excretion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - In Alkaptonuria, urine turns black on exposure to air by the incomplete breakdown of tyrosine and phenylalanine.

Option C - In Albinism, there is defective production of melanin.

Option D - The buildup of phenylalanine in urine is seen in Phenylketonuria.

questions.text: Which of the organisms listed below are capable of producing urease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Helicobacter pylori:

Urease Positive Organisms (Mnemonic Punch Kiss)

  • Proteus mirabilis
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • Nocardia
  • Cryptococcus neoformans
  • Helicobacter pylori
  • Staphylococcus Saprophyticus
  • Staphylococcus Epidermidis

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. They are not urease positive organisms.

questions.text: Which of the following should be avoided by a patient with fish odor syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Choline

  • Choline is recommended to be avoided by patients with fish odor syndrome.
  • In a normal individual, when choline is ingested, it is reduced to TMA by colonic bacteria. The TMA would diffuse passively across cell membranes and enter the enterohepatic circulation. Here, it is removed by the liver, which FMO3 or flavin monooxygenase 3 enzyme normally oxidizes TMA into odorless TMAO. This process of trimethylamine oxidation is defective or impaired in patients with trimethylaminuria.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Biotin does not trigger choline or trimethylamine metabolism. So it has no influence on fish odor syndrome.

Option C - Niacin does not trigger choline or trimethylamine metabolism. So the patient will not have aggravation of fish odor syndrome.

Option D - Pantothenic acid does not trigger choline or trimethylamine metabolism. So the patients with fish odor syndrome can include pantothenic acid in diet.

questions.text: Which antibiotics are Mycoplasma naturally resistant to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Beta-lactam Antibiotics:

  • Beta-lactam antibiotics: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.
  • This is because mycoplasmas lack a cell wall, which is the target of penicillins (like β-lactamase inhibitors) and cephalosporins.
  • The absence of a cell wall makes mycoplasmas naturally resistant to these types of antibiotics.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Macrolides: Mycoplasma is susceptible to macrolide antibiotics such as erythromycin, azithromycin, and clarithromycin. Macrolides are commonly used in the treatment of mycoplasma infections.

Option C - Tetracycline: Mycoplasma is susceptible to tetracycline antibiotics. Tetracyclines, including doxycycline and minocycline, are often effective in treating mycoplasma infections.

Option D - Fluoroquinolones: Mycoplasma is susceptible to fluoroquinolone antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin. Fluoroquinolones are commonly used in the treatment of mycoplasma infections.

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Protein folding

Chaperones assist other proteins in folding properly during and after synthesis. Folding of over half of mammalian proteins is done by chaperones which can be divided into two types:

  • The hsp70 (70-kDa heat shock protein) family of chaperones mainly binds short sequences of hydrophobic amino acids to shield them from solvents in newly synthesized polypeptides. These are produced in response to stress conditions.
  • Chaperonins are another type of chaperone that form large protein complexes that provide a protective environment for the folding of the newly synthesized protein.

Chaperones provide an opportunity to form appropriate secondary structural elements and their subsequent coalescence into a molten globule, thus preventing aggregation.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Ubiquitination of proteins happens through ubiquitin-activated enzymes.

Option B: Non-enzymatic pathways result in protein modification.

Option D: Proteases assist in protein cleavage.

questions.text: Pasteurization is done at .....................
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 63 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes:

  • Pasteurization is done to kill or inactivate harmful microorganisms, such as bacteria, viruses, and parasites while preserving the flavor and nutritional value of the product.
  • Methods of pasteurization:
    • Holder Method: 63° C for 30 minutes.
    • Flash Method: 72° C for 20 seconds. The Flash method is better as it kills Coxiella burnetii (Q fever)
    • Ultra-high-temperature method: 149° C for 1-2 secs

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: Defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme is associated with___
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Type 1 Tyrosinemia

  • Tyrosinemia Type 1 is the most common type of tyrosinemia. It occurs when there is fumarylacetoacetatehydrolase deficiency.
  • It resultsin jaundice, hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, HCC, and liver cirrhosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Type 2 tyrosinemia occurs when there is tyrosine transaminase deficiency.

Option C - Type 3 tyrosinemia(neonatal tyrosinemia) occurs when there is PHPP hydroxylase deficiency and is the rarest of all the types.

Option D - Type 4 tyrosinemia is not known.

questions.text: A newborn baby refuses breast milk since the 2nd day of birth but accepts glucose water. He develops vomiting and severe jaundice by the 5th day. Benedict’s test was positive for urine, and blood glucose was low. The most likely cause is due to the deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

  • The question presented is a case of galactosemia. This occurs due to the deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.
  • Due to the deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, there is an excess accumulation of Galactose-1-Phoshate in the liver and brain that causes jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and mental retardation. Galactosemia is seen mainly in the first week of birth with the symptoms of jaundice.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aldose reductase: Deficiency of aldose reductase is not associated with the symptoms described in the question, such as refusal of breast milk, vomiting, severe jaundice, positive Benedict's test for urine, and low blood glucose levels.

Option B - Galactokinase: Galactokinase deficiency typically presents with symptoms like the presence of galactose in the blood and urine, cataracts, and sometimes intellectual disability.

Option D - UDP galactose-4-epimerase: UDP galactose-4-epimerase deficiency typically presents with symptoms similar to classic galactosemia, including failure to thrive, hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), jaundice, and developmental delay.

questions.text: What would be the recommended treatment for simple myopic astigmatism among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: -1.00 DC × 180 degree
