  • Simple myopic astigmatism is a type of refractive error where there is nearsightedness (myopia) combined with astigmatism. The prescription format for astigmatism includes a spherical component (DS) and a cylindrical component (DC) with a specific axis (in degrees). In this case, -1.00 DC × 180 degrees indicates that there is 1.00 diopter of astigmatism in the minus cylinder form along the 180-degree axis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: +1.00 DS-  A positive value in the spherical component (+DS) indicates hyperopia (farsightedness), which is not suitable for simple myopic astigmatism.

Option C: -1.00 DS- While it addresses myopia (nearsightedness), it does not account for the presence of astigmatism. Simple myopic astigmatism requires correction for both nearsightedness and astigmatism.

Option D: -1.00 DS - 1.00 × 180 degrees- The addition of "-1.00" in front of the cylinder component suggests a double correction, which is unnecessary in simple myopic astigmatism. The correct format should include a single cylindrical component.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with hypertriglyceridemia is considered for niacin therapy. She is a known diabetic managed adequately with sugars well under control. Why should niacin be used cautiously in this patient?

choices.text: It can cause scleroderma, which makes injecting insulin difficult
It can increase the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic drugs

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It can cause hyperglycemia

  • It can cause hyperglycemia: This option is correct. Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, can cause an increase in blood glucose levels.
  • It has been shown to impair glucose tolerance and increase insulin resistance, which can lead to elevated blood sugar levels. Therefore, niacin should be used cautiously in patients with diabetes to avoid worsening of glycemic control.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - It can cause scleroderma, which makes injecting insulin difficult: This option is incorrect. Niacin is not known to cause scleroderma, which is a chronic connective tissue disorder characterized by thickening and hardening of the skin.

Option C - It can increase the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic drugs: This option is incorrect. Niacin primarily affects glucose metabolism and insulin resistance.

Option D - It can cause hypoglycemia: This option is incorrect. Niacin is not known to cause hypoglycemia. On the contrary, it is more likely to cause hyperglycemia, as mentioned in the correct option.

questions.text: Which microorganism is responsible for angular conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Moraxella lacunata:

  • Angular conjunctivitis, also known as angular blepharitis or angular keratoconjunctivitis, is commonly caused by the bacterium Moraxella lacunata.
  • It is characterized by inflammation and infection of the canthi(angles) of the eyes, resulting in redness, discharge, and crusting.
  • Other pathogens causing angular conjunctivitis are:
    • Moraxella axenfeld (most common).
    • Moraxella catarrhalis.
    • Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These organisms do not cause angular conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms can modify gene expression through methylation and acetylation without altering the gene sequence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Epigenetics:

  • Epigenetics means a DNA change but not the DNA code or sequence. It can alter gene expression by methylation and acetylation (chemical DNA modification). The changes are reversible and can be transmitted to the next generation. It can lead to gene activation or gene inhibition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mutation is of many types and the DNA sequence changes in mutation. In point mutation, only one base is changed. Transition, Transversion, silent mutation, missense mutation, and non-sense mutation are all point mutations.

Option B - Translocation occurs when genetic material is exchanged between two different chromosomes.

Option D - Inversion is the alteration in the position of genes within the same chromosome.

questions.text: In developed countries, what is the primary etiology responsible for ophthalmia neonatorum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chlamydia:

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum worldwide..
  • Ophthalmia neonatorum refers to conjunctivitis that occurs in newborn babies within the first month of life.
  • Chlamydial ophthalmia neonatorum is typically acquired during delivery when the baby comes into contact with the infected birth canal.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gonorrhoea: Neisseria gonorrhoeae can manifest with severe symptoms of ophthalmia neonatorum, but is less common than chlamydia.

Option C - Chemical conjunctivitis: Chemical conjunctivitis refers to conjunctival inflammation caused by exposure to irritants or chemicals which are given as a prophylaxis for conjunctivitis.

Option D - Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause various types of infections, including conjunctivitis, but it is not the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum.

questions.text: The flipped LDH ratio implies____
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - LDH 1 > LDH 2

  • In normal people LDH 2 > LDH1 but in those with myocardial infarction, LDH 1 is greater than LDH 2.
  • This is known as a flipped ratio because the ratio of LDH 2 and LDH 1 are reversed in these patients compared to the normal patients.

Incorrect Options - B, C, and D: These are incorrect

questions.text: What is the underlying factor responsible for the development of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Enterovirus 70: Viral causes of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis are:

  • Enterovirus - 70
  • Adenovirus
  • Coxsackie - 24
  • Echovirus - 34

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D do not cause hemorrhagic conjunctivitis

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is 100-day glaucoma observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Central retinal vein occlusion:

  • "100-day glaucoma," also known as neovascular glaucoma, can occur as a complication of ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).
  • Ischaemic CRVO (hemorrhagic retinopathy) refers to acute (sudden) complete occlusion of the central retinal vein.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. 100 days glaucoma is not associated with these diseases.

questions.text: Yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus in dextroversion is _________________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Left medial rectus:

  • Yoke muscles (contralateral synergist) are pairs of muscles, one in each eye, that produce conjugate ocular movements.
  • In dextroversion, the muscle involved for the right eye movement is the right lateral rectus muscle and the contralateral synergist in the left eye is medial rectus muscle..

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Left medial rectus muscle is the yoke muscle of right lateral rectus in dextroversion.

questions.text: A patient, 36 hours after cataract surgery, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?

choices.text: Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Intravitreal antibiotics:

  • Given image of eye shows inflammation, congestion, corneal edema and hypopyon after 36 hours of undergoing cataract surgery is suggestive of acute onset endophthalmitis
  • Treatment of acute onset endophthalmitis will depend upon whether the patient is able to perceive the hand movement or doesn't have hand movement.
    • In the case of only perception of light and no hand movement, Pars Plana Vitrectomy (PPV) helps to quickly reduce the incidence of vision loss by 50%.
    • When there is hand movement and above, the treatment of choice would be intravitreal antibiotic injections (ceftazidime (gram -ve) and vancomycin (gram +ve)).
    • Systemic antibiotics, mainly Quinolones, are preferred. Topical steroids and cycloplegics are used in the case of uveitis.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: In a case of long-standing, uncontrolled diabetes, what is the most common characteristic of third nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ptosis:

  • Neurogenic ptosis it is the most common feature of third nerve palsy in cases of long-standing, uncontrolled diabetes.
  • Ocular manifestation seen in third nerve palsy are:
    • A - Profound ptosis due to weakness of the levator muscle.
    • B - Abduction and depression in the primary position due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
    • C - Normal abduction as the lateral rectus is intact
    • D - Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness.
    • E - Limited elevation due to weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
    • F - Limited depression due to weakness of the inferior rectus.
    • G - Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the most common site of an orbital blowout fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Floor:

  • The blowout fracture most frequently involves the floor of the orbit along the thin bone covering the infraorbital canal.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. These walls of the orbit are not commonly involved in the blowout fracture.

questions.text: A patient presented with tabes dorsalis. What will be observed when his pupils are exposed to light?

choices.text: Pupils react but do not accommodate
Pupils accommodate but do not react

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pupils accommodate but do not react:

  • Tabes dorsalis is a slowly progressive parenchymatous degenerative disease of the dorsal column and dorsal root of the spinal cord is seen in neurosyphilis caused by Treponema pallidum.
  • The ophthalmic feature seen in neurosyphilis is the Argyll Robertson pupil, characterized by a positive accommodative reflex and absent light reflex.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: Roth spots are seen in ____________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute leukemia:

  • Roth spots are retinal findings characterized by round or oval-shaped retinal hemorrhages with a pale or white center. The whitish element is thought to be composed of coagulated fibrin in most cases.
  • Conditions associated with roth spots are:
    • Acute leukemia.
    • Bacteremia (subacute endocarditis, endogenous endophthalmitis).
    • Diabetes.
    • Hypertension.
    • Anemia.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: What should be the power of prescription glasses for a 50-year-old man who is presbyopic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: +2D

  • In presbyopia, the near focusing ability of the eye diminishes, requiring additional positive or converging power to be added to the eye's optical system for clear near vision.
  • It happens around the age of 40 years for an emmetropic person, less than 40 years in hypermetropic patients, and more than 40 years for myopic patients.
  • At 40 years, around +1 D spherical lens is used to correct it. With every year that passes, around 0.5 D increases happen.
  • So, +2D is the most appropriate power of prescription glasses for a 50-year-old man with presbyopia.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: De Quervain's tenosynovitis involves the tendons of which muscles ?

choices.text: Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus:

  • De Quervain's disease: Inflammation of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis longus: This option is incorrect 

Option B - Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: This option is incorrect 

Option C - Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis brevis: This option is incorrect

questions.text: As the intern on duty, your responsibility includes attending to patients involved in a road traffic accident. Identify the patient from the options below for whom you would promptly contact the orthopaedic resident on call.

choices.text: Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of less than 3 seconds in his fingers
Patient with a fractured arm with intact skin and minimal swelling.
Patient with a fractured arm with capillary refill time of 5 seconds in his fingers

questions.solution:
• Capillary refill time (CRT) > 2 seconds indicates delayed perfusion and possible vascular injury or compartment syndrome.

  • CRT of 5 seconds is a red flag suggesting limb ischemia, which requires urgent orthopaedic and possibly vascular intervention.

Orthopedic Emergency Assessment in Trauma

Parameter Critical Concern
Capillary refill time > 2 seconds = vascular compromise
Limb color and temperature Pallor/coldness = poor perfusion
Pulse examination Absent/diminished distal pulses = arterial injury
Skin status Open wounds = open fracture → risk of infection
Pain disproportionate to injury Suspect compartment syndrome
Neurological status Paresthesia, motor weakness = possible nerve injury
Swelling or tense compartments Consider fasciotomy if compartment pressure is high

 

Orthopedic Emergencies in Trauma

Category Examples Urgency
Open fractures Bone exposed or wound >1 cm over fracture site Emergency ortho consult
Vascular compromise Absent pulses, CRT >2 sec, cold limb Emergency ortho + vascular
Compartment syndrome Pain out of proportion, paresthesia, pallor, pulselessness, paralysis Fasciotomy indicated
Joint dislocations Shoulder, knee, hip dislocations Urgent (but not always emergency)
Spinal trauma Neurological deficits, high-impact injury Immobilize + MRI/CT
Pelvic fractures Risk of hemorrhagic shock Emergency trauma care

Recurrent shoulder dislocation (Option A):
Chronic issue; not a priority unless there are neurovascular signs.

Capillary refill < 3 seconds (Option B):
Indicates adequate distal perfusion. No urgent ortho consult needed.

Fractured arm with intact skin and minimal swelling (Option C):
Stable closed fracture without signs of vascular compromise; managed routinely.

questions.text: Identify the condition represented in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Miliary tuberculosis:

  • The image showing a lung specimen represents miliary tuberculosis.
  • Miliary tuberculosis is a form of tuberculosis characterized by the widespread dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis throughout the body.
  • In this condition, the bacteria spread through the bloodstream and affect multiple organs, including the lungs.
  • The term "miliary" refers to the appearance of small millet seed-like lesions, which can be seen on imaging or in pathological specimens, giving the characteristic appearance seen in the image.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D do not present with the widespread millet seed-like lesions seen in the image.

questions.text: Which of the following recommendations was NOT made by the Chadha committee?

choices.text: One basic health worker per 10,000 population
Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: One PHC for 50,000 population

  •  The Chadha Committee, which was primarily focused on the National Malaria Eradication Programme, did not specifically recommend one PHC for every 50,000 population. Instead, its recommendations were more focused on integrating malaria eradication activities into general health services, particularly at the PHC level. The exact recommended ratio of PHCs to population was not mentioned in the committee's report.

Incorrect Options

Option A: PHC at block level

  • The Chadha Committee did recommend the establishment of PHCs at the block level. This recommendation was aimed at decentralizing healthcare and improving access to primary health services across different regions.

Option C: One basic health worker per 10,000 population

  • The Chadha Committee suggested having one basic health worker per 10,000 population to ensure that there were enough healthcare providers available at the grassroots level to carry out primary healthcare services effectively.

Option D: Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication

  • The Chadha Committee emphasized the role of PHCs in the National Malaria Eradication Programme, assigning them responsibilities in the detection, treatment, and prevention of malaria. This integration was part of the broader strategy to utilize existing healthcare infrastructure for disease control programs.

questions.text: A 10-day-old newborn presents with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, diffuse petechiae, and periventricular calcifications. Which of the following will be the best sample for diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Urine examination:

  • The patient’s presentation with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, diffuse petechiae, and periventricular calcifications is suggestive of congenital CMV infection.
  • The best sample for diagnosis of the congenital CMV infection is PCR / viral culture of urine sample.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following options is not linked to Sprengel deformity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Dextrocardia:

  • (Not associated) Dextrocardia refers to a condition in which the heart is situated on the right side of the chest instead of the left. While dextrocardia is a distinct condition, it is not typically associated with Sprengel deformity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diastematomyelia: (Associated) Diastematomyelia refers to a condition in which the spinal cord is split into two parts (bifid) by a bony or fibrous spur. Diastematomyelia has been reported in association with Sprengel deformity, suggesting a potential link between the two conditions.

Option B - Klippel-Feil syndrome: (Associated) Klippel-Feil syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by the fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae in the neck. It is commonly associated with Sprengel deformity, among other skeletal anomalies

Option D - Congenital scoliosis: (Associated) Congenital scoliosis is a spinal deformity that is present at birth and results from abnormal vertebral development. It has been reported in association with Sprengel deformity, suggesting a potential relationship between the two conditions.

questions.text: Which one of the subsequent options pertains to a stomach tumor present with acanthosis nigricans?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Gastric adenocarcinoma:

  • Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor that presents with acanthosis nigricans.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C do not present with acanthosis nigricans.

questions.text: Identify the given fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Colles Fracture

  • The given image is of Colles Fracture.
  • The Colles fracture is defined as a distal radius fracture with dorsal comminution, dorsal angulation, dorsal displacement, radial shortening, and an associated ulnar styloid fracture.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Monteggia Fracture- The Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the proximal ulna associated with dislocation of the radial head.

Option C: Galeazzi Fracture - 
A Galeazzi fracture is a fracture of the middle to distal third of the radius associated with dislocation or subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint

Option D: None of the above- This option is incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect in relation to the provided image?

choices.text: It is associated with facial angiofibroma
They are diagnostic of a neurocutaneous syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It is associated with facial angiofibroma:

  • The given image shows discrete nodules over the iris which are Lisch nodules seen in neurofibromatosis 1.
  • It is not associated with facial angiofibroma.
  • Facial angiofibromas, also known as adenoma sebaceum, are skin lesions characterized by red papules or nodules that commonly occur in the central face, particularly the cheeks and nose.
  • Facial angiofibromas are associated with tuberous sclerosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It represents melanocytic hamartoma: Lisch nodules are the melanocytic hamartomas found in adults with NF1 and are the most consistent features of NF1.

Option B - It causes no visual disturbance: Lisch nodules, although present in the eye, do not typically cause visual disturbance.

Option D - They are diagnostic of a neurocutaneous syndrome: Lisch nodules found in adults with NF1 and are the most consistent features of NF1.

questions.text: In the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure, which of the following centres is the furthest from the core?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Designated Microscopy Centre

 

Explanation:

  • Under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP) organization structure in India, the Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC) is considered the most peripheral center.
  • The DMC is responsible for performing sputum smear microscopy, which is a crucial diagnostic test for tuberculosis (TB).
    • It is usually located at the primary healthcare level, such as a Primary Health Centre (PHC) or a sub-district level health facility.

 

Under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP) in India, the distribution of centers is as follows:

  • Sub-Centre: The sub-centre is the first point of contact for healthcare services at the village level.
  • Designated Microscopy Centre (DMC): The DMC is located at the primary healthcare level, such as a Primary Health Centre (PHC) or a sub-district level health facility.
  • Primary Health Centre (PHC): The PHC is a higher-level primary healthcare facility that serves as a referral center for sub-centres.
  • Community Health Centre (CHC): The CHC is a secondary level healthcare facility that serves as a referral center for PHCs.
  • District TB Centre (DTC): The DTC is responsible for overseeing and coordinating TB control activities at the district level. (Option A)
  • Intermediate Reference Laboratory (IRL): The IRL is typically located at the state or regional level. (Option B)

 

Tuberculosis Unit (Option C): The Tuberculosis Unit refers to a health unit or department that is responsible for the diagnosis, treatment, and management of TB patients.

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of congenital adrenal hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Female pseudohermaphroditism:

  • In congenital adrenal hyperplasia, female pseudohermaphroditism occurs when there is prenatal exposure to excess androgens due to the enzyme deficiency.
  • It leads to virilization of the external female genitalia, causing them to appear more masculine.

Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are not seen in congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a road traffic accident 2 years back, and has developed pain and swelling now at the same site. His X-ray image is shown in the image given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chronic Osteomyelitis:

  • Chronic osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone that persists for an extended period, typically more than six weeks. The infection leads to inflammation, bone destruction, and the formation of dead bone fragments called sequestrum.
  • The X-ray image showing sequestrum and involucrum supports the diagnosis of chronic osteomyelitis. In chronic osteomyelitis, sequestrum refers to the dead bone fragments or necrotic tissue that can be seen as areas of radiolucency on the X-ray. Involucrum, on the other hand, refers to new bone formation surrounding the sequestrum, which appears as a dense, irregularly shaped area on the X-ray.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteogenic Sarcoma: Osteogenic sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that arises from bone-forming cells ,the X-ray findings of sequestrum and involucrum are not typical for osteosarcoma.

Option B - Ewing's Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is malignant bone tumor that often affects children and young adults. It typically presents with a characteristic onion-skin appearance on imaging. The X-ray findings of sequestrum and involucrum are not consistent with Ewing's sarcoma.

Option D - Multiple Myeloma: Multiple myeloma is a malignancy of plasma cells that primarily affects the bone marrow. the X-ray findings of sequestrum and involucrum are not typically associated with multiple myeloma.

questions.text: What is the maximum duration for TRALI to occur after a blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct option C: 6 hours:

  • Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a potentially severe complication that can occur after a blood transfusion.
  • It is characterized by the sudden onset of respiratory distress and non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema.
  • TRALI typically manifests within 6 hours after a blood transfusion.

Incorrect options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the statements below is correct regarding the Factories Act?

choices.text: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories
A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM
The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week
A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Children under 14 years of age must not be employed in factories- This statement is true and in line with the provisions of the Factories Act. The Act prohibits the employment of children below the age of 14 in any factory.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: A child of 16 years can be employed only between 6 AM and 8 PM-  The Act states that they should not be allowed to work between 7 PM and 6 AM.

Option C: The maximum working hours for an adult is 72 hours per week- As per the Act, an adult worker should not be required to work more than 48 hours in a week.

Option D: A child of 16 years can work till 5 hours per day- The Factories Act limits working hours for children aged 15 to 18 to a maximum of 4.5 hours per day and 9 hours in any continuous period, including breaks.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with a past medical record of discomfort in the musculoskeletal system. Which of the subsequent options indicates that the pain is not related to the joints?

choices.text: Pain in both movement and at rest

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Painless on passive movement:

  • When pain is absent during passive movement, it suggests that the pain is non-articular.
  • Passive movement refers to movement of a joint that is performed by another person or with the assistance of an external force, rather than through voluntary muscle contraction.
  • If the pain is non-articular, it is likely originating from structures outside the joint, such as muscles, tendons, ligaments, or nerves.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Swelling: Swelling is typically associated with joint involvement and is commonly seen in articular or joint-related conditions. In articular pain, such as arthritis, the joint may become inflamed, leading to swelling. Therefore, the presence of swelling suggests that the pain may be articular rather than non-articular.

Option B - Pain in both movement and at rest: Pain experienced during both movement and at rest does not provide a definitive indication of whether the pain is articular or non-articular. This symptom alone does not differentiate between the two types of pain.

Option D - Presence of crepitation: Crepitation refers to a crackling or grating sensation or sound that may occur during joint movement. It is commonly associated with articular conditions such as osteoarthritis or joint degeneration. Therefore, the presence of crepitation.

questions.text: What is the characteristic sign of a simple bone cyst?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fallen Fragment Sign:

  • The fallen fragment sign refers to a radiographic finding seen in simple bone cysts. It appears as a detached and fallen fragment of bone within the cystic cavity. This sign is considered pathognomonic, meaning it is unique to simple bone cysts and strongly indicative of their presence.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Scalloping of Cortex:

  • Scalloping of the cortex can be observed in various bone lesions, including tumors and cysts. It refers to a concave deformity or erosion of the bone cortex adjacent to the lesion. While scalloping can be seen in simple bone cysts, it is not pathognomonic and can also occur in other conditions.

Option C - Never Breaches Physis: 

  • The physis, or growth plate, is a cartilaginous region at the ends of long bones responsible for bone growth. Simple bone cysts can extend across the physis, breaching its boundaries and causing disruption. Therefore, the statement that simple bone cysts never breach the physis is incorrect.

Option D- Central Radiolucent Lesion: 

  • While simple bone cysts typically appear as central radiolucent lesions on imaging studies, this finding is not specific to simple bone cysts alone. Other bone lesions, such as aneurysmal bone cysts or giant cell tumors, can also present as central radiolucent lesions. Thus, it is not a pathognomonic sign for simple bone cysts.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a newborn who has a patch of hair on the lower back region?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Spina bifida occulta:

  • A tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region in a newborn is a clinical sign that is most commonly associated with spina bifida occulta

Incorrect Options:

Options B and C do not present with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region.

Option D - Congenital dermal sinus: It can sometimes occur in the lumbosacral region, the presence of a tuft of hair alone is not a specific sign of this condition.

questions.text: As per the recommended dietary allowance, what is the prescribed dosage of iodine for lactating women in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: 280 μg/day- The recommended dose of iodine for lactating women in India, according to the recommended dietary allowance, is 280 μg/day.

  • Iodine is an essential mineral required for the synthesis of thyroid hormones. During pregnancy and lactation, the iodine requirement increases to support the growth and development of the fetus and the production of breast milk.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 200 μg/day- This dosage is lower than the recommended dietary allowance for lactating women in India.

Option B: 220 μg/day- This dosage is also lower than the recommended dietary allowance for lactating women in India.

Option C: 250 μg/day- This dosage is still lower than the recommended dietary allowance for lactating women in India.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about perilunate dislocation?

choices.text: Lunate is dislocated anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remains in position
Lunate remains in position but rest other dislocate dorsally
Tavernier's manoeuvre is used for closed reduction

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lunate is dislocated anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remains in position:

  • Perilunate dislocation involves the disruption of the normal alignment between the carpal bones in the wrist. In perilunate dislocation, the lunate bone remains in its anatomical position, while the other carpal bones, including the scaphoid, triquetrum, and other adjacent bones, dislocate dorsally Therefore, the statement that the lunate is dislocated anteriorly while the rest of the carpals remain in position is incorrect.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lunate remains in position but rest other dislocate dorsally - In perilunate dislocation, the lunate bone remains in its anatomical position, while the other carpal bones, including the scaphoid, triquetrum, and other adjacent bones, dislocate dorsally. This displacement can result from high-energy trauma or significant wrist hyperextension.

Option C - Involves median nerve injury- Perilunate dislocation can cause compression or injury to the median nerve. The median nerve runs through the carpal tunnel, which can be affected by the dislocation and subsequent displacement of the carpal bones. Median nerve injury can lead to symptoms such as numbness, tingling, or weakness in the hand and fingers.

Option D - Tavernier's manoeuvre is used for closed reduction- Tavernier's maneuver, or closed reduction, is a technique used to reposition the dislocated carpal bones in perilunate dislocation. It involves applying traction and manipulation to guide the displaced carpal bones back into their proper alignment. This maneuver is commonly employed to reduce the dislocation before further stabilization or surgical intervention.

questions.text: In newborns, what is the primary cause of ventriculomegaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Aqueductal stenosis

  • Ventriculomegaly refers to the dilation or enlargement of the cerebral ventricles, which are fluid-filled spaces within the brain. It is a common finding in newborns and can be caused by various underlying conditions. Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns.
  • Aqueductal stenosis is a condition characterized by a narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, a narrow passage that connects the third and fourth ventricles in the brain. When this passage is narrowed or blocked, the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is obstructed, leading to the accumulation of fluid in the ventricles and resulting in ventriculomegaly.

Incorrect Choices

Option A: Arnold-Chiari malformation- Arnold-Chiari malformation refers to a group of structural defects in the brain and spinal cord. It involves a downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the opening at the base of the skull. While it can be associated with hydrocephalus, it is not the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns.

Option B: Dandy-Walker syndrome- Dandy-Walker syndrome is a congenital brain malformation characterized by the enlargement of the fourth ventricle and the presence of a cystic structure in the posterior fossa. While it can cause hydrocephalus, it is not the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns.

Option C: Arachnoid Villi malformation- Arachnoid villi are structures that help drain cerebrospinal fluid from the brain into the bloodstream. Malformation or dysfunction of these structures can lead to impaired CSF drainage and hydrocephalus. However, it is not the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns.

questions.text: When do you consider administering epinephrine to a neonate during resuscitation?

choices.text: Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations
Heart rate remains at < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations
Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask ventilation
Infants with severe respiratory depression fail respond to positive-pressure ventilation via bag and mask

questions.solution:
Correct option A: Heart rate remains at < 60 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations:

  • During neonatal resuscitation, epinephrine is considered when the heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute despite effective compressions and ventilations.
  • In neonatal resuscitation, the primary goal is to establish effective ventilation and oxygenation.
  • However, if the heart rate does not improve despite adequate ventilation and chest compressions, the administration of epinephrine may be necessary.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Heart rate remains at < 100 beats/minute despite effective compressions and ventilations: In neonatal resuscitation, a heart rate below 100 beats per minute is still considered within the acceptable range for a newborn and may not require immediate administration of epinephrine.

Option C: Heart rate does not improve after 30 seconds with bag and mask ventilation:

  • This statement suggests a lack of response to initial ventilation efforts.
  • In this case, it is important to reassess and optimize the ventilation technique, such as by checking the airway, repositioning the mask, or adjusting the ventilation parameters.

Option D: Infants with severe respiratory depression fail respond to positive-pressure ventilation via bag and mask:

  • Severe respiratory depression may indicate a need for intervention, but it does not necessarily indicate the immediate administration of epinephrine.
  • In such a case, efforts should be focused on improving ventilation and oxygenation before considering the use of additional medications.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes non-parametric tests?

choices.text: ANOVA is an example of a non-parametric test
It is used for skewed distributions
It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution
It cannot be used for small sample sizes

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: It is used for skewed distributions- Non-parametric tests are commonly used for skewed distributions. Unlike parametric tests, which make assumptions about the underlying distribution of the data (such as a normal distribution), non-parametric tests do not rely on these assumptions. Instead, they are designed to analyze data that may not meet the requirements of parametric tests, such as when the data is not normally distributed or when the data is ordinal or categorical.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: ANOVA is an example of a non-parametric test-  ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is an example of a parametric test, not a non-parametric test.

Option C: It involves the assumption that the data has a normal distribution- non-parametric tests do not assume that the data has a normal distribution. In fact, they are specifically used when the data does not meet the assumption of normality.

Option D: It cannot be used for small sample sizes: It is incorrect because non-parametric tests can be used with small sample sizes.

questions.text: Prolonged bleeding time is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Von Willebrand Disease:

  • Prolonged bleeding time is seen in Von Willebrand disease.
  • Von Willebrand disease is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (VWF), a protein involved in platelet adhesion and blood clotting.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D: Prolonged bleeding time is not seen.

questions.text: Identify the carpal bone that is most commonly fractured after fall on an outstretched hand.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A:

  • Scaphoid: The scaphoid bone is located on the radial side of the wrist, near the base of the thumb. It is susceptible to fractures when a person falls on an outstretched hand because of its position and the forces transmitted through the wrist during such an impact. Scaphoid fractures are common and can cause pain, tenderness, swelling, and limited wrist motion. It is important to diagnose and treat scaphoid fractures promptly, as they have a higher risk of complications such as nonunion (failure of the bone to heal) or avascular necrosis (loss of blood supply to the bone).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pisiform: The pisiform bone is a small bone located on the ulnar side of the wrist, anterior to the triquetrum bone. While fractures of the pisiform bone can occur, they are less common than scaphoid fractures after a fall on an outstretched hand.

Option C - Lunate: The lunate bone is located in the center of the proximal row of carpal bones. Although it can be involved in wrist injuries, fractures of the lunate bone are less common than scaphoid fractures in cases of a fall on an outstretched hand.

Option D - Hamate: The hamate bone is located on the ulnar side of the wrist, distal to the pisiform bone. While fractures of the hamate bone can occur, they are less common than scaphoid fractures after a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ataxia telangiectasia is false?

choices.text: Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Follows autosomal dominant mode of inheritance:

  • Ataxia telangiectasia is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Mutations in 11q gene is implicated: Ataxia telangiectasia is caused by mutations in the ATM gene located on chromosome 11q.

Option C: Humoral and cellular immunodeficiency: Ataxia telangiectasia is associated with both humoral (antibody-mediated) and cellular (T-cell-mediated) immunodeficiency.

Option D: Linked to adenocarcinomas: Individuals with ataxia telangiectasia have an increased risk of developing certain types of cancer, including lymphomas, leukemia, and certain solid tumors such as breast and gastric adenocarcinomas.

questions.text: Which specific article in the Indian constitution grants the Right to Life to the residents of India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option-B: Article 21-  Article 21 of the Indian Constitution confers the Right to Life to the citizens of India.

  • Article 21 states that "No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to the procedure established by law." This article is considered one of the fundamental rights guaranteed to every citizen of India. It ensures the protection of an individual's life and personal liberty from any unlawful or arbitrary deprivation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Article 11- Article 11 of the Indian Constitution does not confer any specific right. It relates to the power of the Parliament to regulate the rights of citizenship.

Option C: Article 23- Article 23 prohibits human trafficking and forced labor, but it does not directly confer the Right to Life.

Option D: Article 25- Article 25 guarantees the freedom of religion and the right to practice and propagate religion. It does not specifically confer the Right to Life.

questions.text: For hypertrophic non-union following a fracture, the most appropriate treatment
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Stabilization

  • Hypertrophic non-union refers to a type of non-healing fracture where there is excessive callus formation at the fracture site, but the bone ends fail to unite. In this case, the most appropriate treatment is stabilization, which involves providing mechanical support and immobilization to the fractured bone. Stabilization can be achieved using various methods such as external fixation, internal fixation with plates and screws, or intramedullary nails. Stabilization promotes bone healing by reducing motion at the fracture site, allowing for the formation of a more stable environment that encourages bone union.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Bone grafting- While bone grafting can be a useful treatment option for certain types of non-union, it is not the first-line treatment for hypertrophic non-union. Hypertrophic non-union typically involves adequate callus formation, indicating that there is potential for bone healing. Therefore, stabilization alone is often sufficient to promote bone union in hypertrophic non-union cases, without the need for additional bone grafting.

Option C: Stabilization and bone grafting- In hypertrophic non-union, where there is excessive callus formation, stabilization alone is usually effective in promoting bone healing. The addition of bone grafting may not be necessary in this situation, as the existing callus provides a favorable environment for bone union. Therefore, stabilization and bone grafting are not typically combined as the primary treatment for hypertrophic non-union.

Option D: None of the above- The correct answer is not "None of the above" because stabilization is indeed an appropriate treatment option for hypertrophic non-union. While bone grafting may be indicated in certain types of non-union, it is not the most appropriate treatment for hypertrophic non-union.

questions.text: Warthin-Finkeldey cells are seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rubeola:

  • Warthin-Finkeldey cells are multinucleated giant cells that are characteristic of measles (rubeola) infection.
  • These cells are formed by the fusion of infected lymphocytes and are found in the respiratory epithelium and lymphoid tissues during the acute phase of measles.

Incorrect Options:

Warthin-Finkeldey cells are not seen in Options A, C, and D.

questions.text: What immunization coverage percentage is required by the WHO for the eradication of measles?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- 96%: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), a minimum of 96% immunization coverage is needed for the eradication of measles.

  • Measles is a highly contagious viral disease that can spread rapidly among unvaccinated populations. Achieving a high level of immunization coverage is crucial to control and eliminate measles. The 96% immunization coverage target is set to ensure that a significant proportion of the population is protected against the measles virus, creating herd immunity.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A- 68%: This percentage is too low to achieve herd immunity and effectively control the spread of measles.

Option B- 72%: Similar to option A, this percentage is insufficient to achieve the desired level of immunization coverage for measles eradication.

Option C- 84%: While this percentage is higher than the previous options, it still falls short of the recommended 96% coverage needed for measles eradication.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent conditions is characteristic of an X-linked disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Color blindness:

  • Color blindness is a X-linked disorder.
  • It is caused by mutations in the genes responsible for the production of photopigments in the cone cells of the retina.
  • These mutations lead to a deficiency or absence of the photopigments, resulting in an inability to distinguish certain colors, particularly shades of red and green.

Incorrect Options - Options B, C, and D are autosomal recessive disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters in Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) indicates an unfavorable prognosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Age > 10 years:

  • Children older than 10 years of age have a higher risk of relapse and poorer outcomes.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Leukocyte count < 50,000/mm3:

  • A lower leukocyte count is associated with a more favorable prognosis in ALL.
  • High leukocyte counts at diagnosis indicate a higher tumor burden and are considered a poor prognostic factor.

Option C: Hyperdiploidy: Hyperdiploidy, which refers to the presence of more than the normal number of chromosomes in leukemic cells, is associated with a favorable prognosis in pediatric ALL.

Option D: Trisomy of chromosomes 4, 10, and 17: Trisomies involving chromosomes 4, 10, and 17 are often observed in pediatric ALL and are associated with a more favorable prognosis.

questions.text: The predominant organ producing insulin-like growth factor I is
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Liver

  • The liver is the predominant organ producing insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I).
  • IGF-I is synthesized primarily in the liver in response to growth hormone (GH) stimulation.
  • It plays a crucial role in growth and development, as well as in the regulation of various metabolic processes.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Pituitary gland- The pituitary gland does not produce significant amounts of insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I). Instead, the pituitary gland produces and releases growth hormone (GH), which stimulates the liver to produce IGF-I.

Option C: Pancreas- While the pancreas is responsible for producing and secreting insulin, which plays a role in regulating blood sugar levels, it is not the primary organ producing insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I). IGF-I is mainly synthesized in the liver.

Option D: Adrenal glands- The adrenal glands are involved in the production and secretion of various hormones, including cortisol and adrenaline, but they do not play a significant role in the production of insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I).

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the findings of a well-designed cancer study that obtained similar remission rates of 33.2% for both a new treatment and the usual treatment, with a p-value of 0.04?

choices.text: Both the treatments are equally effective
Neither of the treatments is effective
The new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment
The information given is not adequate to compare the efficacy of the treatments

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The new treatment is more effective than the usual treatment.

  • A p-value of 0.04 suggests a 4% chance of obtaining observed results, or more extreme results, if the null hypothesis is true. With a significance level of 0.05, results are statistically significant if the p-value is less than this threshold. Since 0.04 is below 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis, concluding the new treatment is more effective. While similar remission rates could be chance, statistical analysis indicates this difference isn't solely due to randomness..

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Both the treatments are equally effective: The p-value of 0.04 signifies a significant difference between treatments, suggesting they aren't equally effective.

Option B - Neither of the treatments is effective:The study didn't assess treatment effectiveness but compared remission rates between them. Since both treatments had identical remission rates, we can't conclude their ineffectiveness from this data..

Option D - The information given is not adequate to compare the efficacy of the treatments: The p-value of 0.04 indicates a statistically significant difference in remission rates between treatments, implying a meaningful efficacy difference.

questions.text: What is the single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Allograft Arteriopathy:

  • The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is allograft arteriopathy, also known as cardiac allograft vasculopathy (CAV).
  • Allograft arteriopathy refers to the progressive narrowing and occlusion of the coronary arteries of the transplanted heart.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the viral infection that can lead to temporary aplastic anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Parvovirus B-19

  • Parvovirus B-19 is known to cause a transient aplastic crisis, which is a temporary suppression of red blood cell production in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders, such as sickle cell disease or hereditary spherocytosis.
  • Parvovirus B-19 infects erythroid precursor cells in the bone marrow, leading to their destruction and subsequent reduction in red blood cell production.

Incorrect Options - A, B, and D do not cause temporary aplastic anemia.

questions.text: What is Prosopagnosia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Difficulty in identifying known faces:

  • Prosopagnosia, also known as face blindness, is a neurological disorder characterized by the inability or difficulty to recognize and identify familiar faces, including those of friends, family members, and even one's own face.
  • It is caused due to lesion in the inferior temporal lobe.
  • People with prosopagnosia may have normal vision and intellectual abilities but struggle specifically with facial recognition.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What are the accurate characteristics of ovotesticular disorders of sex development?

choices.text: Ovotesticular disorder of sex development can be identified in the gonadal biopsy
The response of testosterone to hCG is increased.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ovotesticular disorder of sex development can be identified in the gonadal biopsy:

  • Ovotestis, which contains both ovarian and testicular tissue, can be identified in the gonadal biopsy of individuals with ovotesticular disorders of sex development.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: The karyotype is 46 XY: Ovotesticular disorders of sex development can have various karyotypes, including 46 XX, 46 XY, or mosaic patterns.

Option C: The response of testosterone to hCG is increased: The response of testosterone to human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) stimulation is typically decreased in individuals with ovotesticular disorders of sex development.

Option D: Uterus is usually absent: While the presence or absence of a uterus can vary in ovotesticular disorders of sex development, it is possible for individuals with this condition to have a uterus.

questions.text: Which chromosome is involved in myotonic dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chromosome 19:

  • Myotonic dystrophy is caused by an expansion of CTG trinucleotide repeats in the DMPK gene, which is located on chromosome 19.
  • This genetic mutation leads to the production of an abnormal form of the myotonic dystrophy protein kinase (DMPK) and results in the characteristic symptoms of myotonic dystrophy.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following components is not responsible for the countercurrent multiplier mechanism in the kidney?

choices.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb
Water outflow in thin descending limb
Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb
Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT:

  • This component is not involved in the countercurrent multiplier mechanism of the kidney.
  • The countercurrent multiplier involves the following:
    • The high medullary tonicity is maintained by the following:
      • Sodium and chloride outflow in thick ascending limb.
      • Sodium and chloride outflow in the thin ascending limb.
      • Reabsorption of urea from medullary collecting duct into the interstitium.
    • This outflow of solutes into the medullary interstitium will result in hypertonicity which will result in the outflow of the water from isotonic fluid flowing through the thin descending limb of the loop of the henle.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the criteria for diagnosing neurofibromatosis 1?

choices.text: Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Acoustic neuromas:

  • Acoustic neuromas (also called vestibular schwannomas) are not specific to NF1 and are more commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).
  • Diagnostic criteria for neurofibromatosis - 1: Presence of 2 or more of the following:
    • Freckling of the axillary or inguinal areas
    • Lisch nodules, 2 or more involving the eyes
    • Optic glioma (most common tumor seen in NF-1)
    • First-degree relative affected with same disorder
    • Presence of 2 or more neurofibromas
    • Presence of 6 or more Caif au lait spots - Significant if the size is >5 mm in prepubertal age and >15 mm in Adolescence
    • A distinctive osseous lesion, such as sphenoid dysplasia or thinning of long bone cortex, also known as dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What is the appropriate treatment for a 9-month-old infant experiencing diarrhea, who is consuming food adequately and displaying signs of thirst, with skin returning to normal within 2 seconds after being pinched?

choices.text: 200-400 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
700-900 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
In addition to the usual fluid intake, 100-200 ml should be given after each loose stool.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours:

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) provides guidelines for the management of diarrhea, including the recommended amount of ORS to be administered:
  • In the case of a child who is consuming food adequately, displaying signs of thirst, and showing normal skin turgor (skin returns to normal within 2 seconds after being pinched), the recommended amount of ORS to be given in the first four hours is 400-700 ml.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 200-400 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours: This may not be sufficient for rehydration in this particular case.

Option C - 700-900 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours: This may be excessive for a child with normal skin turgor and signs of thirst, and it could lead to overhydration.

Option D - In addition to the usual fluid intake, 100-200 ml should be given after each loose stool: While additional fluid intake after each loose stool is important to prevent dehydration, this option does not specify the total amount of ORS to be given in the first four hours.

questions.text: Cowden syndrome is associated with mutations in:
questions.solution:
Correct option A: PTEN:

  • Cowden syndrome is associated with a mutation in the PTEN gene.
  • PTEN is a tumor suppressor gene that regulates cell growth and division.
  • Mutations in the PTEN gene can lead to the development of Cowden syndrome, which is an inherited condition characterized by multiple benign and malignant tumors, particularly in the breast, thyroid, and other organs.

Incorrect options: Cowden syndrome is not associated with mutations in options B, C, and D.

questions.text: Glucose is absorbed in the intestine by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Secondary active transport

  • Glucose is primarily absorbed in the intestine through SGLT 1, which transports the 2 molecules of Na+ with the gradient and 1 molecule of glucose against the gradient in the enterocyte, which is a secondary active transport.
  • It is dependent on Na+ K+ ATPase for the removal of excess Na+ from the enterocyte into the interstitial space when a large amount of glucose is absorbed from the cell for accommodation of the newer molecules.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text:
What BMI value is generally considered extremely low and associated with a higher risk of severe health complications in men?

a. BMI < 10 b. BMI < 15 c. d.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is:

Option A. BMI < 15

Explanation:

BMI (Body Mass Index) is a numerical value calculated based on an individual's weight and height. A BMI below 15 is considered extremely low and is associated with a significantly increased risk of severe health complications. This level of underweight can indicate malnutrition and a host of potential health problems, including:

  1. Weakened immune system: Malnutrition can lead to a compromised immune system, making the individual more susceptible to infections and diseases.

  2. Organ damage: Extremely low BMI can result in damage to vital organs, including the heart, liver, and kidneys, which can lead to organ failure.

  3. Nutritional deficiencies: Severely low BMI is often indicative of severe nutritional deficiencies, including deficiencies in essential vitamins and minerals.

  4. Muscle wasting: It can result in muscle wasting and overall weakness, affecting mobility and daily functioning.

  5. Increased risk of mortality: Extremely low BMI is associated with a significantly higher risk of mortality, especially if it is sustained over time.

It's important to note that the specific threshold for severe health risk can vary depending on an individual's unique circumstances, such as age, underlying health conditions, and muscle mass. However, a BMI below 15 is generally considered a critical indicator of extreme underweight and associated health risks. It is important for individuals with such low BMIs to seek medical attention and nutritional support to address these health concerns.

Options B, C, and D represent BMI values that are not considered extremely low, and they do not typically pose the same level of health risk associated with a BMI below 15.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of agranulocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Drug toxicity:

  • The most common cause of agranulocytosis is drug toxicity.
  • Agranulocytosis refers to a severe decrease in the number of granulocytes in the blood.
  • Various medications, such as certain antibiotics (e.g., penicillin, sulfonamides), antithyroid drugs (e.g., propylthiouracil, methimazole), anticonvulsants (e.g., carbamazepine), and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), can cause agranulocytosis as a rare adverse reaction.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are not the most common cause of agranulocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not employed in evaluating body fat?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Breslow index

  • The Breslow index, also known as the Breslow thickness, is not used to assess body fat. Instead, it is a measurement used in the staging of melanoma, a type of skin cancer. The Breslow index quantifies the thickness of melanoma tumor cells within the skin, providing information about the cancer's severity and prognosis. It is unrelated to body fat assessment.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Quetelet's index- Also known as Body Mass Index (BMI), Quetelet's index is commonly used to assess body fatness in relation to weight and height. It is calculated by dividing a person's weight in kilograms by the square of their height in meters. BMI provides a general estimation of body fat levels and is widely used in population studies and clinical settings.

Option B: Total body potassium- Although not directly used to measure body fat, total body potassium measurement can indirectly provide an estimate of lean body mass. Since potassium is primarily found within cells, the total body potassium content can be used as an indicator of the body's muscle mass. By subtracting lean body mass from total body weight, body fat mass can then be estimated.

Option C: Total body water- Similar to total body potassium, measuring total body water is not a direct method for assessing body fat but is used to estimate body composition. By determining the amount of water present in the body, various equations can be applied to estimate fat-free mass, and subsequently, body fat mass.

questions.text: What is the proportion of disease occurrence in the exposed population compared to the non-exposed population?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Relative risk:

  • Relative risk measures the ratio of the risk of developing a disease in the exposed group compared to the non-exposed group. It's particularly useful in cohort studies for determining how strongly an exposure is associated with the outcome.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Attributable risk: Attributable risk measures the difference in risk between exposed and non-exposed groups.

Option B - Odds ratio: Odds ratio compares the odds of the outcome between exposed and non-exposed groups, often used in case-control studies.

Option D - Population attributable risk: Population attributable risk estimates the proportion of cases attributable to the exposure in the population.

questions.text: All of these are characteristic features of pancreatic carcinoma, except:

choices.text: Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
Carcinoma of body pancreas often present with jaundice

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Carcinoma of body pancreas often present with jaundice:

  • Carcinomas of the body and tail of the pancreas often do not present with jaundice because they are not located near the common bile duct.
  • Jaundice is more commonly associated with tumors located in the head of the pancreas, where they can obstruct the common bile duct and lead to the accumulation of bilirubin in the bloodstream.
  • In contrast, tumors in the body of the pancreas may cause symptoms such as abdominal pain, weight loss, and digestive issues but are less likely to cause jaundice.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cigarette smoking is a risk factor:

  • Cigarette smoking is a well-established risk factor for pancreatic carcinoma.
  • It is one of the most significant environmental risk factors for developing pancreatic cancer, increasing the likelihood of developing the disease.

Option C - They elicit intense desmoplastic response:

  • Pancreatic carcinoma is known for its intense desmoplastic response.
  • The tumor microenvironment in pancreatic cancer is characterized by the proliferation of fibrous connective tissue, which creates a dense stromal reaction around the tumor cells.
  • This desmoplastic response contributes to the poor prognosis and therapeutic challenges associated with pancreatic carcinoma.

Option D - Perineural invasion is common:

  • Perineural invasion is a common feature of pancreatic carcinoma.
  • The tumor cells have a propensity to invade and infiltrate along the nerves in the vicinity of the pancreas, which can contribute to the spread and metastasis of the disease.

questions.text: What should be the minimum rate of couple protection in order to achieve the demographic target of NRR = 1?  NRR: Net Reproduction Rate
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: 60%

This option correctly states that the couple protection rate should exceed 60% to achieve an NRR of 1. While the exact required rate may vary depending on other factors, a couple protection rate exceeding 60% is generally necessary to achieve replacement-level fertility and an NRR of 1.

  • NRR, or Net Reproduction Rate, is a measure used to estimate the average number of daughters that would be born to a woman over her lifetime, given the prevailing age-specific fertility rates. An NRR of 1 indicates that the population is replacing itself, with each generation being replaced by an equal number of offspring.
  • To achieve an NRR of 1, it is necessary to have a couple protection rate that exceeds a certain threshold. The couple protection rate refers to the percentage of couples using effective contraception to prevent pregnancy. The higher the couple protection rate, the more effectively pregnancies are prevented, leading to a lower total fertility rate and potentially achieving an NRR of 1.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 50%- This option suggests that a couple protection rate of 50% is required to reach an NRR of 1. However, this is not accurate. A couple protection rate of 50% might not be sufficient to achieve replacement-level fertility and an NRR of 1.

Option B: 40%- This option suggests that a couple protection rate of 40% is needed to reach an NRR of 1. However, this is not correct. A couple protection rate of 40% might still be insufficient to achieve the desired replacement-level fertility.

Option C: 70%- This option suggests that a couple protection rate of 70% is necessary to reach an NRR of 1. However, this is not accurate. While a higher couple protection rate increases the likelihood of achieving replacement-level fertility, a rate of 70% may be higher than what is required to reach an NRR of 1

questions.text: Stellate granuloma is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cat-scratch disease:

  • Stellate granuloma is a characteristic histopathological finding in cat-scratch disease.
  • Cat-scratch disease is caused by the bacteria Bartonella henselae, which is typically transmitted to humans through scratches or bites from infected cats.
  • Stellate granulomas are collections of histiocytes with radiating, slender cytoplasmic projections, giving them a star-shaped appearance.
  • These granulomas are commonly found in the lymph nodes near the site of inoculation.

Incorrect Options:

  • Stellate granuloma is not seen in options A, C, and D.

questions.text: What is the name of the recently introduced online software by the Indian government, as part of the national tuberculosis elimination program (NTEP), for the purpose of monitoring patients with tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  A - NIKSHAY:

  • This is the correct answer. NIKSHAY is an online software specifically designed for the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program in India. It facilitates the tracking of TB patients, monitors their treatment progress, manages drug supply, and provides real-time data for better decision-making and planning.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - NISCHAY: NISCHAY is not associated with the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program or TB patient monitoring. 

Option C - E-DOTS: While e-DOTS is a term associated with the use of electronic DOTS for TB treatment, it is not the specific software launched under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program in India.

Option D - NIKUSTH: NIKUSTH is not a recognized software or system related to the monitoring of TB patients under the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program.

questions.text: How are cytotoxic and expired drugs typically disposed of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Incineration

  • Incineration involves burning the drugs at high temperatures in a controlled environment. Incineration is an effective method for the disposal of cytotoxic drugs, which are hazardous due to their potential toxicity. It ensures that the drugs are completely destroyed, reducing the risk of environmental contamination and potential harm to human health.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Dumping- Dumping, or simply discarding drugs, is not an appropriate method for disposing of cytotoxic and expired drugs.

Option B: Autoclave-Autoclaving sterilizes by high heat and pressure, effective for lab waste and medical gear, but not ideal for disposing of cytotoxic drugs or expired medications.

Option D: Chemical disinfection- Chemical disinfection kills microbes on surfaces or in liquids but isn't suitable for disposing of cytotoxic or expired drugs.

questions.text: A colonoscopy of an elderly patient revealed brownish pigmented lesions as shown below. He admitted to chronic laxative abuse. Which of the following laxatives is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Senna:

  • Senna is a stimulant laxative commonly used for the treatment of constipation.

  • It contains anthraquinone derivatives that can cause pigment deposition in the colon, resulting in melanosis coli.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bran: Bran is a high-fiber substance derived from the outer layer of cereal grains. It is commonly used as a natural laxative. Bran itself does not typically cause melanosis coli, which is characterized by brownish pigmented lesions in the colon.

Option B - Psyllium: Psyllium is a soluble fiber commonly used as a bulk-forming laxative. It absorbs water and adds bulk to the stool, promoting regular bowel movements. Psyllium is not known to cause melanosis coli.

Option D - Methylcellulose: Methylcellulose is a bulk-forming laxative that absorbs water and forms a gel-like substance, adding bulk to the stool. It does not typically cause melanosis coli. Thus, it is not the likely cause of the condition described.

questions.text: In a population of 1000 individuals, a screening test was conducted for DM (diabetes mellitus). It showed that 90 individuals tested positive for DM. Subsequently, a gold standard test for DM was conducted, and it showed that 100 individuals tested positive. Your task is to determine the sensitivity of the screening test.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 90/100:

  • Sensitivity measures how well a screening test identifies individuals with the disease (true positives).

  • In this case, out of 100 individuals with diabetes, the screening test correctly identified 90 (true positives).

Therefore, the sensitivity of the screening test is 90/100

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A patient who is on treatment for angina, presents to you with erectile dysfunction. You decide against prescribing sildenafil because the patient is being treated with ____________:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nitrates:

  • Nitrates: Nitrates are a class of medications commonly used in the treatment of angina.

  • Sildenafil, the medication used for erectile dysfunction, should not be prescribed concomitantly with nitrates.

  • Both medications can cause a significant drop in blood pressure when used together, leading to a potentially dangerous condition called hypotension.

  • Therefore, nitrates are the correct option for the given scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers are commonly used in the treatment of angina to relax and widen the blood vessels, reducing the workload on the heart and improving blood flow. They are generally not contraindicated with sildenafil, the medication used to treat erectile dysfunction. Therefore, calcium channel blockers are an incorrect option for the given scenario.

Option B - Beta blockers: Beta blockers are another class of medications commonly used to treat angina. They work by reducing the heart rate and blood pressure. While beta blockers can potentially contribute to erectile dysfunction, they are not an absolute contraindication for sildenafil use. In fact, sildenafil can be prescribed cautiously in patients taking beta blockers under appropriate medical supervision. Therefore, beta blockers are an incorrect option for the given scenario.

Option D - ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors are a class of medications commonly used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure. They do not typically cause significant interactions or contraindications with sildenafil. Therefore, ACE inhibitors are an incorrect option for the given scenario.

questions.text: What is the prevalence of a disease with an average duration of 2 years, when the incidence is 4 per 1000 of the population?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 8/1000:

  • Prevalence is calculated by multiplying the incidence rate by the duration of the disease. Here, the incidence rate is 4 per 1000 of the population, and the average duration is 2 years. Multiplying these values gives us a prevalence of 8/1000.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 8/100: This represents a prevalence percentage rather than a prevalence rate per 1000.

Option B - 2/1000: This only reflects the incidence rate and does not consider the duration of the disease.

Option C -4/1000: This represents the incidence rate rather than the prevalence rate.

questions.text: An example of a bacteriostatic drug is ________________:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Linezolid:

  • Linezolid is an example of a bacteriostatic drug.

  • It inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome, preventing the formation of functional ribosomes.

  • This inhibits bacterial growth and replication without necessarily killing the bacteria. Therefore, linezolid is a bacteriostatic drug.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aminoglycoside: Aminoglycosides such as gentamicin and amikacin are examples of bactericidal drugs. They work by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis and killing the bacteria, rather than just inhibiting their growth. Therefore, aminoglycosides are not bacteriostatic drugs.

Option B - Vancomycin: Vancomycin is primarily a bactericidal drug. It interferes with bacterial cell wall synthesis, leading to cell lysis and bacterial death. Therefore, vancomycin is not a bacteriostatic drug.

Option C - Metronidazole: Metronidazole is primarily a bactericidal drug. It acts by disrupting the DNA structure and inhibiting nucleic acid synthesis in susceptible bacteria, leading to their death. Therefore, metronidazole is not a bacteriostatic drug.

questions.text: Which antiviral drug possesses dual antiviral activity against both HIV and HBV?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Tenofovir:

  • Tenofovir is a nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is effective against both HIV and HBV.
  • It inhibits the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is essential for the replication of both viruses.
  • Tenofovir is available in two main formulations: tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF) and tenofovir alafenamide (TAF).
  • Both are used in the treatment of HIV infection as well as chronic hepatitis B infection.
  • TDF and TAF are included in various combination antiretroviral therapy (ART) regimens for HIV/AIDS, providing dual antiviral activity against both viruses.

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the likelihood of an infection occurring in a susceptible individual after coming into contact with an infectious person during the incubation period?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Secondary attack rate:

  • The secondary attack rate measures the proportion of susceptible individuals who become infected after coming into contact with an infectious individual during the incubation period. It provides an estimate of the transmission potential of the disease within a specific population or setting.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Case fatality rate: The case fatality rate (CFR) is the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a particular disease who die from it. 

Option C - Primary attack rate: The primary attack rate measures the proportion of initially susceptible individuals who become infected after exposure to an infectious agent. 

Option D - Tertiary attack rate: The term "tertiary attack rate" is not commonly used in epidemiology. It does not refer to a specific measure of disease transmission

questions.text: What is the prescribed dosage of hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency, measured in milligrams per square meter per day?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C -  10:

  • The replacement dose of hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency is typically based on the body surface area (BSA) of the individual.

  • The recommended dose is approximately 10-12 mg/m²/day.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 20 mg/m²/day: This dosage is higher than the recommended replacement dose for hydrocortisone in adrenal insufficiency.

Option B - 25 mg/m²/day: This dosage is also higher than the recommended replacement dose.

Option D - 5 mg/m²/day: This dosage is lower than the recommended replacement dose and may not be sufficient to adequately manage adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: Which of the options below does not lead to water hardness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Calcium carbonate

  • This compound does not contribute to water hardness directly.

Option B: Calcium sulphate- Calcium sulphate, also known as gypsum, is a common mineral that can dissolve in water, releasing calcium and sulphate ions.
