Option C: Calcium bicarbonate- When carbon dioxide dissolves in water, it forms carbonic acid, which can react with calcium carbonate to produce calcium bicarbonate. This compound is soluble in water and contributes to water hardness.

Option D: Magnesium bicarbonate- Magnesium bicarbonate forms when magnesium ions react with bicarbonate ions in water.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for scrub typhus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Doxycycline:

  • This is the drug of choice for scrub typhus.

  • Doxycycline is effective against Orientia tsutsugamushi and is commonly used as the first-line treatment.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Azithromycin: Azithromycin can be an alternative treatment option for scrub typhus, especially in cases where doxycycline is contraindicated or not tolerated. However, doxycycline is generally preferred due to its established efficacy.

Option C - Chloramphenicol: Chloramphenicol was previously considered the drug of choice for scrub typhus. However, due to its potential side effects and the availability of safer and more effective alternatives, such as doxycycline, it is no longer recommended as the first-line treatment.

Option D - Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is not typically used as the first-line treatment for scrub typhus. Other antibiotics, such as doxycycline and azithromycin, are more commonly recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with QT prolongation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Quinidine:

  • Quinidine is an antiarrhythmic medication that can cause QT prolongation, along with other cardiac rhythm abnormalities. It is known to have a potential proarrhythmic effect.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lignocaine: Lignocaine (also known as Lidocaine) is a local anesthetic and is not typically associated with significant QT prolongation. It can shorten the QT interval.

Option C - Magnesium sulfate: Magnesium sulfate is commonly used in the treatment of certain cardiac arrhythmias and is not typically associated with significant QT prolongation.

Option D - All of the above: Lignocaine and magnesium sulfate are not strongly associated with QT prolongation. Only quinidine is known for its potential to prolong the QT interval.

questions.text: Which of the following options does not represent a method of direct transmission of communicable diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Droplet nuclei (in bold letters):

  • Droplet nuclei are small (size <5 microns) and lighter particles
  • They are airborne and can remain suspended in the air for long periods and can travel over distances greater than 1 meter.
  • They are involved in airborne transmission, which is an indirect method of transmission. Hence, this option does not represent a method of direct transmission.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & D are incorrect

  • Vertical transmission, Contact with soil and Droplet transmission are all examples of direct transmission

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of sacubitril, a newly approved drug for the treatment of chronic heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Neutral endopeptidase inhibitor:

  • Sacubitril is a neutral endopeptidase inhibitor, also known as a neprilysin inhibitor. It is used in the treatment of chronic heart failure.

  • The mechanism of action of sacubitril involves inhibiting the enzyme neprilysin, which is responsible for the degradation of several vasoactive peptides, including natriuretic peptides, bradykinin, and adrenomedullin.

  • By inhibiting neprilysin, sacubitril increases the levels of these vasoactive peptides, leading to vasodilation, diuresis, and natriuresis.

  • This helps to reduce the workload on the heart and improve cardiac function in patients with heart failure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Angiotensin II inhibitor: Angiotensin II inhibitors, also known as angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), work by blocking the action of angiotensin II, a hormone that constricts blood vessels and promotes water and salt retention. They are commonly used in the treatment of hypertension and heart failure, but sacubitril is not an angiotensin II inhibitor.

Option B - ACE inhibitor: ACE inhibitors, or angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, block the enzyme ACE, which converts angiotensin I to angiotensin II. Sacubitril is not an ACE inhibitor.

Option C - Renin inhibitor: Renin inhibitors target the enzyme renin, which plays a key role in the production of angiotensin II. By inhibiting renin, these drugs reduce the production of angiotensin II and help lower blood pressure. However, sacubitril is not a renin inhibitor.

questions.text: What should be the minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 4 weeks:

  • Minimum interval between two live vaccines is 4 weeks
  • Live vaccines contain weakened forms of infectious agents
  • Stimulate immune system without causing full-blown illness
  • Interval ensures adequate immune response, minimizes interference

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 2 weeks: Shorter interval may not allow sufficient time for immune response

Option C - 8 weeks: Longer interval may not be necessary, recommended minimum is shorter

Option D - 12 weeks: Even longer interval generally not required for most live vaccines

questions.text: Which drugs require monitoring of the coagulation profile during therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lepirudin:

Coagulation profile monitoring is needed in therapy with lepirudin.

  • Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that is mainly used as an anticoagulant during heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

  • Coagulation profile monitoring, including activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), is necessary during lepirudin therapy to ensure appropriate anticoagulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux is a synthetic anticoagulant that specifically inhibits factor Xa. It does not require routine coagulation profile monitoring.

Option B - Enoxaparin: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin that also inhibits factor Xa. While regular coagulation profile monitoring is not necessary, periodic monitoring of platelet count is recommended.

Option C - Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor. It does not require routine coagulation profile monitoring, as it has a predictable anticoagulant effect.

questions.text: Mononuclear Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lymphocyte-rich HL:

  • Mononuclear Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are characteristic cells seen in the lymphocyte-rich subtype of HL.

Incorrect Options:

  • Mononuclear Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells are not seen in Options A, B, and D.

questions.text: Which of the following areas is not endemic to Kala-Azar?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Assam:

  • Kala-Azar is not endemic in Assam. While Assam does have its share of vector-borne diseases, Kala-Azar is not prevalent in this state.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & C are incorrect

  • West Bengal, Uttar Pradesh (UP) and Bihar are endemic to Kala-Azar

questions.text: Which of the subsequent antihypertensive medications are contraindicated during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Propranolol

  • Propranolol is not typically used in pregnancy due to its potential adverse effects on fetal growth and development.
  • Propranolol is generally avoided during pregnancy, particularly during the first trimester, due to concerns about its potential adverse effects on fetal growth and development.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Alpha methyldopa- Alpha methyldopa is commonly used as an antihypertensive medication during pregnancy. It has a long history of safe use and is considered one of the first-line choices for managing hypertension in pregnant women.

Option B: Hydralazine- Hydralazine is also frequently used in pregnancy to control blood pressure. It is considered safe for use during pregnancy and is often used as an alternative if other agents are not suitable or effective.

Option D: Labetalol- Labetalol is commonly used in pregnancy to manage hypertension. It is considered safe and effective for use during pregnancy and is often recommended as a first-line choice for treating hypertension in pregnant women.

questions.text: Among the subsequent atypical antipsychotic medications, which one poses the greatest likelihood of galactorrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Risperidone:

  • Risperidone is known to have a higher risk of causing galactorrhea compared to other atypical antipsychotics.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Iloperidone:

  • While iloperidone can potentially cause hyperprolactinemia (elevated levels of prolactin hormone), it is not commonly associated with a high risk of galactorrhea.

Option C - Clozapine:

Adverse effects

  • Can produce Agranulocytosis (dose independent).

  • Seizures (dose dependent).

  • Myocarditis.

  • Wet pillow syndrome- Causes Sialorrhea due to M4 agonism by Clozapine. The treatment is Atropine given locally

  • Anticholinergic properties

    • Risk of mydriasis

    • Contraindicated in angle closure glaucoma

Option D - Aripiprazole:

  • Aripiprazole is known as a partial agonist of dopamine receptors and has a lower risk of causing hyperprolactinemia and subsequent galactorrhea compared to some other atypical antipsychotics.

questions.text: In ecological studies, what is the unit of observation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Population:

  • Ecological studies analyze population-level relationships between exposures and health outcomes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Patient: Focuses on individual health conditions, not population-level data.

Option C - Healthy individuals: Ecological studies consider entire populations, not just healthy individuals.

Option D - Case: Pertains to specific health conditions, not the broader population studied in ecological research.

questions.text: When the pH = pKa of a drug, which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Concentration of the drug is 50% ionic and 50% non-ionic
Concentration of the drug is 90% ionic and 10% non-ionic
Concentration of the drug is 75% ionic and 25% non-ionic
Concentration of the drug is 25% ionic and 75% non-ionic

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Concentration of the drug is 50% ionic and 50% non-ionic: 

  • The pKa of a drug is the pH at which the drug exists in equal concentrations of its ionized (ionic) and non-ionized (non-ionic) forms.

  • There for when pH = pKa, the drug is at its half-ionization point, meaning that it is 50% ionized and 50% non-ionized.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which corticosteroid is recommended for promoting the maturation of fetal lungs in preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Betamethasone

  • Betamethasone is the corticosteroid indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation in preterm labor.
  • Betamethasone belongs to the class of glucocorticoids and has potent anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive properties.
  • It is commonly used in obstetrics to enhance fetal lung maturity when preterm delivery is anticipated.
  • Administering betamethasone to the pregnant woman helps promote the production of surfactant in the fetal lungs, which is crucial for the proper functioning of the lungs and prevention of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm infants.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Hydrocortisone is a corticosteroid that has a wide range of uses, but it is not specifically indicated for fetal lung maturation in preterm labor.

Option B: Triamcinolone, another corticosteroid, is primarily used for its anti-inflammatory properties and is not the preferred choice for fetal lung maturation.

Option C: Methylprednisolone- Methylprednisolone is a corticosteroid that is used for various medical conditions, including inflammatory and autoimmune disorders. However, it is not the corticosteroid of choice for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation in preterm labor.

questions.text: In fungi, where does amphotericin B primarily exert its effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C: Cell membrane

  • Amphotericin B primarily acts on the cell membrane of fungi.
  • It binds to ergosterol, a component of the fungal cell membrane, forming pores and disrupting the integrity and function of the membrane.
  • This leads to leakage of intracellular contents, altered ion balance, and ultimately, cell death.
  • By targeting the cell membrane, amphotericin B exhibits its antifungal activity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Nucleic acid- Amphotericin B does not directly target nucleic acids in fungi. Its mechanism of action is primarily related to the disruption of the cell membrane.

Option B: Ribosome- Amphotericin B does not target the ribosomes of fungi. Ribosomes are involved in protein synthesis, and their inhibition is the mechanism of action of certain antibiotics, but not amphotericin B.

Option D: Cytoplasm- Amphotericin B does not act within the cytoplasm of fungi. Its primary site of action is the cell membrane, as mentioned above.

questions.text: Which of the following actions leads to a decrease in bone resorption and an increase in bone formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Strontium ranelate:

  • Strontium ranelate is a medication used for the treatment of osteoporosis.

  • It exerts its effects by both decreasing bone resorption (the process of breaking down bone) and increasing bone formation.

  • It enhances osteoblast activity, which is responsible for bone formation, while reducing osteoclast activity, which is responsible for bone resorption.

  • This dual mechanism helps to improve bone density and strength.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ibandronate: Ibandronate is a bisphosphonate medication that primarily acts by inhibiting osteoclast activity and reducing bone resorption. It does not have a direct effect on bone formation.

Option C - Teriparatide: Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and is used in the treatment of osteoporosis. It primarily stimulates bone formation by activating osteoblasts and increasing bone remodeling. However, it does not have a direct effect on reducing bone resorption.

Option D - Calcitonin: Calcitonin is a hormone that regulates calcium and phosphate metabolism. It can inhibit osteoclast activity and reduce bone resorption. However, it does not have a significant effect on promoting bone formation.

questions.text: What is the medication utilized for the treatment of refractory and intractable rheumatic chorea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D: Sodium valproate

  • Sodium valproate is an antiepileptic medication that is also used for the treatment of various neurological and psychiatric conditions.
  • It has been found to be effective in managing refractory intractable rheumatic chorea, a movement disorder associated with rheumatic fever.
  • Sodium valproate helps to reduce the severity and frequency of abnormal movements seen in chorea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Probenecid- Probenecid is a medication primarily used in the treatment of gout and certain other conditions involving high levels of uric acid. It does not have a specific role in the management of rheumatic chorea.

Option B: Diazepam- Diazepam is a benzodiazepine medication that is commonly used as a muscle relaxant, antianxiety agent, and anticonvulsant. While it may help manage some of the symptoms associated with chorea, it is not considered a primary treatment for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea.

Option C: Haloperidol- Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication primarily used in the treatment of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders. While it may help control certain aspects of chorea, it is not the drug of choice for refractory intractable rheumatic chorea.

questions.text: In which of the following medical conditions can the X-ray finding be observed?
questions.solution:
Correction Option C: Reflux esophagitis

  • Reflux esophagitis is the condition for which X-ray findings may show signs of esophageal inflammation, such as mucosal irregularities, ulcerations, or strictures.
  • Reflux esophagitis is a condition characterized by inflammation of the esophagus due to the backward flow of stomach acid and contents. I
  • It is typically associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

Incorrect options

Option A: Esophageal atresia- Esophageal atresia is a congenital condition in which the esophagus does not properly connect to the stomach. X-ray findings for esophageal atresia may show an absence or air-filled pouch in the upper or lower part of the esophagus. This abnormality can be detected on an X-ray examination with contrast material.

Option B: Esophageal stenosis- Esophageal stenosis refers to a narrowing or constriction of the esophagus. It can be caused by various factors, including scarring, inflammation, or abnormal tissue growth. X-ray findings for esophageal stenosis may show a narrowing or "pinched" appearance of the esophagus on a contrast-enhanced X-ray study.

Option D: Barrett's esophagus- Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the normal lining of the esophagus is replaced with abnormal cells resembling those found in the intestine. This change is often associated with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Diagnosis of Barrett's esophagus typically requires an endoscopic examination with biopsy. X-ray findings alone may not be indicative of Barrett's esophagus

questions.text: What is basiliximab?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C: IL-2 receptor antagonist

  • Basiliximab is an immunosuppressive medication that acts as an IL-2 receptor antagonist.
  • It specifically binds to the alpha chain of the IL-2 receptor, which is expressed on activated T lymphocytes.
  • By blocking this receptor, basiliximab inhibits IL-2 signaling and prevents T-cell activation and proliferation.
  • It is primarily used as part of immunosuppressive therapy in kidney transplantation to reduce the risk of organ rejection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: IL-1 receptor antagonist- IL-1 receptor antagonists are a class of drugs that specifically block the activity of interleukin-1 (IL-1), a pro-inflammatory cytokine. Basiliximab does not act as an IL-1 receptor antagonist.

Option B: Anti-CD3 antibody- Anti-CD3 antibodies are monoclonal antibodies that target the CD3 antigen on T lymphocytes. They are used in certain immune-mediated disorders and organ transplantation to modulate T-cell function. Basiliximab is not an anti-CD3 antibody.

Option D: TNF inhibitor- Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors are a class of drugs that block the activity of TNF, a pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in various immune-mediated diseases. Basiliximab does not have TNF inhibitory properties.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below:
questions.solution:
Correction Option C: Superior vena cava

  • The marked structure corresponds to the superior vena cava
  • The superior vena cava is a large vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the upper body to the right atrium of the heart.
  • It is located in the upper part of the chest and is typically visible on a CT scan.

Other options

Option A: Descending aorta- This option is incorrect

Option B: Ascending aorta- This option is incorrect

Option D: Right pulmonary artery- This option is incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can be treated with pirenzepine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Peptic ulcer disease:

  • Pirenzepine is an anticholinergic medication that can be used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease.

  • It works by selectively blocking the M1 receptors of gastric parietal cells, which reduces gastric acid secretion.

  • By reducing acid production, pirenzepine helps in the healing and prevention of ulcers in the stomach and duodenum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Asthma: Pirenzepine is not indicated for the treatment of asthma. Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by airway inflammation and bronchoconstriction. The primary treatment for asthma involves bronchodilators, anti-inflammatory medications, and in some cases, corticosteroids. Antimuscarinic drugs used in asthma target M3 receptors which are found in the bronchioles.

Option C - Glaucoma: Pirenzepine is not used in the treatment of glaucoma. Glaucoma is an eye condition characterized by increased intraocular pressure, which can lead to optic nerve damage. The mainstay of treatment for glaucoma involves medications that lower intraocular pressure, such as prostaglandin analogs, beta-blockers, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors. Anticholinergics are not used in treatment of glaucoma as they cause mydriasis and potentially worsen the condition by blocking aqueous humour outflow

Option D - Hypertension: Pirenzepine is not indicated for the treatment of hypertension. Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is typically managed with antihypertensive medications such as diuretics, beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, or calcium channel blockers.

questions.text: Which of the following antimicrobials is effective against an organism producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Piperacillin – Tazobactam:

  • Extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs) are enzymes produced by certain bacteria that confer resistance to a broad range of beta-lactam antibiotics, including penicillins and cephalosporins.

  • Piperacillin-Tazobactam: This combination antibiotic consists of piperacillin, a penicillin, and tazobactam, a beta-lactamase inhibitor. Tazobactam inhibits the activity of beta-lactamases, including ESBLs, thereby restoring the efficacy of piperacillin against ESBL-producing bacteria.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Amoxicillin-Clavulanic acid: This combination antibiotic consists of amoxicillin, a penicillin, and clavulanic acid, a beta-lactamase inhibitor. While it is effective against some beta-lactamase-producing organisms, it may not be effective against ESBL-producing bacteria, as ESBLs can still hydrolyze the amoxicillin component.

Option B - Penicillin: Penicillin antibiotics are not effective against bacteria producing ESBLs, as these enzymes can hydrolyze and inactivate penicillins.

Option D - Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a cephalosporin antibiotic and is not effective against ESBL-producing bacteria. ESBLs can hydrolyze and inactivate cephalosporins, including ceftriaxone.

questions.text: Which of the options hinders the production of glucocorticoid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Metyrapone:

  • Metyrapone is a medication used to inhibit the synthesis of glucocorticoids in the adrenal glands.

  • It acts by inhibiting the enzyme 11-beta-hydroxylase, which is involved in the conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol, a major glucocorticoid hormone.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mifepristone: Mifepristone, also known as RU-486, is a medication used for medical abortion and in some cases for the treatment of Cushing's syndrome. It acts as a progesterone and glucocorticoid receptor antagonist, but it does not directly inhibit the synthesis of glucocorticoids.

Option B - Flutamide: Flutamide is an antiandrogen medication primarily used in the treatment of prostate cancer. It does not inhibit the synthesis of glucocorticoids.

Option C - Finasteride: Finasteride is a medication primarily used for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (enlarged prostate) and male pattern hair loss. It inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), but it does not directly inhibit the synthesis of glucocorticoids.

questions.text: The X Ray of the skull as shown in the image given below is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Hyperparathyroidism

  • The X-ray appearance of a "salt and pepper" skull is typically seen in hyperparathyroidism.
  • Hyperparathyroidism is a condition characterized by overactivity of the parathyroid glands, resulting in excessive production of parathyroid hormone (PTH).

Incorrect Option:

Option B: Multiple myeloma- Multiple myeloma is a type of cancer that affects plasma cells in the bone marrow. While multiple myeloma can cause bone lesions and bone destruction, the specific "salt and pepper" appearance of the skull on X-ray is not typically associated with this condition.

Option C: Hyperthyroidism- Hyperthyroidism is a condition characterized by overactive thyroid function, resulting in excessive production of thyroid hormones. While hyperthyroidism can affect bone metabolism and density, it does not commonly cause the "salt and pepper" appearance of the skull on X-ray.

Option D: Paget's disease- Paget's disease of bone is a chronic condition characterized by abnormal bone remodeling, leading to enlarged bones. While Paget's disease can result in changes to the skull, including thickening or enlargement, the "salt and pepper" appearance on X-ray is not a typical finding in this condition.

questions.text: Isosorbide dinitrate is indicated for congestive heart failure in combination with which of the following vasodilators?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hydralazine:

  • Isosorbide dinitrate can be used in combination with hydralazine for the treatment of congestive heart failure.

  • Hydralazine is a direct-acting vasodilator that works by relaxing the smooth muscles of the blood vessels, thereby reducing peripheral resistance and improving cardiac output.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Minoxidil: Minoxidil is a potent vasodilator primarily used for the treatment of hypertension and male pattern baldness. It is not commonly used in combination with isosorbide dinitrate for congestive heart failure.

Option C - Nimodipine: These are calcium channel blockers primarily used for the treatment of cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage. They are not typically used in combination with isosorbide dinitrate for congestive heart failure.

Option D - Nitrendipine: These are calcium channel blockers primarily used for the treatment of cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage. They are not typically used in combination with isosorbide dinitrate for congestive heart failure.

questions.text: How does colchicine work in the body?

choices.text: Binds to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Colchicine:

  • Colchicine exerts its mechanism of action by binding to tubulin and inhibiting granulocyte migration, specifically targeting the microtubules.
  • This action reduces the inflammatory response associated with conditions such as gout and familial Mediterranean fever.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Inhibits synthesis of uric acid: This is not the mechanism of action of colchicine. Colchicine does not directly inhibit the synthesis of uric acid.

Option B - Promotes excretion of uric acid: Colchicine does not promote the excretion of uric acid. Its primary action is related to its anti-inflammatory properties.

Option C - Inhibits xanthine oxidase enzyme: Colchicine does not inhibit the xanthine oxidase enzyme. Xanthine oxidase inhibitors, such as allopurinol, are used to reduce uric acid production.

questions.text: Which dye is employed for the identification of esophageal perforation during diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Iohexol

  • "Iohexol," as it can be used to assess esophageal perforation in certain imaging modalities, particularly CT scans with oral contrast.
  • Iohexol is a non-ionic, water-soluble radiographic contrast medium with a molecular weight of 821.14 (iodine content 46.36%).

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A: Gastrografin- Gastrografin is a water-soluble iodinated contrast agent that is commonly used for diagnostic imaging of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. It is not preferred nowadays due to risk of pulmonary edema and aspiration pneumonia.
  • Option C: Gadolinium- Gadolinium is a contrast agent used for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). It is primarily used to enhance the visualization of blood vessels, organs, and certain tissues during MRI scans. However, gadolinium is not commonly used for the diagnosis of esophageal perforation.
  • Option D: Barium sulfate- It is contraindicated in esophageal perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes prasugrel?

choices.text: It acts as an P2Y12 agonist
It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel
Omeprazole interferes in its activation to an active metabolite

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It is a pro drug:

  • Prasugrel is a thienopyridine antiplatelet agent that is administered in its inactive prodrug form.

  • It requires enzymatic conversion in the liver to its active metabolite, which then irreversibly inhibits the P2Y12 adenosine diphosphate (ADP) receptor on platelets, preventing platelet activation and aggregation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It acts as a P2Y12 agonist: Prasugrel acts as a P2Y12 antagonist, not an agonist. It blocks the P2Y12 receptor on platelets, leading to inhibition of platelet activation.

Option B - It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel: Prasugrel is considered to be more potent than clopidogrel. It has a faster onset of action, greater inhibition of platelet aggregation, and reduced inter-individual variability compared to clopidogrel.

Option D - Omeprazole interferes in its activation to an active metabolite: Omeprazole, a proton pump inhibitor, is known to inhibit the activation of clopidogrel to its active metabolite. However, there is no significant interaction between prasugrel and omeprazole that interferes with its activation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has come with sudden onset of chest pain and his CT scan shows the following picture. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Aortic dissection

  • Based on the sudden onset of severe chest pain and the characteristic appearance of the CT scan image with a dissection flap in the aorta, the correct diagnosis in this case is option b, "Aortic dissection."

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Pulmonary embolism- The symptoms typically include sudden onset chest pain, shortness of breath, and sometimes coughing up blood. However, the CT scan image provided in this case does not show typical findings consistent with pulmonary embolism.

Option C: Aortic aneurysm- While aortic aneurysms can present with chest or abdominal pain, the CT scan image provided does not demonstrate the typical appearance of an aortic aneurysm.

Option D: Myocardial infarction- It usually presents with symptoms such as severe chest pain, shortness of breath, and sweating. The CT scan image shown does not provide evidence of a myocardial infarction.

questions.text: To which class of drugs does Apixaban belong in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Factor Xa inhibitors:

  • Apixaban belongs to the class of drugs known as Factor Xa inhibitors.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Antifibrinolytic: Antifibrinolytic drugs work by promoting clot stability and preventing the breakdown of blood clots. Examples of antifibrinolytic drugs include tranexamic acid and aminocaproic acid. They have a different mechanism of action compared to apixaban.

Option C - Oral direct thrombin inhibitor: Oral direct thrombin inhibitors, such as dabigatran, directly inhibit the activity of thrombin, which is a key enzyme involved in the clotting cascade. These drugs act upstream in the clotting process compared to Factor Xa inhibitors like apixaban.

Option D - Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor: Parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors are administered through injection or infusion and directly inhibit thrombin.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a young woman taking oral contraceptives based on the provided scan?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Hepatic adenoma

  • The given CT scan image showing a liver mass in a young woman on oral contraceptives is most likely indicative of a hepatocellular adenoma, which is associated with oral contraceptive use.
  • The CT scan image may show a well-defined mass in the liver with characteristic features of hepatocellular adenoma.

Incorrect Options;

Option A: Hepatocellular carcinoma- The given CT scan image showing a hepatocellular adenoma is not consistent with the appearance of hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option B: Metastatic infiltrates- Metastatic infiltrates refer to the spread of cancer cells from another primary site to the liver. While metastatic liver lesions can occur in individuals with a history of cancer, the given CT scan image showing a hepatocellular adenoma is not consistent with metastatic infiltrates.

Option D: Hemangioma- Hemangiomas are benign tumors that consist of abnormal blood vessels. They are the most common benign liver tumors and are typically asymptomatic. Hemangiomas can be incidentally found on imaging studies such as CT scans. However, the given CT scan image showing a hepatocellular adenoma is not consistent with the appearance of a hemangioma.

questions.text: What is the consequence of thrombosis in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lateral medullary syndrome:

  • Thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) can cause lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome.
  • Lateral medullary syndrome can occur due to occlusion of any of the 5 vessels
    • Vertebral artery
    • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
    • Superior medullary artery
    • Middle medullary artery
    • Inferior lateral medullary artery
  • It presents with vertigo, numbness of the ipsilateral face and contralateral limbs, diplopia, hoarseness, dysarthria, dysphagia, and ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Weber syndrome: This statement is incorrect. Weber syndrome is caused by the lesions in the midbrain.

Option C - Medial medullary syndrome: This statement is incorrect. Medial medullary syndrome is caused by the thrombosis of the anterior spinal artery.

Option D - Millard Gubler syndrome: This statement is incorrect. Millard Gubler syndrome, also known as ventral pontine syndrome, is caused by a lesion affecting the pons.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who has symptoms of frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis, along with a 24-hour urine volume of 7 liters, a urine osmolarity of 260 mOsm/L, an ADH assay result of 0.8 pg/ml, and a brain MRI showing no bright spot on T1 weighted images?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C -  Pituitary DI (diabetes insipidus)

  • The patient's presentation of frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis along with a 24-hour urine volume of 7 liters and low urine osmolarity indicates the inability to concentrate urine, which is a characteristic feature of diabetes insipidus.
  • The low ADH (antidiuretic hormone) level detected by the assay suggests and absence of the bright spot on T1 weighted MRI is consistent with a lack of posterior pituitary gland hyperintensity, further supporting the diagnosis of pituitary DI.
  • In pituitary DI, the polyuria results in a small (1–2%) decrease in body water and a commensurate increase in plasma osmolarity and sodium that stimulates thirst and a compensatory increase in water intake.
  • As a result, hypernatremia and other overt physical or laboratory signs of dehydration do not develop unless the patient also has a defect in thirst or fails to increase fluid intake for some other reason.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nephrogenic DI: This statement is incorrect. Nephrogenic DI is characterized by impaired renal response to ADH, resulting in the inability to concentrate urine. 

Option B - Primary polydipsia: This statement is incorrect. Primary polydipsia refers to excessive water intake leading to water diuresis. 

Option D - Mannitol infusion: This statement is incorrect. Mannitol infusion, a diuretic agent, is used to increase urine output in specific clinical situations.

questions.text: A child presents with left to right shunt and high output cardiac failure. The following is his MRA. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Vein of Galen malformation

  • The given MRA image showing the abnormality in the Vein of Galen supports this diagnosis. Vein of Galen malformation is a rare but significant condition that requires specialized management and treatment.
  • Vein of Galen malformation. It is a rare congenital vascular abnormality involving the malformation of the deep cerebral veins, resulting in an abnormal connection between the arterial and venous systems within the brain.
  • This abnormality leads to a left to right shunt, where blood flows directly from high-pressure arterial circulation to low-pressure venous circulation, causing a high-output cardiac failure.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Dandy Walker syndrome- Dandy Walker syndrome is a congenital brain malformation characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the cerebellar vermis, cystic enlargement of the fourth ventricle, and an enlarged posterior fossa. It is not related to the MRA image provided, which shows a vascular abnormality rather than a brain malformation.

Option C: Pneumocephalus- Pneumocephalus refers to the presence of air or gas within the cranial cavity. It typically occurs as a result of trauma, surgery, or infection. The MRA image does not show any evidence of pneumocephalus, and it is not related to the symptoms of left to right shunt and high-output cardiac failure mentioned in the question.

Option D. Venous sinus thrombosis: Venous sinus thrombosis is a condition characterized by the formation of blood clots within the dural venous sinuses, which are large veins that drain blood from the brain. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including headache, seizures, and neurological deficits. However, the MRA image provided does not show any evidence of venous sinus thrombosis, and it is not associated with the typical presentation of left to right shunt and high-output cardiac failure.

questions.text: The most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Painless hematuria:

  • Painless hematuria is the most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma.
  • Hematuria refers to the presence of blood in the urine, and when it occurs without pain, it is often associated with bladder carcinoma.
  • Painless hematuria may occur intermittently or be persistent, and it is an important warning sign that should prompt further evaluation for bladder cancer.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Painful hematuria:

  • While hematuria can sometimes be associated with pain, especially in conditions such as urinary tract infections or kidney stones, painful hematuria is less commonly seen in bladder carcinoma.
  • Bladder carcinoma typically presents with painless hematuria as the primary symptom.

Option C - Dysuria:

  • Dysuria refers to painful or difficult urination and is not a consistent feature of bladder carcinoma.
  • Dysuria is more commonly associated with urinary tract infections.

Option D - Suprapubic mass:

  • The presence of a suprapubic mass is not a specific or consistent feature of bladder carcinoma.
  • Bladder carcinoma may lead to the development of a bladder tumor or a thickened bladder wall, but the presence of a palpable mass is less common.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Unicornuate uterus

  • Based on the given hysterosalpingogram image, the correct diagnosis is option C, "Unicornuate uterus."
  • The image demonstrates a single uterine cavity without evidence of a double uterus, bicornuate uterus, or septate uterus.
  • A unicornuate uterus is a condition in which only one half of the uterus develops properly, while the other half fails to develop or is very small.
  • It results from the incomplete development of one Müllerian duct.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Uterus didelphys- Uterus didelphys, also known as a double uterus, is a condition in which there are two separate uterine cavities, each with its own cervix. It occurs due to incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts during embryonic development.

Option B: Bicornuate uterus- Bicornuate uterus is a condition characterized by a uterus that has a heart-shaped or two-horned appearance. I

Option D: Septate uterus- Septate uterus is a condition characterized by the presence of a uterine septum, which is a band of tissue dividing the uterine cavity into two separate cavities.

questions.text: In which situation is the Bragg peak effect most prominent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Proton

  • "Proton." Protons exhibit a pronounced Bragg peak effect, meaning they deposit most of their energy at a specific depth within tissue.
  • This characteristic is advantageous in radiation therapy, as it allows for precise targeting of tumors while minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissue.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: X-ray- X-rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation commonly used in medical imaging. X-rays have a relatively low mass and do not exhibit the Bragg peak effect. Instead, their energy deposition decreases gradually as they pass through tissue.

Option C: Neutron- Neutrons are electrically neutral particles found in the atomic nucleus. Neutrons have a different interaction mechanism with tissue compared to protons. While they can cause ionization and biological damage, they do not exhibit a pronounced Bragg peak effect like protons. Neutrons have a more gradual energy deposition profile as they penetrate through tissue.

Option D: Electron- Electrons are negatively charged particles that are commonly used in radiation therapy. Electrons have a different energy deposition pattern compared to protons. They typically deposit their energy in a continuous manner along their path, without a distinct Bragg peak effect

questions.text: The image seen below shows
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Hysterosalpingography

  • The given image corresponds to a hysterosalpingogram showing bilateral hydrosalpinx, which indicates tubal blockage and the accumulation of fluid in the fallopian tubes.
  • It is a radiologic procedure used to evaluate the anatomy of the uterus and fallopian tubes.
  • During HSG, a contrast medium is injected into the uterine cavity, and X-ray images are taken to assess the shape, size, and patency of the fallopian tubes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)- Magnetic Resonance Imaging is a diagnostic imaging technique that uses strong magnetic fields and radio waves to produce detailed images of the body's internal structures.

Option B: Positron Emission Tomography (PET)- Positron Emission Tomography is a nuclear medicine imaging technique that uses a radioactive tracer to visualize metabolic and physiological processes in the body. It is not typically used for the evaluation of tubal patency or the diagnosis of hydrosalpinx.

Option D: Laparoscopic chromopertubation- Laparoscopic chromopertubation is a surgical procedure performed under anesthesia to assess tubal patency. It involves the direct visualization of the pelvic organs using a laparoscope and the injection of a dye into the uterus to evaluate the spillage of dye through the fallopian tubes.

questions.text: Fever occurs during inflammation due to all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Histamine:

  • Histamine is released during allergic reactions and is involved in immediate hypersensitivity reactions.

Incorrect Options:

  • Fever occurs during inflammation due to options A, B, and C.

questions.text: Which prolactin levels are indicative of prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D >200µg/L

  • Elevated prolactin levels are a hallmark feature of prolactinomas, and levels exceeding 200µg/L are considered significantly elevated and strongly indicative of a prolactinoma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C: These statements are incorrect.

questions.text: Anaplasia refers to:

choices.text: Variation in cell size and shape
Replacement of one type of cell by other

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lack of differentiation:

  • Anaplasia is characterized by the loss of normal cellular differentiation, i.e., the tumor cells do not resemble the parent tissue cells they originated from.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Variation in cell size and shape: Pleomorphism refers to the presence of cells with different sizes and shapes within a tumor.

Option C - Replacement of one type of cell by another: Metaplasia refers to the reversible change of one mature cell type to another mature cell type in response to certain stimuli or chronic irritation.

Option D - Disordered arrangement of tumor cells: The disordered arrangement of tumor cells is known as architectural disorder or loss of normal tissue architecture, which is often observed in malignant tumors.

questions.text: Identify the artery marked by arrow
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Superior Mesenteric Artery 

  • Superior mesenteric artery: The artery marked by the blue arrow in the image is indeed the Superior mesenteric artery. It is one of the major branches of the abdominal aorta and supplies blood to the small intestine, part of the large intestine, and other abdominal structures.
  • Red arrow marks left renal vein.
  • The given CT image shows nutcracker syndrome where the left renal vein is compressed between superior mesenteric artery and aorta is seen.

 

Artery Level on CT (Vertebral Level) Origin Branches Structures Supplied Imaging Clues on CT
Celiac Trunk T12–L1 (mainly T12) Abdominal aorta (anterior) Left gastric, splenic, common hepatic Foregut: esophagus to 2nd part of duodenum, etc. Short trunk, “tripod”/“trifurcation” appearance
Superior Mesenteric L1 Aorta (just below celiac) Inferior pancreaticoduodenal, jejunal, etc. Midgut: distal duodenum to proximal 2/3 transverse Long, anterior vessel inferior to celiac, over renal vein
Inferior Mesenteric L3 Aorta (anterior) Left colic, sigmoid, superior rectal Hindgut: distal 1/3 transverse colon to upper rectum Small, anterior, near aortic bifurcation
Renal Arteries L1–L2 Lateral aspect of aorta Segmental arteries Kidneys, adrenal glands, ureters Course laterally; right passes posterior to IVC
Gonadal Arteries L2 Aorta (anterior/lateral) No major named branches Gonads (testes/ovaries) Thin, descending; rarely visible unless dilated
Common Iliac Arteries L4 Aortic bifurcation Internal and external iliac arteries Pelvis, lower limbs  

Inferior mesenteric artery (Option B):
Incorrect because it arises much lower on the abdominal aorta (at L3), and would not be seen at this level.

Celiac artery (Option C):
Incorrect because the celiac trunk is typically located just above the SMA and trifurcates into left gastric, splenic, and common hepatic arteries — that trifurcation is not shown here.

Intestinal artery (Option D):
Incorrect term — intestinal branches arise from the SMA and IMA but are too small to be individually identified at this level on CT.

questions.text: Which of the following is an opsonin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - C3b:

  • C3b is a component of the complement system.
  • When C3b binds to the surface of pathogens, it acts as an opsonin, facilitating the binding of phagocytic cells to the pathogen.
  • This enhances phagocytosis and promotes the clearance of pathogens.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - C3a: C3a acts as an inflammatory mediator.

Option C - C5a: C5a acts as a potent chemoattractant for immune cells.

Option D - C6: C6 participates in the formation of the membrane attack complex, which helps destroy pathogens.

questions.text: Which organism is most likely responsible for the development of prosthetic valve endocarditis in a patient following valve replacement surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Staphylococcus epidermidis:

  • Staphylococcus epidermidis, is most commonly associated with prosthetic valve endocarditis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Staphylococcus aureus: This statement is incorrect. While Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of infective endocarditis, including native valve endocarditis, it is less commonly associated with prosthetic valve endocarditis

Option C - Coagulase-negative staphylococci are more commonly associated with prosthetic valve endocarditis within 12 months.

Option D - HACEK organisms: This statement is incorrect.

questions.text: CD-59 is involved in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria:

  • CD59 is a regulatory protein that inhibits the complement system, specifically membrane attack complex (MAC) formation.
  • In PNH, there is a deficiency of CD59 on the surface of red blood cells, making them susceptible to complement-mediated lysis.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What extra-articular manifestation is commonly observed in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subcutaneous nodule:

  • Subcutaneous nodules are the most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • These nodules typically develop over bony prominences or pressure points and are often found on the extensor surfaces of the forearms and elbows.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sjogren's syndrome: While Sjogren's syndrome, an autoimmune disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, can occur in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, it is not the most common extra-articular manifestation of the disease.

Option C - Felty's syndrome: Felty's syndrome is a rare complication of rheumatoid arthritis characterized by the triad of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia. It occurs in a small percentage of patients with rheumatoid arthritis but is not the most common extra-articular manifestation.

Option D - Vasculitis: Vasculitis, inflammation of blood vessels, can occur in rheumatoid arthritis but is not the most common extra-articular manifestation. It is less common compared to subcutaneous nodules.

questions.text: In which condition are macrophages observed to be positive for periodic acid Schiff staining?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Whipple's disease:

  • Whipple's disease is a rare systemic infectious disorder caused by the bacterium Tropheryma whipplei.
  • It is characterized by infiltration of small intestinal mucosa by ‘foamy macrophages’, which stain positive with periodic acid-schiff (PAS) reagent.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Agammaglobulinemia: This statement is incorrect. Agammaglobulinemia refers to a group of primary immunodeficiency disorders characterized by a lack of mature B cells and reduced or absent immunoglobulin production.

Option C - Abetalipoproteinemia: This statement is incorrect. Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the absence of beta-lipoproteins, leading to impaired absorption and transport of dietary fats and fat-soluble vitamins.

Option D - Crohn's disease: This statement is incorrect. While Crohn's disease is associated with the presence of macrophages and other immune cells in the affected intestinal tissue, PAS-positive macrophages are not a specific feature of Crohn's disease.

questions.text: Leiden mutation is of factor:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: V

  • Leiden mutation is a genetic mutation of factor V, also known as Factor V Leiden. Factor V is a protein involved in the blood clotting process. The Leiden mutation refers to a specific mutation in the factor V gene, which leads to an increased risk of abnormal blood clot formation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Factor VIII- Factor VIII is another protein involved in the blood clotting process, but it is not associated with the Leiden mutation.

Option C: Factor I- Factor I, also known as fibrinogen, is a protein involved in the formation of blood clots, but it is not associated with the Leiden mutation.

Option D: Factor X- Factor X is another protein involved in the blood clotting process, but it is not associated with the Leiden mutation.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis based on the image of the scan given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Craniopharyngioma

  • The image provided corresponds to a craniopharyngioma, a benign brain tumor that arises near the pituitary gland.
  • Craniopharyngiomas can have significant effects on hormone production, vision, and overall brain function.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A: Pituitary apoplexy- Pituitary apoplexy refers to a sudden hemorrhage or infarction (loss of blood supply) in the pituitary gland. It typically presents with sudden-onset severe headache, visual disturbances, and hormonal abnormalities. However, the given image is showing a craniopharyngioma and not indicative of pituitary apoplexy.

Option B: Pituitary macroadenoma- Pituitary macroadenoma is a benign tumor of the pituitary gland that measures more than 1 centimeter in size. These tumors can cause hormonal imbalances, visual disturbances, and headaches. However, the given image specifically shows a craniopharyngioma and not a pituitary macroadenoma.

Option C: Rathke cleft cyst- A Rathke cleft cyst is a benign cystic lesion that develops from remnants of Rathke's pouch, an embryological structure that contributes to the development of the pituitary gland. These cysts are typically asymptomatic and incidental findings on imaging. They are different from craniopharyngiomas, which are solid tumors.

questions.text: According to the Berlin definition, which of the following is not a characteristic of moderate ARDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 200 < PaO2/FiO2 =<300mm/Hg with PEEP Is moderate:

  • According to the Berlin definition, moderate ARDS is defined by a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 100-200 mmHg. A
  • PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 200-300 mmHg would fall into the mild ARDS category.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bilateral interstitial infiltrates: This statement is correct. 

Option C - Symptom onset within a week: This statement is correct. 

Option D - No cardiac failure in echocardiography: This statement is correct.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is associated with ATP7A gene causing low levels of copper in the blood stream?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Menke's disease

  • Menke's disease, also known as Menkes syndrome or copper transport disease, is a rare X-linked recessive disorder characterized by impaired copper absorption and transport.
  • It is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, which encodes a copper-transporting ATPase involved in the transport of copper into the cells.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by chronic jaundice due to impaired excretion of conjugated bilirubin. It is not related to copper metabolism or the ATP7A gene.

Option B: Wilson's disease

  • Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, leading to impaired copper transport and accumulation of copper in the liver and brain. It is associated with high levels of copper in tissues and low levels in the blood, but it is not caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene.

Option D: Gilbert's syndrome

  • It is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
  • The condition is caused by mutations in the UGT1A1 gene, which leads to reduced activity of the enzyme uridine diphosphate-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1). This enzyme is crucial for converting bilirubin into a form that can be excreted from the body.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important determinant of malignant potential in the papillary type of renal tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Size:

  • In the papillary type of renal tumor, the most important determinant of malignant potential is the size of the tumor.
  • One of the most important predictors is size:
    • Size < 1.5cm = Adenoma
    • Size ≥ 1.5cm = Papillary RCC

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the next recommended investigation to aid in diagnosing the condition of a patient who has cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ANCA:

  • The patient's presentation of cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy is suggestive of small vessel vasculitis.
  • ANCA testing is a valuable investigation in such case.
  • ANCA is a group of autoantibodies that target neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens.
  • Two main patterns of ANCA are recognized: cytoplasmic (c-ANCA) and perinuclear (p-ANCA).
  • c-ANCA is typically associated with antibodies against proteinase 3 (PR3) and is seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis).
  • p-ANCA is associated with antibodies against myeloperoxidase (MPO) and is seen in microscopic polyangiitis and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Churg-Strauss syndrome).

Incorrect Options:

Option B -  RA factor (rheumatoid factor): Rheumatoid factor is an autoantibody commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). While RA can involve multiple systems, including joints, it is not typically associated with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy. Therefore, performing RA factor testing is unlikely to provide relevant diagnostic information in this case.

Option C - HbsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen): Hepatitis B infection can present with various clinical manifestations, but cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy are not commonly associated with hepatitis B infection. Therefore, testing for HbsAg is unlikely to help diagnose the underlying condition in this case.

Option D - MIF (migration inhibitory factor): Migration inhibitory factor is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that has been implicated in various inflammatory conditions. However, it is not specific to any particular disease or diagnostic entity. Testing for MIF alone would not provide sufficient diagnostic information to identify the underlying cause of the patient's presentation with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: What is the most probable cause of hypokalemia, hypertension, and metabolic alkalosis in a 35-year-old female patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Liddle’s syndrome:

  • Liddle's syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease caused by a defect in epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) exhibiting a gain of function.
  • Liddle's syndrome is characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Bartter syndrome: Bartter syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects the loop of Henle in the kidney and leads to salt wasting, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.

Option B- Gitelman's syndrome: Gitelman's syndrome is another genetic disorder that affects the distal convoluted tubules of the kidney and results in hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and hypomagnesemia.

Option D- Fanconi's syndrome: Fanconi's syndrome is a condition characterized by dysfunction of the proximal tubules of the kidney, leading to hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis, and other electrolyte abnormalities can occur.

questions.text: What is the approximate time interval between HIV infection & manifestation of AIDS in an untreated patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 10 years:

  • 10 years: The approximate time interval between HIV infection and the manifestation of AIDS can vary significantly among individuals.
  • During this time, individuals infected with HIV may remain asymptomatic or experience mild symptoms.
  • As the disease progresses, the immune system becomes progressively weakened, leading to the development of opportunistic infections and other AIDS-related complications.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 7.5 years: This option underestimates the typical time interval between HIV infection and the manifestation of AIDS. It is important to note that the progression from HIV infection to AIDS can be influenced by various factors, including individual differences, viral factors, and access to healthcare and antiretroviral therapy.

Option C - 12 years: This option overestimates the typical time interval between HIV infection and the manifestation of AIDS. While some individuals may experience a longer latency period, the average duration is generally shorter than 12 years.

Option D - 5 years: This option significantly underestimates the typical time interval between HIV infection and the development of AIDS. In most cases, it takes longer than 5 years for HIV infection to progress to AIDS.

questions.text: Which diagnostic test is preferred for detecting HIV in a newborn delivered by an HIV-positive mother?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HIV DNA PCR:

  • HIV DNA PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) is the correct diagnostic test of choice for HIV in a baby born to an HIV-infected mother. This test detects the presence of HIV DNA in the baby's blood, providing early and accurate diagnosis of HIV infection. It is highly sensitive and can detect HIV infection as early as a few weeks after birth.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female came complains of weakness, easy fatigability, double vision and drooping of the upper eyelids. On examination her deep tendon reflexes are normal. What is the pathogenesis of the condition in this case?

choices.text: Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings
Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Decreased synaptic transmission at the myoneural junction:

  • The patient's symptoms—weakness, easy fatigability, double vision (diplopia), and drooping of the upper eyelids (ptosis)—along with normal deep tendon reflexes, suggest a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis. The pathogenesis of myasthenia gravis involves an autoimmune attack on the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
  • In myasthenia gravis, autoantibodies target and destroy acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This decreases the efficiency of synaptic transmission, leading to muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly after repeated use.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Decreased acetylcholine release at the nerve endings: This option is incorrect. In myasthenia gravis, the primary defect lies in the postsynaptic membrane of the neuromuscular junction, where autoantibodies target and interfere with AChRs.

Option B - Decreased myosin: This option is incorrect. Myosin is a protein involved in muscle contraction. Myasthenia gravis does not involve a decrease in myosin levels or dysfunction of myosin.

Option C - Absence of troponin C: This option is incorrect. Troponin C is a component of the regulatory complex involved in muscle contraction. Its absence is not associated with myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Weber's syndrome is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ipsilateral paralysis of lower face:

  • Weber's syndrome typically does not involve paralysis of the lower face.
  • Ipsilateral facial nerve palsy, or paralysis of the facial muscles on the same side as the brain lesion, such as Bell's palsy or lesions affecting the facial nerve itself.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Contralateral hemiplegia: Weber's syndrome, also known as midbrain syndrome, is characterized by the presence of contralateral hemiplegia.

Option B - Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy: Weber's syndrome is associated with ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy.

Option C - Contralateral parkinsonism: Weber's syndrome is commonly associated with contralateral parkinsonism.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is not typically observed in allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Low serum IgE levels:

  • Low serum IgE levels are incorrect. Elevated levels of serum IgE are a characteristic feature of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. IgE-mediated hypersensitivity to Aspergillus antigens leads to the production of specific IgE antibodies, resulting in an increased serum IgE level.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cough: Cough is a common symptom of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. It is typically productive and may be associated with the production of brownish sputum plugs.

Option C -  Wheezing: Wheezing is a common finding in allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. It is caused by the airway inflammation and narrowing resulting from the immune response to Aspergillus antigens.

Option D - Central bronchiectasis: Centeal bronchiectasis is a common feature of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). It is characterized by the dilation and thickening of the airways in the distal portions of the lungs.

questions.text: What is the most probable condition of a 10-year-old boy complaining of recurrent episodes of intense pain in his fingers and toes that spontaneously resolve over the course of the last year?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sickle cell anemia:

  • Sickle cell anemia is a genetic blood disorder characterized by the presence of abnormal hemoglobin, known as hemoglobin S.
  • In sickle cell anemia, the abnormal red blood cells can become stiff and sticky, leading to blockages in the blood vessels.
  • These blockages can cause episodes of pain called vaso-occlusive crises of sickle cell crises. These crises can occur in various parts of the body, including the bones, joints, and organs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alpha-thalassemia: Alpha-thalassemia is a genetic disorder characterized by reduced or absent production of alpha-globin chains. It can lead to anemia, but it typically does not cause episodes of pain or resolve on its own.

Option B - Beta-thalassemia: Beta-thalassemia is a genetic disorder characterized by reduced or absent production of beta-globin chains. Similar to alpha-thalassemia, it can cause anemia but does not typically present with episodes of pain that resolve spontaneously.

Option D - Von Willebrand disease type 1: Von Willebrand disease is a bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, a protein involved in blood clotting.

questions.text: What is grade 2 hypertension values according to the American Heart Association?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D -≥140/90 mmHg:

  • According to the current guidelines of AHA, immediate pharmacological management should be initiated in patients with hypertension if their blood pressure readings are consistently at or above ≥140/90 mmHg

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hepatitis C: 

  • Cryoglobulinemia refers to the presence of abnormal proteins called cryoglobulins in the blood.
  • These cryoglobulins can precipitate and cause inflammation in small blood vessels, leading to various symptoms and complications.
  • Cryoglobunimea is associated with Hepatitis C infections.

Incorrect Options:

  • Cryoglobulinemia is not associated with Options B, C and D. hence these options are incorrect.

questions.text: In which of the subsequent situations does oxygen therapy prove to be ineffective?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Central respiratory depression

  • In cases of central respiratory depression, oxygen therapy may not be beneficial or effective.
  • Central respiratory depression refers to a decrease or cessation of breathing due to a suppressed respiratory drive in the central nervous system. In such cases, providing oxygen alone may not stimulate the respiratory centers enough to overcome the underlying cause of respiratory depression.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Asthma- Oxygen therapy can be beneficial in asthma exacerbations. In asthma, there is bronchoconstriction and inflammation of the airways, which can lead to reduced oxygen levels. Supplemental oxygen can help improve oxygenation and alleviate symptoms in individuals with asthma.
Option B: Acute myocardial infarction- Oxygen therapy is commonly used in the management of acute myocardial infarction (heart attack). It helps to increase oxygen supply to the heart muscle and improve oxygenation in the body. Providing supplemental oxygen during an acute myocardial infarction can help reduce myocardial damage and improve outcomes.
Option C: Pulmonary edema- This option is incorrect. Oxygen therapy is typically used in the management of pulmonary edema. Pulmonary edema is characterized by fluid accumulation in the lungs, leading to impaired gas exchange. Supplemental oxygen can help improve oxygenation and relieve respiratory distress in individuals with pulmonary edema.

questions.text: What is the typical pattern observed in Brown-Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Contralateral loss of joint sense and position
Ipsilateral loss of complete sensory functions

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Contralateral loss of pain sensation:

  • The characteristic pattern seen in Brown-Sequard syndrome is contralateral loss of pain sensation.
  • Brown-Sequard syndrome is a neurological condition caused by damage to one half of the spinal cord.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D: These options are incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the thyroid function test results for a middle-aged woman diagnosed with Grave's disease, presenting symptoms such as tremors, palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities?

choices.text: Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Low TSH levels

  • Low TSH levels is the correct answer. In Grave's disease, an autoimmune disorder causing overactivity of the thyroid gland, the production and release of thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) are increased. The elevated levels of thyroid hormones exert negative feedback on the pituitary gland, suppressing the secretion of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). Therefore, in Grave's disease, TSH levels are typically low.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Low free T4 levels: In Grave's disease, there is excessive production of thyroid hormones, resulting in elevated levels of free T4. Therefore, low free T4 levels would be an unlikely finding in this condition.

Option C- Low serum T3 levels: Grave's disease is characterized by increased production of both T3 and T4. Thus, low serum T3 levels would not be expected in this condition.

Option D- Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) at 24 hours below normal: In Grave's disease, the thyroid gland is hyperactive and takes up iodine more than usual. This results in an increased radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) on a nuclear medicine scan, not a below-normal uptake.

questions.text: The observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match the patient's ECG findings. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Takotsubo cardiomyopathy:

  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as "broken heart syndrome," is a condition characterized by transient left ventricular dysfunction that typically occurs following an emotional or physical stressor.
  • The ECG findings in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy can vary and may not always match the observed myocardial stunning pattern.
  • This discrepancy between ECG findings and myocardial function is a characteristic feature of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Restrictive cardiomyopathy: Restrictive cardiomyopathy is a type of cardiomyopathy characterized by stiffening of the heart muscle, which impairs its ability to relax and fill with blood. The ECG findings in restrictive cardiomyopathy may show features such as low voltage QRS complexes and atrial abnormalities, but they are not typically associated with a discrepancy between ECG findings and myocardial stunning pattern.

Option C - Brugada syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with a loss of function mutation in cardiac sodium channels that predisposes affected individuals to fatal cardiac arrhythmias.

Option D - Pericardial tamponade: Pericardial tamponade is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, which compresses the heart and impairs its ability to fill properly. The ECG findings in pericardial tamponade often show specific patterns, such as electrical alternans and low voltage QRS complexes.

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Serum ceruloplasmin levels:

  • The clinical presentation of hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration, along with the presence of Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings in the eyes, is highly suggestive of Wilson's disease, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired hepatic copper transport leading to copper accumulation in various organs, including the liver, brain, and eyes. This leads to the characteristic KF rings seen on ocular examination.
  • The initial step in the diagnostic workup of a suspected case of Wilson's disease is to measure serum ceruloplasmin levels. Ceruloplasmin is a copper-binding protein synthesized in the liver, and low levels of ceruloplasmin are commonly observed in Wilson's disease due to impaired copper incorporation into the protein.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Serum ceruloplasmin is a more appropriate diagnostic test in this scenario.

questions.text: Which antiretroviral drug is not utilized in cases of concurrent HIV and hepatitis B infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Abacavir:

  • Abacavir is primarily used for the treatment of HIV but is not effective against hepatitis B. Therefore, it is not typically used in the management of HIV and hepatitis B co-infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tenofovir: Tenofovir is an antiretroviral drug that is commonly used in the treatment of both HIV and hepatitis B. It is effective against both viruses and is often included in the antiretroviral regimen for individuals with HIV and hepatitis B co-infection.

Option C - Lamivudine: Lamivudine is an antiretroviral drug that is effective against both HIV and hepatitis B. It is frequently used in the treatment of individuals with HIV and hepatitis B co-infection.

Option D - Emtricitabine: Emtricitabine is another antiretroviral drug that is effective against both HIV and hepatitis B. It is commonly included in the treatment regimen for individuals with co-infection.

questions.text: ‘c’ wave in JVP is seen in?

choices.text: Slow filling at end of diastole

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Iso-volumetric contraction:

  • The 'c' wave in the JVP is typically seen during the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle. It occurs during early ventricular systole when the tricuspid valve bulges back into the right atrium due to the increased pressure in the right ventricle. This causes a slight rise in the JVP.
  • The isovolumetric contraction occurs immediately after the closure of the atrioventricular valves (mitral and tricuspid valves) and before the onset of ventricular ejection.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: For which of the following conditions is automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) implantation performed?

choices.text: Acute coronary syndrome with low ejection fraction

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - All the above:

  • Automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) implantation is indicated for all of the mentioned conditions.

Option A - Brugada syndrome: AICD implantation is recommended for patients with Brugada syndrome who have a history of aborted sudden cardiac death (SCD), syncope, or documented ventricular arrhythmias.

Option B - Ventricular fibrillation: AICD implantation is the treatment of choice for patients who have survived a cardiac arrest due to ventricular fibrillation (VF) or sustained ventricular tachycardia (VT) with hemodynamic compromise.

Option C - Acute coronary syndrome with low ejection fraction: AICD implantation is considered for patients with acute coronary syndrome who have reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (EF) (typically ≤35%) and are at risk of sudden cardiac death.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the actions of endothelin-1 except_________.
questions.solution:
Correct Options A - Bronchodilation:

  • Endothelin 1 is the most potent vasoconstrictor known so far. Veins are more sensitive to endothelin 1 than arteries. Endothelin-1 can cause a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) by constricting the afferent arterioles of the kidney.
  • It is also a potent positive chronotropic and inotropic agent (increases heart rate and myocardial contractility).

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: In which electrolyte abnormality is Pseudo P pulmonale observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hypokalemia:

  • Pseudo p pulmonale is seen in hypokalemia, and it refers to tall peaked P waves seen in patients with this condition.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the most effective stimulus for increasing aldosterone secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hyperkalemia:

  • Aldosterone secretion is maximally stimulated by hyperkalemia, which refers to an elevated level of potassium in the blood.
  • High levels of potassium act directly on the adrenal cortex, specifically the zona glomerulosa, to increase aldosterone production and release.
  • Aldosterone acts on the kidneys to promote potassium excretion and sodium reabsorption, helping to regulate electrolyte balance.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - ACTH: While ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) does stimulate the secretion of aldosterone to some extent, it is not the primary factor that maximally stimulates aldosterone secretion. ACTH primarily stimulates the secretion of cortisol from the adrenal cortex.

Option C - Hypernatremia: Hypernatremia decreases the aldosterone secretion.

Option D - Hyponatremia: It also increases the secretion of aldosterone, nut is not the most potent stimulus.

questions.text: cGMP is the second messenger of
questions.solution:
Correct Option D:  NO (nitric oxide)

  • Nitric oxide (NO) activates the enzyme guanylate cyclase, which converts guanosine triphosphate (GTP) into cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP).
  • cGMP then serves as the second messenger, mediating various cellular responses.
  • NO is a key signaling molecule involved in several physiological processes, including vasodilation, neurotransmission, and immune regulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Somatostatin- Somatostatin acts through G-protein-coupled receptors, but its second messenger system involves inhibitory G-proteins and intracellular pathways such as the inhibition of adenylate cyclase and decrease in cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) levels.
